policy_description: Directs the AZDHS to implement a statewide contact tracing and case investigation system.
intended_duration: Until further notice with consideration for revision or repeal every 2 weeks

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist)
policy_description: Requires that all molecular devices and assays used in point of care settings be approved by the Secretary of Health before use.

policy_subtarget: Public sector/government employees; Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist); Manufacturers
policy_description: Prohibits the use of SARS-CoV-2 serologic tests that have not been FDA approved through the EUA process or that have not received written approval by the Secretary of Health. Prohibits the use of all serologic assays, including rapid point of care devices, outside of CLIA-certified laboratories or settings.

Announcement that the State of California will in partnership with Apple and Google,  participate in a Exposure Notification Technology pilot program, which will confidentially notify product users if they may have been exposed to COVID-19.

policy_subtarget: Essential business (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive); Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services
policy_description: Executive Order No. 7UU, is repealed and replaced with the following: There shall be a program of mandatory testing for COVID-19 of the staff of private and municipal nursing home facilities, managed residential communities, and assisted living services agencies as detailed.
All Affected Travelers shall complete a Travel Health Form.

policy_subtarget: Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare); Primary education; Secondary education
policy_description: Local Education Agencies must notify parents/guardians and students aged 18 and up if the school becomes aware that a person who tested positive was in the school building at the same time as students.

Food and drink establishments  are required to notify patrons that they may provide their name and contact information to the establishment, so that they may be contacted if another patron or employee has tested positive for COVID-19.  Logistical and structural changes must be employed to facilitate social distancing within the food and drink establishment.

Local Education Agencies must notify parents/guardians and students aged 18 and up if the school becomes aware that a person who tested positive was in the school building at the same time as students.

Mayor Bowser establishes the DC Contact Trace Force to hire hundreds of additional tracers at DC Health. DC Health currently has around 65 contact tracers and is in the process of increasing that team to 200 tracers. During Phase One of reopening, up to 700 additional tracers may be hired.

The District is expanding the criteria for priority COVID-19 testing to include essential workers with a history of exposure to a confirmed COVID-19 patient, regardless of whether they are symptomatic.

The Director of the Department of Health must establish a goal and make the best effort to hire at least 50% District residents for the Contact Trace Force initiative. For the position of investigator, the goal must be to hire at least 25% graduates from a workforce development or adult education program funded or administered by the District of Columbia.

During the public health emergency, dentists are authorized to administer swab tests for COVID-19 as well as supervise self-tests and collect swabs. Audiologists, speech language pathologists, and their assistants are authorized to observe self-tests for COVID-19 and collect self-test swabs.

The Director of the Department of Health must establish a goal and make the best effort to hire at least 50% District residents for the Contact Trace Force initiative. For the position of investigator, the goal must be to hire at least 25% graduates from a workforce development or adult education program funded or administered by the District of Columbia.

The Director of the Department of Health must establish a goal and make the best effort to hire at least 50% District residents for the Contact Trace Force initiative. For the position of investigator, the goal must be to hire at least 25% graduates from a workforce development or adult education program funded or administered by the District of Columbia.

Non-District residents coming from any state or country other than a low-risk jurisdiction (with fewer than 10 cases per 100,000) must test negative for COVID-19 within 72 hours of arrival in order to enter the District. Visitors to the District staying for more than 3 days should limit their activities until they obtain a second negative test result, administered 3 to 5 days after arrival.  Virginia and Maryland residents are exempt. There are special provisions for essential workers.

DC is piloting asymptomatic testing protocols for students and staff participating in DC Public Schools in-person programming. With parental consent, students may receive a PCR swab test every ten days. DCPS staff will receive a self-administered testing kit in the mail once per week. Students and staff may continue to participate in in-person programming while test results are pending.

Directs the Illinois Department of Public Health, Illinois Department of Insurance, and Illinois Department of Healthcare and Family Services to take necessary actions to ensure expanded access to COVID-19 testing, and that consumers do not face financial barriers in accessing testing and treatment services for COVID-19.

Directs the Illinois Department of Public Health, Illinois Department of Insurance, and Illinois Department of Healthcare and Family Services to take necessary actions to ensure expanded access to COVID-19 testing, and that consumers do not face financial barriers in accessing testing and treatment services for COVID-19.

Directs the Illinois Department of Public Health, Illinois Department of Insurance, and Illinois Department of Healthcare and Family Services to take necessary actions to ensure expanded access to COVID-19 testing, and that consumers do not face financial barriers in accessing testing and treatment services for COVID-19.

Directs the Illinois Department of Public Health, Illinois Department of Insurance, and Illinois Department of Healthcare and Family Services to take necessary actions to ensure expanded access to COVID-19 testing, and that consumers do not face financial barriers in accessing testing and treatment services for COVID-19.

Announces release of COVID-19 data related to the state's contact tracing operation, building on the administration's commitment to transparency in its data-driven response to the pandemic. This includes statewide COVID-19 data related to outbreaks and exposure locations as well as school-level data in both categories.

Directs the Illinois Department of Public Health, Illinois Department of Insurance, and Illinois Department of Healthcare and Family Services to take necessary actions to ensure expanded access to COVID-19 testing, and that consumers do not face financial barriers in accessing testing and treatment services for COVID-19.

Directs the Illinois Department of Public Health, Illinois Department of Insurance, and Illinois Department of Healthcare and Family Services to take necessary actions to ensure expanded access to COVID-19 testing, and that consumers do not face financial barriers in accessing testing and treatment services for COVID-19.

Clinician's order is not required for lab services, for insurers to cover testing costs, and clinicians do not need to establish formal clinician-patient relationship to conduct testing. And all medical plans are required to provide coverage for diagnosis
Surge COVID-19 testing will be taking place at the Keeneland Race Course in Fayetteville County.
Health care providers are authorized to collect and submit SARS-CoV-2 molecular or antigen tests for laboratory analysis.
intended_duration: For the duration of the public health emergency

policy_description: Healthcare providers must write down information for the patient about how and when they will receive test results, next steps to take following the test, and an outline for expectations for maintaining self-quarantine for 14 days.
intended_duration: For the duration of the public health emergency

policy_description: Collection sites must use appropriate PPE and store specimen of SARS-CoV-2 carefully. They also must report the total number of COVID-19 tests performed to the Maine CDC.
intended_duration: For the duration of the public health emergency

policy_description: Any individual in Maine who is at least 12 months old may obtain testing for SARS-CoV-2.
intended_duration: For the duration of the public health emergency

policy_description: Orders Maryland Secretary of Health to establish a process for the authorization of COVID-19 testing labs.
Incarcerated persons due for early release must be screened for symptoms of COVID-19. Those displaying symptoms must be isolated immediately and tested for COVID-19. Any
Universal testing is required of all residents and staffs at nursing homes. Residents will also be evaluated daily.
Licensed pharmacists may order COVID-19 tests for patients and collect specimens for COVID-19 testing.
All staff, volunteers, and vendors who are in the facility regularly, shall be tested on a weekly basis for COVID-19 using a reverse transcription PCR-type test
Incarcerated persons due for early release must be screened for symptoms of COVID-19. Those displaying symptoms must be isolated immediately and tested for COVID-19. Any

All nursing home staff, volunteers, and vendors who are in the facility regularly shall be tested at least twice a week, until further notice, with a combination of one reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction-type test (PCR Assay) and one rapid point-of-care COVID-19 diagnostic testing device (POC system) on separate days.
All nursing home residents who have not previously tested positive for COVID-19, per CDC guidance, shall be tested using a PCR assay once a week.

Nursing homes shall establish a cohort of staff who are assigned to care for known or suspected COVID-19 residents. Nursing homes shall designate a room, series of rooms, unit, or floor of the nursing home as a separate observation area where newly admitted and readmitted residents are kept for 14 days while being observed every shift for signs and symptoms of COVID-19. Nursing homes shall designate a room, series of rooms, unit, or floor of the nursing home to care for residents with known or suspected COVID-19.
Governor Baker announced a collaboration with Partners in Health to hire 1000 contact tracers for COVID-19 community mitigation

policy_subtarget: Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Indoor spaces
policy_description: If a host or event venue is notified that an event attendee or event worker has tested positive for COVID-19, the event host or event venue must immediately notify the Local Board of Health in the city or town where the event took place. Hosts and event venues must assist the Department of Public Health and Local Boards of Health with contact tracing and case investigations, including, upon request, providing lists of attendees at social gatherings and their contact information. Event hosts and venues who fail to timely report positive cases or cooperate with contact tracing and case investigations may be subject to penalties and be in violation of this order.

policy_subtarget: Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Indoor spaces
policy_description: If a host or event venue is notified that an event attendee or event worker has tested positive for COVID-19, the event host or event venue must immediately notify the Local Board of Health in the city or town where the event took place. Hosts and event venues must assist the Department of Public Health and Local Boards of Health with contact tracing and case investigations, including, upon request, providing lists of attendees at social gatherings and their contact information. Event hosts and venues who fail to timely report positive cases or cooperate with contact tracing and case investigations may be subject to penalties and be in violation of this order.
Allows for free drive thru testing through the end of May
Increases testing site and who has an authority to order a test

policy_subtarget: Public sector/government employees; Criminal justice system/prisons/jails/incarcerated persons
policy_description: There must be state assistance for expanded testing: The Department of Health and Human Services must provide direct assistance with testing supplies, specimen collection, and laboratory processing to jails and local lockups that request assistance.
The department must conduct COVID-19 diagnostic testing in all of its facilities consistent with guidance issued by the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services.

The Department of Corrections facilities must conduct COVID-19 diagnostic testing in all of its facilities. The Department of Health and Human Services must provide direct assistance with testing to jails and local lockups that request assistance.

Medical assistance is available for uninsured individuals for the purpose of testing for and diagnosing COVID-19 as stated in the Social Security Act. Coverage is limited to any diagnostic product available for the detection of COVID-19, necessary to make the diagnosis of COVID-19, and the associated visit.

The state’s saliva testing program will the open of new testing sites, Moorhead on October 17 and Brooklyn Park on October 20, and a pilot of the mail order program. These sites will offer free saliva tests to any Minnesotan who believes they need to be tested, as part of the state’s strategy to provide easy access to quick, reliable testing.

A new saliva testing center will open at the Minneapolis Convention Center, in addition to 11 other new testing sites across the state. The new sites will be open for anyone, with no barriers to access. Testing sites will offer a combination of PCR and saliva tests.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Minors and children
policy_description: Director of Department of Health and Senior Services orders the immediate initiation of contact tracing for school children between the ages of 3 and 21. Local public health agencies should begin contact tracing within 24 hours of a positive test, and the agency should notify the school to expedite contact tracing. If a school is notified of a relevant positive COVID-19 test result, the school will immediately notify the local health authority.

The next round of community testing events will take place in 8 counties from Sept. 14-23. Anyone can receive a free test regardless of where they live or whether they are having symptoms. Over 50 counties in Missouri already participated in community testing from April to July.
Pharmacies authorized to initiate, order, administer, and analyze SARS-CoV-2 point-of-care diagnostic test kits to detect SARS-CoV-2 or its antibodies.

All staff and volunteers must receive a PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 and test negative in the 7 day period before arriving at camp. Staff and volunteers must undergo a second PCR test upon arrival at the camp (Day 1 of 14 day quarantine). Staff and volunteers must undergo a third PCR test one week into quarantine (Day 7 of 14 day quarantine). All results must be back for all staff before the arrival of campers. Records must be kept of all tests and results. Anyone testing positive must be isolated immediately.
Camper’s will not be allowed on camp if parents/guardians do not give consent for testing as outlined in this document, including testing on an ad hoc basis if camper becomes symptomatic.

Any person (staff, volunteer, or camper) who develops any of the above symptoms must be tested for COVID-19 using an appropriately collected nasopharyngeal swab. Camp medical directors should be the ordering clinician for all COVID-19 specimen collection and testing conducted through the camp.

All campers must must receive a PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 and test negative in the 7 day period before arriving at camp. Campers must also undergo a second test upon arrival and a third test during their second week at camp. Records must be kept of all tests and results. Any camper testing positive should be isolated immediately.

For contract tracing purposes, businesses must maintain a record of clients receiving services, the date and time of those services, and the identities of staff who had direct interaction with clients receiving services.

For contract tracing purposes, businesses must maintain a record of clients receiving services, the date and time of those services, and the identities of staff who had direct interaction with clients receiving services.

For contract tracing purposes, businesses must maintain a record of clients receiving services, the date and time of those services, and the identities of staff who had direct interaction with clients receiving services.
Double its testing capacity from 20,000 a day by the end of May and 25,000 a day by the end of June
Implements a robust contact tracing program

Launch of contact tracing dashboard to monitor the percentage of cases successfully interviewed, those who provided contacts, contacts notified, and more. The governor urges civilians to answer contact tracing phone calls.

Announcement of the launch of COVID-19 exposure notification mobile apps in New Jersey and New York. New Jersey and New York will join Pennsylvania and Delaware in creating a regional COVID Alert app network that operates across state lines.

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist)
policy_description: Governor Andrew Cuomo extended an order that the Department of Health create a statewide process for prioritizing who gets tested statewide. Testing labs must comply with this process, testing first those individuals prioritized by the state government.

Amendment: Nursing homes & similar facilities are still required to conduct COVID-19 for all personnel and to notify the Department of Health of positive results, but in counties that have entered Phase 2 or greater, testing must occur only once weekly (as opposed to twice weekly in counties in Phase 1).

Mobile testing teams are deployed to counties with high numbers of seasonal workers in agriculture, to assist with early detection.
Testing of wastewater for viral RNA is expanded, to investigate whether this program can provide a useful indicator of COVID-19's prevalence throughout the population.

In neighborhoods experiencing outbreaks of COVID-19 and classified as "yellow zones" by Department of Health's cluster action initiative, schools must adhere to Department of Health guidance regarding mandatory testing of personnel and students.
Extension: nursing homes & similar facilities are required to conduct COVID-19 tests for all personnel and to notify the Department of Health of positive results. Testing must occur once weekly.

Extension with modifications: nursing homes & similar facilities are required to conduct COVID-19 tests for all personnel and to notify the Department of Health of positive results. Testing must occur once weekly. Additionally, in regions identified as yellow, orange, or red zones by the Department of Health's cluster action initiative, nursing homes must now follow the direction of the Commissioner of Health regarding testing of personnel.

Governor Cooper expands the testing, ordering the State Health Director to issue standing orders allowing those who fit North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services criteria to be tested.
Authorizes PCR testing for all residents of the Grand Forks County, to be carried out by the Grand Forks Health Department

The State Health Department authorised PCR testing for all residents and employees of nursing homes, assisting living facilities, and similar centres, to be carried out by the respective centres' Registered Nurses.
The State Health Department authorised PCR testing for all residents of certain counties included in the First District Health Unit (FDHU), to be carried out by FDHU staff.
intended_duration: Until end of emergency, or rescinded

policy_description: Nursing homes must follow testing guidelines set by the Ohio Dept of Public Health.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space; Non essential business (inclusive); Confirmed cases
policy_description: A PCR COVID-19 test must be administered to each athlete and team staff member participating in inter-team contact sport competition no more than 72 hours prior to the start of the competition and the results must be in hand prior to the state of the competition. If competition lasts more than four days, administer a second COVID-19 test four days after the first test was administered. A negative test clears the athlete for competition; a positive test prohibits the athlete, teammates and all team staff from continued participation in the competition. Testing should occur every two days following the second test.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space; Non essential business (inclusive); Confirmed cases
policy_description: EXTENSION: A PCR COVID-19 test must be administered to each athlete and team staff member participating in inter-team contact sport competition no more than 72 hours prior to the start of the competition and the results must be in hand prior to the state of the competition. If competition lasts more than four days, administer a second COVID-19 test four days after the first test was administered. A negative test clears the athlete for competition; a positive test prohibits the athlete, teammates and all team staff from continued participation in the competition. Testing should occur every two days following the second test.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space; Non essential business (inclusive); Confirmed cases

If competition lasts more than four days, administer a second COVID-19 test four days after the first test was administered. A negative test clears the athlete for competition; a positive test prohibits the athlete, teammates and all team staff from continued participation in the competition. Testing should occur every two days following the second test.

If a confirmed case of COVID-19 participated in competitive play, the team must notify all opponents played between the date of the positive test and two days prior to the onset of symptoms. If the teams, schools, or clubs reside in different counties, the health departments in each county must be notified to help facilitate effective contact tracing.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Nursing homes/assisted living facility
policy_description: Residential care facilities licensed by the Ohio Department of Health shall cooperate with COVID-19 testing for residents and staff as required by the State. Testing shall include, but is not limited to, staff testing and strategic testing of residents.

If a confirmed case of COVID-19 participated in competitive play, the team must notify all opponents played between the date of the positive test and two days prior to the onset of symptoms. If the teams, schools, or clubs reside in different counties, the health departments in each county must be notified to help facilitate effective contact tracing.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Public services
policy_description: Once testing is readily available, senior center facilities shall test all suspected infections or exposures.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Public services
policy_description: Senior center facilities shall work with local health department to identify potentially infected or exposed individuals to help facilitate effective contact tracing/notifications.
Governor Kevin Stitt authorized University of Oklahoma and Oklahoma State University labs to perform testing.
intended_duration: Until end of state of emergency

policy_description: A statewide plan was established for testing all long-term care facilities (LTCs) by September 30, and testing all LTCs once per month thereafter.
All nursing home staff and residents must be tested for COVID-19 at least once by July 24, at which point nursing homes must continue to comply with testing-related guidance from the state.
Businesses must collect information to assist contact tracers.
The Department of Corrections conducted a mass testing event at the South Dakota Women’s Prison covering 112 inmates
Extension: Nursing homes may request operation and financial support in testing residents/staff from the Department of Health and the National Guard.
Expands testing in communities more heavily impacted by coronavirus
Pharmacists are authorized to conduct COVID-19 tests, subject to specific requirements.

Students at institutions of higher education who attend in-person classes or live on campus must receive COVID-19 tests at least once per week; this requirement goes into effect as soon as possible, and must be implemented by January 1, 2021 at the latest.

Extension with modifications: Students who are at least 18 years old and who attend in-person classes or live on campus at institutions of higher education must receive COVID-19 tests at least once per week; this requirement goes into effect as soon as possible, and must be implemented by January 1, 2021 at the latest.

Extension with modifications: Students who are at least 18 years old and who attend in-person classes or live on campus at institutions of higher education must receive COVID-19 tests at least once every fourteen days. This requirement only applies to public institutions and private institutions enrolling at least 10,000 students in Utah. This requirement goes into effect as soon as possible, and must be implemented by January 1, 2021 at the latest.

Extension: Students who are at least 18 years old and who attend in-person classes or live on campus at institutions of higher education must receive COVID-19 tests at least once every fourteen days. This requirement only applies to public institutions and private institutions enrolling at least 10,000 students in Utah. This requirement goes into effect as soon as possible, and must be implemented by January 1, 2021 at the latest.
Individuals must provide complete and accurate information to contact tracers and comply with their instructions regarding testing.
Non-essential businesses (including restaurants) must maintain a log of customer contact information to assist contact tracing.
Extension: non-essential businesses (including restaurants) must maintain a log of customer contact information to assist contact tracing.
Extension: individuals must provide complete and accurate information to contact tracers and comply with their instructions regarding testing.

Governor Inslee specified that restaurants and bars should not require patrons to provide contact information, but that restaurants and bars are still required to maintain a 30-day log and patrons are encouraged to provide information to assist contact tracing.
Personal information collected for purposes of contact tracing and other public health purposes relating to COVID-19 is protected from public release (for example, under a public records request).

Agricultural employers must ensure employees have access to testing if an outbreak occurs among their employees; for employees that they house in isolation, they must ensure access to medical monitoring and emergency medical care is available.

The leaders of the state legislature extended the following policy: Personal information collected for purposes of contact tracing and other public health purposes relating to COVID-19 is protected from public release (for example, under a public records request).

Governor Jim Justice ordered that the WV National Guard be mobilized to work with the Division of Health and Human Resources and local health departments to test all employees and residents of nursing homes in the state, including those previously tested.
In high transmission counties, the WV Department of Health and National Guard are to work to scale up free testing within 24 hours.
The state is providing resources for all public and private not-for-profit institutions of higher education to conduct surveillance testing for 10% of their population each week.
All staff at nursing homes and assisted living facilities must be tested for COVID-19 twice weekly.
The governor announced the intention to test students at institutions of higher education for COVID-19 on a biweekly basis.
The Alabama Bureau of Pardons and Paroles is suspending indefinitely public visitation to its LIFE Tech Transition Center in Thomasville as a precaution as the coronavirus spreads nationally

State government offices will be closed at the direction of the Governor. State agency heads will receive instructions from the Governor's Office or the State Personnel Director if closures are authorized.
Government bodies may hold meetings and establish quorum through digital mediums and shall make these digital meetings available to the public during and after they take place.
intended_duration: For the duration of the current emergency conditions

policy_description: Corporations may find alternative ways to host stockholder meetings, if they implement a reasonable means of verifying the identity of stockholders, provided stockholders participating remotely with reasonable means of engaging in the meeting, provide notice to stockholders of changes to meeting procedure, and make available a list of the stockholders eligible to vote at the meeting.

A county or municipality may authorize law enforcement officers to issue summonses in lieu of arrest, except for cases of violent or threats of violent crimes, use or possession of alcohol or a controlled substance in a way that poses a threat to public safety, where the victim is a minor, the person is charged with driving under the influence, and person is charged with a crime that would require restitution to the victim.
The Board of Pardons and Paroles will resume hearings in a manner that minimizes human-to-human interaction.

policy_subtarget: Public sector/government employees; Hotels/lodging; Housing sector; Non-governmental organizations
policy_description: A government entity or nonprofit that offers temporary shelter due to the COVID-19 outbreak and that independently identifies a need to offer non-congregate sheltering shall provide the temporary shelter and necessary wrap-around using non-congregate solutions. Individuals qualified for this include those who are high risk and first responders.

policy_subtarget: Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services
policy_description: Businesses and healthcare facilities may re-open and be reasonable protected from lawsuits so long as they comply with public health guidance.
intended_duration: Until the public health emergency is terminated

policy_description: The July 14, 2020 runoff election will be run by fewer poll workers. Probate judges must approve and may inspect polling conditions. Costs of implementing this--especially related to reimbursing poll workers--will be reimbursed per Ala. Code 17-16-1.
Anyone using a beach shall maintain six feet of distance between themselves and those not from their household.
Safer at home policies, including recommendations for individuals, quarantine for infected persons, non-work related gatherings, and protections for employees/customers will be implemented.
All non-work related gatherings of any size, including drive-in gatherings, that cannot maintain a consistent six-foot distance between persons from different households are prohibited.
Entertainment venues may open with guidelines.

All employers shall take reasonable steps, where practicable as work duties permit, to protect their employees by maintaining a distance of six feet, disinfecting items and surfaces, encouraging handwashing, preventing employees who are sick from encountering other people, facilitating remote work options, and minimizing employee travel. They will also protect customers by ensuring six feet of distance and regularly disinfecting surfaces.
Retailers will limit occupancy to 50%, not allow customers or patrons to congregate within six feet, and comply with CDC recommendations on sanitation.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Close-contact service providers—such as barber shops, hair salons, waxing salons, threading salons, nail salons and spas, body art facilities, tattoo services, and massage therapy establishments and services—shall not allow clients/those accompanying them to congregate within six feet, have employees wear a facial mask, enforce hand sanitation, and sanitize surfaces where practicable.
Entertainment venues must encourage customers to maintain six feet of distance, cap capacity at 50%, require employees to wear face coverings, and adopt reasonable sanitation practices.

Effective May 23, 2020, at 5:00 P.M., facilities providing child day care, including any child day care facility described in Ala. Code § 38-7-2, shall comply with the following rules:  a. Social distancing. Employees shall not knowingly allow parents or other guests to congregate within six feet of a person from another household. Facilities shall also take reasonable steps to prevent parents or other guests from congregating in lobby areas, cafeterias, and other common areas.  b. Sanitation. Child day care facilities shall take reasonable steps, where practicable, to regularly disinfect frequently used items and surfaces. c. Facial coverings. Each employee shall wear a mask or other facial covering that covers his or her nostrils and mouth at all times while in regular interaction with students or guests

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Effective May 23, 2020, day and overnight youth summer camps shall comply with the following rules:  a. Social distancing. (i) Employees shall not knowingly allow campers or guests to congregate within six feet of a person from another household. (ii) Employees shall not knowingly allow campers or guests to participate in athletic activities in violation of paragraph 10.  b. Sanitation. Camps shall take reasonable steps where practicable, to regularly disinfect frequently used items and surfaces.  c. Facial coverings. Employees shall, to the greatest extent practicable, wear a mask or other facial covering that covers his or her nostrils and mouth at all times when in regular interaction with campers and guests.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Primary education; Secondary education; Higher education
policy_description: Effective June 1, 2020, all schools, public and private—including elementary, secondary, postsecondary, technical, and specialty schools, and colleges and universities—shall comply with the following rules: a. Social distancing. Schools shall take reasonable steps, where practicable, to maintain six feet of separation between persons of different households. b. Sanitation. Schools shall take reasonable steps, where practicable, to regularly disinfect frequently used items and surfaces. c. Facial coverings. Employees shall, to the greatest extent practicable, wear a mask or other facial covering that covers his or her nostrils and mouth at all times when in regular interaction within six feet of a person from a different household.
All athletic facilities must implement rules of social distancing, facial coverings (except when actively participating in athletic activities), and sanitation.
Nonprofit corporations may hold board meetings remotely, as long as eligible members can vote and participate.
intended_duration: Duration of the public health emergency

policy_description: County sheriffs and jails are ordered to maintain custody of inmates until they can be transferred safely to a Department facility.
Safer at home policies, including recommendations for individuals, quarantine for infected persons, non-work related gatherings, and protections for employees/customers will be implemented.

Visitation by the general public will be suspended to Department of Corrections (DOC) Facilities, Division of Juvenile Justice Facilities, Alaska Military Youth Academy Alaska Psychiatric Institute, with limited visitation to Alaska Pioneer Homes.
intended_duration: Until suspended by the Department of Health and Human Services and the Office of the Govenor

policy_description: All individuals arriving in Alaska are required to self-quarantine for 14 days. Businesses providing critical infrastructure must submit a plan for how to maintain function under this rule without endangering the lives of the communities where they operate.

Gatherings of individuals and social organizations may occur if they adhere to certain social distancing, travel (including a 14 day quarantine if arriving from out of state), and (if symptomatic) isolation protocols.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Personal care facilities
policy_description: Personal care services may begin to take reservations for services.
Camping and Lodging facilities may resume operations

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space; Gym/workout facility/fitness center
policy_description: Outdoor classes and activities at gyms and fitness centers may resume operations.
Retail businesses may resume operations.
Restaurants may resume dine-in table service.
Non-essential businesses can resume operations.
Non-public-facing businesses may resume operations.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Personal care facilities
policy_description: Personal care services that begin to take reservations for services must follow certain social distancing, hygiene, staffing, and cleaning protocols.
Non-essential businesses that resume operations must follow certain social distancing, hygiene, staffing, and cleaning protocols.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Retail stores (not including food)
policy_description: Retail businesses that resume operations must meet certain social distancing, hygiene, staffing, and cleaning requirements.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space; Gym/workout facility/fitness center
policy_description: Outdoor classes and activities at gyms and fitness centers that resume operations must follow certain social distancing, hygiene, staffing, and cleaning protocols.
Restaurants that resume table service must maintain social distancing, capacity, operational, hygiene, staffing, and cleaning protocols.
Non-public-facing businesses that resume operations must follow certain social distancing, hygiene, staffing, and cleaning protocols.
Camping and Lodging facilities must file a protective plan or adopt certain social distancing, hygiene, staffing, and cleaning protocols to resume operations.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Homeless shelters/homeless individuals
policy_description: Provides FEMA reimbursement eligibility for temporary sheltering and quarantine for homeless individuals, emergency responders, adults with underlying conditions, and individuals who are unable to self-quarantine.
intended_duration: Duration of the Public Health Disaster Emergency Declaration

policy_description: Allows charitable gaming permittees to conduct raffles, lotteries and other contests online.
intended_duration: Duration of the Public Health Disaster Emergency Declaration

policy_description: Allows business to be conducted virtually and via electronic communications for boards of corporations, non-profit, and ANCs.
intended_duration: Duration of the Public Health Disaster Emergency Declaration

policy_subtarget: Essential workers (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Farming/Agriculture/Food processing
policy_description: Provides guidance for critical infrastructure workers in Alaska. Specific guidance for the following industries: commercial fishing, independent harvesters, and seafood processing plants.
intended_duration: Duration of the Public Health Disaster Emergency Declaration

policy_description: Allows business to be conducted virtually and via electronic communications for boards of corporations, non-profit, and ANCs.
intended_duration: Duration of the Public Health Disaster Emergency Declaration

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Homeless shelters/homeless individuals
policy_description: Provides FEMA reimbursement eligibility for temporary sheltering and quarantine for homeless individuals, emergency responders, adults with underlying conditions, and individuals who are unable to self-quarantine.
intended_duration: Duration of the Public Health Disaster Emergency Declaration

policy_description: Allows charitable gaming permittees to conduct raffles, lotteries and other contests online.
intended_duration: Duration of the Public Health Disaster Emergency Declaration

policy_subtarget: Essential workers (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Farming/Agriculture/Food processing
policy_description: Provides guidance for critical infrastructure workers in Alaska. Specific guidance for the following industries: commercial fishing, independent harvesters, and seafood processing plants.
intended_duration: Duration of the Public Health Disaster Emergency Declaration

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Restaurants/bars; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Manufacturers; Retail stores (not including food)
policy_description: Restaurants, bars, movie theaters, and indoor gyms will confirmed cases of COVID-19 will close access to the public until further notice. Restaurants may continue to serve the public through pick up, delivery, and drive-thru. Law enforcement officers will not enforce provisions prohibiting the sale of alcohol off-premises, so long as they are sold in sealed containers and are only sold to individuals over 21. Manufacturers, wholesalers, or retailers may buy back unopened products from restaurants, bars, and clubs. Cafeterias that provide meals to the needy may continue normal operations.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Institutions including Nursing Care, Residential Care, ICF-IIDs, and DD Medical Group homes shall comply will infection control guidance from the CMS and CDC, cohort COVID-19 positive residents away from negative residents, develop policies on admission and readmission, report through EMResource every week the number of positive residents/type and use of PPE/number of transfers to and from hospital, offer electronic communication if visitation is restricted.
Allows pools to stay open with the limitation of groups no larger than 10 congregating.
intended_duration: Until further notice with review every 2 weeks after July 27, 2020

policy_description: Directs schools that have begun to offer childcare programs to continue doing so.
intended_duration: Expires upon the start of in-person classes

policy_description: Organized public events of more than 50 people are prohibited.
intended_duration: Until further notice with review every 2 weeks after July 27, 2020

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Pauses the operations of bars, indoor gyms, fitness clubs or centers, indoor movie theaters, water parks, and tubing operations.
intended_duration: Until further notice with review every 2 weeks after July 27, 2020

policy_description: Ceases the issuing of series 15 and 16 special event and festival licenses.
intended_duration: Until further notice with review every 2 weeks after July 27, 2020

policy_description: Is in addition to requirements for businesses in Executive Orders 2020-40 and 2020-36.
intended_duration: Shall remain in place until further notice with considered revision every 2 weeks.

policy_description: Requires restaurants with indoor seating to operate at less than 50 percent capacity.
intended_duration: Shall remain in place until further notice with considered revision every 2 weeks.

policy_description: Supersedes provisions of Executive Order 2020-34 paragraph 2
intended_duration: Shall remain in place until further notice with considered revision every 2 weeks.

policy_description: Expands the Civic Duty Leave to include serving at a voting location.
Directs the Arizona Department of Administration to assist the counties in providing voting locations with proper equipment and PPE.
Directs the Arizona Department of Administration to make available state-owned facilities that can be used for voting locations in August and November 2020.
Each school and charter school shall inform parents of school operations.
intended_duration: Until the end of the 2020-2021 school year

policy_description: Directs the Arizona Department of Health to develop and provide public health benchmarks for the safe return of in-person classroom instruction by August 7, 2020 that each school district and charter school shall consider.
intended_duration: Until the end of the 2020-2021 school year

policy_description: Each school and charter school shall begin to offer free on-site learning opportunities and support services for students who need a place to go during the day as prescribed in Executive Order 2020-41 and shall begin on August 17, 2020 and prescribed in Executive Order 2020-44.
intended_duration: Until the end of the 2020-2021 school year

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space; Restaurants/bars
policy_description: Extends provision of Executive Order 2020-43, pausing the operations of bars, indoor gyms, fitness clubs or centers, indoor movie theaters, water parks, and tubing operations.
intended_duration: Reviewed or repealed every two weeks

policy_description: Extends provision of Executive Order 2020-43, allowing pools to stay open with the limitation of groups no larger than 10 congregating.
intended_duration: Reviewed or repealed every two weeks

policy_description: Extends mass gatherings limited to less than 50 persons provision of Executive Order 2020-43.
intended_duration: Reviewed or repealed every two weeks

policy_description: Extends provision of Executive Order 2020-43, ceasing the issuing of series 15 and 16 special event and festival licenses.
intended_duration: Reviewed or repealed every two weeks

policy_description: Lays out guidelines for schools reopening with in-person instruction.  Suggests counties meet the below criteria and consult the following link for more county specific info: https://www.azdhs.gov/preparedness/epidemiology-disease-control/infectious-disease-epidemiology/index.php#novel-coronavirus-schools  Cases: a two-week decline in weekly average cases OR two weeks below 100 cases per 100,000 population Diagnostic test percent positivity: two weeks with positivity below 7%  COVID-19-Like-Illness Syndromic Surveillance: two weeks with less than 10% of hospital visits due to COVID-like illness
Lays out guidelines by ADHS for the phased reopening of Water Parks & Tubing Operators.
Lays out guidelines by ADHS for the phased reopening of restaurants and bars providing dine-in services.
If a business does not timely request a hearing the continued closure of the business will not be subject to judicial review.
intended_duration: Shall remain in effect no longer than 18 months.

policy_description: A business whose application to reopen is denied may request an informal settlement conference with ADHS.
intended_duration: Shall remain in effect no longer than 18 months.

policy_description: Lays out guidelines by ADHS for the phased reopening of indoor gyms and fitness clubs/centers.
Lays out guidelines by ADHS for the phased reopening of indoor theaters.
Lays out guidelines by ADHS for the phased reopening of bars and nightclubs not operating as a restaurant.
If required to remain closed after an informal settlement hearing the business may request a hearing before the Office of Arizona Administrative Hearings within 30 days.
intended_duration: Shall remain in effect no longer than 18 months.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space; Restaurants/bars; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Indoor gyms, fitness centers, indoor theaters, water parks, tubing operators, and bars shall remain closed as required under Executive Order 2020-43 and 2020-52 unless they meet on an individual basis the terms and conditions required for reopening or apply to ADHS for approval.
intended_duration: Shall remain in effect no longer than 18 months.

policy_description: A business that must remain closed may apply to ADHS for approval to reopen if it can prove or has proven it has taken extras steps beyond the provided guidelines and benchmarks for counties whose community transmission metrics are in the moderate category.
intended_duration: Shall remain in effect no longer than 18 months.

policy_description: Businesses closed by executive order 2020-43 and 2020-52 must complete the attestation form and comply with business specific guidelines published by ADHS to fully reopen.
intended_duration: Shall remain in effect no longer than 18 months.

policy_description: Outlines the benchmarks a county must meet over a consecutive period of 14 days to move from one transmission category to another.
intended_duration: Shall remain in effect no longer than 18 months.

policy_description: If a closed business is located within a county that does not meet the community transmission metrics in the moderate or minimal category then the business must remain closed.
intended_duration: Shall remain in effect no longer than 18 months.

policy_description: Amends paragraph 1 of executive order 2020-43 and any extension under executive order 2020-52 to state: Organized public events of more than 50 people are prohibited unless the city, town, county, or  unincorporated area has determined that adequate safety precautions exist consistent with ADHS and CDC guidance and approves said event.
intended_duration: Until further notice with consideration for repeal or revision every 2 weeks

policy_description: Approved events jurisdictions' are required to post mitigation measures that the event organizer is required to implement and enforce on the jurisdiction's website and submit it to ADHS.
intended_duration: Until further notice with consideration for repeal or revision every 2 weeks

policy_description: The Arizona Department of Liquor and License Control shall accept and review requests by liquor licenses who are seeking to temporarily extend their premises outdoors for the purpose of mitigating the spread of COVID-19.
intended_duration: Until further notice with consideration for repeal or revision every 2 weeks

policy_description: The Arizona Department of Liquor and License Control may only approve a temporary extension of premises after a city, town, or county has approved the temporary extension of premises.
intended_duration: Until further notice with consideration for repeal or revision every 2 weeks

policy_description: Allows the issuing of a series 15 or series 16 special events license by the Arizona Department of Liquor Licenses and Control for events of 5o or more people that is approved.
intended_duration: Until further notice with consideration for repeal or revision every 2 weeks

policy_description: The remainder of executive order 2020-43 as extended and supplemented remains in effect.  Extends provision of Executive Order 2020-43, allowing pools to stay open with the limitation of groups no larger than 10 congregating.
intended_duration: Until further notice with consideration for repeal or revision every 2 weeks

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Restaurants/bars
policy_description: The remainder of executive order 2020-43 as extended and supplemented remains in effect.  Extends provision of Executive Order 2020-43, pausing the operations of bars, indoor gyms, fitness clubs or centers, indoor movie theaters, water parks, and tubing operations.
intended_duration: Until further notice with consideration for repeal or revision every 2 weeks

policy_description: Effective immediately, the Arkansas Department of Health directs all long-term care facilities to prohibit all visitation until further notice unless medically necessary or by law enforcement or other emergency personnel, a representative from the Arkansas Department of Health, a representative from the Arkansas Department of Human Services Office of Long-term Care, or a representative from the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services.
All hospitals shall conduct mandatory temperature and COVID-19 symptom screening of staff and visitors.
K-12 schools and extracurricular activities, including athletic events and practices, will remain closed for on-site instruction an additional 3 weeks.

State government employees will conduct business through both remote work and on-site work. On-site government work will be limited to employees that are critical to the necessary function of government during a public health emergency and are required to report to work on site.

Regulations preventing shareholds from holding annual meetings of shareholders solely or partially by remote communication. They may instead be held by remote or a combination of remote and in-person methods. The board of directors must adopt guidelines for governing such a meeting and to provide verified shareholders no physically present with a reasonable means to participate, be deemed present in-person, and be allowed to vote.
intended_duration: For the duration of the emergency order

policy_description: Commercial lodgings and short-term rentals, including, but not limited to, hotels, motels, and vacation rentals, are no longer limited as to the type of guests they can house that were delineated in the directive of April 4, 2020.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: All types of recreational pools can open to their patrons at 50% capacity if they meet the following requirements: screening employees, maintain physical distancing, and regular disinfecting.

policy_subtarget: Minors and children; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare)
policy_description: Allows summer day camps to reopen if they follow the Secretary of Health's guidelines. Social distancing must be maintained and only parents and guardians may enter the facility. Frequently touched areas must be routinely disinfected.

policy_subtarget: Minors and children; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare)
policy_description: Overnight camps: All staff and campers shall receive a pre-screening questionnaire that is reviewed upon entry to camp. This could include an agreement signed by the parent or staff member affirming they have followed the 14-day self-quarantine. Advise campers and families in advance about COVID-19 symptoms and exclusions, and place signage at all entrances.

policy_subtarget: Minors and children; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare)
policy_description: Summer residential camps may begin to operate as long as they follow the Secretary of Health's measures to protect the health of attendees and staff. Camps may require all staff and campers to self-quarantine for 14 days and a PCR COVID-19 test performed within 4 days (96 hours) prior to being admitted to camp.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Primary education; Secondary education; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: This directive provides requirements for lifting limitations to community-based and school-sponsored team sports through a phased approach for both adult and youth athletes. This includes physical distancing, health screenings, prohibits use of spas and saunas, and regular sanitizing of equipment.

All businesses, manufacturers, and construction companies must implement the Secretary of Health's guidelines for reopening. Physical distancing must be possible, employees should be screened for symptoms, and surfaces must be regularly disinfected.

Gyms: Screening must be completed on entry for all staff and participants. Those who have had a fever of 100.4°F or greater in the past two days or possible COVID symptoms or contact should not enter.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: According to Phase II of the reopening plan, outdoor venues such as concerts, plays, and sporting events that are designed for large groups may reopen at 66% capacity.

Dine in services of food establishments and restaurants may resume at 66% capacity following the Phase II reopening guidelines. All guidelines outlined by the Department of Health must be followed, such as physical distancing, signage, and handwashing.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Indoor spaces; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Indoor venues such as theaters, arenas, stadiums, and auction houses that are designed for large groups may reopen at 66% capacity.
Allows bars and clubs to reopen at 66% capacity and following public health guidelines according to Phase II of the reopening plan.

Gyms: The use of pools, spas, showers, saunas, etc. may resume at this time. Indoor and outdoor swimming pools at a gym, fitness center, or athletic club may now operate in accordance with the Directive for Recreational Pool Reopening.
Per Phase II, casinos may reopen at 66% capacity if they have a detailed plan for how they will conduct their operations to minimize the risk of transmission of COVID-19.
There is now no quarantine requirement for international travelers entering Arkansas based on the location they traveled from.
There is now no quarantine requirement for domestic travelers entering Arkansas based on the location they traveled from.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Personal care facilities
policy_description: Barbers, body art establishments, body art schools, cosmetology establishments, medical spas, and massage therapy clinics, may resume operations at 66% capacity pursuant to guidelines by the Secretary of Health.

Amends reopening guidelines for gyms. Everything remains the same except that spacing between individuals may be reduced to 6 feet if an impermeable barrier is placed between each individual or piece of equipment in use.

July 7 Special Elections: Counties may consolidate polls to no less than one site up to three days before the election, so long as notice of the change is posted at all sites that would have been used. Electors may request appropriate absentee ballots to be mailed to their residence. County officials may act on an absentee ballot application received within seven days before the election date and mail a ballot.

Governor Asa Hutchinson issued an executive order today that allows Arkansans to vote absentee if they are concerned that voting in person may be a risk to their health or the health of others because of COVID-19. Executive Order 20-44 also allows elections officials to start processing the absentee ballots a week earlier than usual to allow for an anticipated increase in the number of absentee voters. He issued the executive order in response to an official request from the Arkansas Association of County Clerks.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Primary education; Secondary education; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Amends directive about community and school sports resuming. Allows close contact team sports to resume practice, such as basketball, volleyball, soccer, and wrestling. Limited contact sports may resume competitions and meets.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Private and public school athletic events will not be required to submit COVID compliance plans to the Arkansas Department of Health provided they follow the ADH guidelines.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Minors and children; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: This directive provides requirements for lifting limitations to community and school-based music practicing and performing. These guidelines include physical distancing of six feet, screenings, and face coverings. It is preferred that performances are held outside.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Primary education; Secondary education; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Amends directive about community and school sports resuming. Allows close contact team sports to resume practice and competitions between two different teams. Tournaments are still not allowed.

Dine in services of food establishments and restaurants may resume at 66% capacity following the Phase II reopening guidelines. This amendment allows self-service operations, including, but not limited to, salad bars, buffets, and condiment bars to resume, provided that they follow the Secretary of Health's guidelines.
intended_duration: until the Secretary of Health determines epidemiological data are sufficient to proceed to Phase 3.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Minors and children; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Requirements for school music and theater remains in place except now if, while outdoors, it is not possible to use a disposable absorbent product, spit valves may only be emptied if 12 feet away from others and emptied in an area where others will not be walking.

Allows long-term care facilities to expand visitation and other activities beyond the minimum visitation described only if the facility has not had a newly positive COVID-19 case in the fourteen (14) calendar days before expanded visitation or other activities are offered.
Arkansas Health Department has issued a directive that Arkansas businesses that are licensed to sell and allow consumption of alcohol on their premises must close by 11 p.m.

policy_subtarget: Higher education; Primary education; Secondary education
policy_description: Schools will continue to receive funding if they close due to COVID-19, and are allowed to offer distance learning. Certain requirements regarding maintenance will also be waived. The Department of Education will provide guidance on implementing distance learning, accommodating the needs of students with disabilities, and providing meals.

California Code of Regulations, Title 15, section 3041(b)(2), shall be waived for any inmate who loses a current compensated assignment as a result of a modified program or transfer until such time as the inmate receives a new compensated assignment.

The timeline to provide notification of a scheduled discharge consideration hearing is reduced from 60 to 30 days prior to the hearing.  For hearings conducted digitally for juveniles, the right of a guardian or victim to be present is fulfilled by their digital appearance. After determining a youth should be discharged, they must be released within 14 days. Re-entry disposition hearings will be conducted by teleconference at a DJJ, whenever practical.
Employees must be allowed to wash their hands every 30 minutes.
intended_duration: For the length of stay-at-home orders

policy_description: To the extent that such sectors are re-opened, Californians may leave their homes to work at, patronize, or otherwise engage with those businesses, establishments, or activities.
Californians must continue at all times to practice physical distancing, minimize their time outside of the home, and wash their hands frequently.

The order requires that each county’s elections officials send vote-by-mail ballots for the November 3, 2020 General Election to all registered voters. Californians who may need access to in-person voting opportunities – including individuals with disabilities, individuals who speak languages other than English, individuals experiencing homelessness, and others – will still be able to access in-person voting opportunities.

March 19, 2020, the Governor Issued Executive Order N-25-20, requiring all residents to heed the guidance of state health officials, which in turn provided that “restaurants should be closed for in-restaurant seated dining, and should be open only to drive-through or other pick-up/delivery options."  The county interprets that outdoor seating shall not be considered “in-restaurant dining;”  Sets up regulations for outdoor seating for restaurant dining:  Social distancing must be maintained and tables must be separated by at least 8ft in all directions.  Orders shall be placed from outside the establishment/by phone or other means, hand sanitizer should be available when exchanging money.  Customers shall not wait inside the establishment to pick-up orders, or use restrooms or other facilities.  Food and drink ordered is only ordered "to-go" and may only be eaten at out-door tables situated as specified above.  Additional food and drink is ordered and picked up in the same manner.  No table service is allowed.  All plates, cups and utensils provided by the restaurant must be disposable.  All customers must bus their own table (i.e. throw away their own dishes and trash).  All staff must wear appropriate PPE while cleaning the outdoor area.  Restaurants must have adequate trash containers accessible.  Maximum of 6 adults per table - families with small children may increase this number to space limit.  The outside seating area must be open on at least two sides to allow maximum ventilation.  Restaurant staff must clean and disinfect tables after each use; garbage receptacles and other frequently touched surfaces must be cleaned at least twice daily, all surfaces must be cleaned using EPA-approved disinfectant products, following the manufacturer’s directions. https://www.epa.gov/pesticide-registration/list-n-disinfectants-use-against-sars-cov-2 (Link page attached further in the code)

Notwithstanding any contrary provision of state law (including, but not limited to, Elections Code sections 3019.5 and 3019.7), all county elections officials are required to use the Secretary of State’s vote-by-mail ballot tracking system, created pursuant to Elections Code section 3019.7, and to use Intelligent Mail Barcodes on all vote-by-mail ballot envelopes.   Notwithstanding any contrary provision of state law (including, but not limited to, any such provision of Elections Code sections 12200–12286 or 12288, and specifically including the requirement in Elections Code section 12286(a)(3) that at least one polling place be designated per precinct), a county that is not subject to the California Voter’s Choice Act shall not, in connection with the November 3, 2020 General Election, be required to make available more than one polling place per 10,000 registered voters, as long as the county complies with certain conditions.  Notwithstanding any contrary provision of state law (including, but not limited to, any such provision of Elections Code section 4005 or section 4007, as applicable), a county that is subject to the California Voter’s Choice Act shall not, in connection with the November 3, 2020 General Election, be required to open any vote center (as that term is used in Elections Code sections 357.5, 4005, and 4007) prior to Saturday, October 31, 2020. Counties are nevertheless encouraged to open vote centers earlier, where feasible and as conditions warrant, to maximize opportunities for voter participation in the November 3, 2020 General Election.   Notwithstanding any contrary provision of state law (including, but not limited to, any such provision of Elections Code section 4005(a)(10)), no county elections official shall be required to conduct any in-person public meetings or workshops in connection with the preparation of plans for the administration of the November 3, 2020 General Election, as long as a draft of each such plan is posted on the relevant county election official’s website in a manner consistent with Elections Code section 4005(a)(10)(E)(iii) and the relevant county elections official accepts public comment on the draft plan for at least 10 days. Counties are encouraged to take additional steps, where feasible, to facilitate and encourage public participation in the development of such plans.   Nothing in this Order is intended, or shall be construed, to limit a county’s ability to fulfill the requirements imposed on that county by existing law (including, but not limited to, any provision of law conditionally suspended by Paragraph 3 as to counties not subject to the California Voter’s Choice Act) concerning procedures for the November 3, 2020 General Election. In particular, any county described in Paragraph 3 that complies with all such requirements applicable to that county (and that therefore need not avail itself of the conditional suspension set forth in Paragraph 3) may do so without additionally satisfying any separate requirements that would otherwise be imposed by Paragraph 3. Additionally, where feasible, counties are encouraged to exceed the minimum requirements imposed by this Order, or otherwise imposed by law in connection with the administration of the November 3, 2020 General Election, to maximize opportunities for voter participation in that election.   The Legislature and the Secretary of State are requested to continue working in partnership with my Administration to ensure that the November 3, 2020 General Election is safe, secure, and accessible for all, including by ensuring (and by working with county elections officials to ensure) that there is sufficient voter education and outreach to prepare voters to participate in that election. Nothing in this Order is intended, or shall be construed, to limit in any way the enactment of legislation concerning the November 3, 2020 General Election.
Expanding access to voting by mail.

All bars, pubs, brewpubs, and breweries in San Bernardino County must close. Dine-in restaurants, wineries, and tasting rooms may continue to operate, but indoor seating is prohibited.  Zoos, museums, and move theaters must close to visitors, but are allowed to operate outdoor attractions and services.
Wineries and tasting rooms must close indoor services to customers. During this closure all wineries and tasting rooms must comply with the guidance for restaurants, wineries, and bars.

Order given to California by Governor Gavin Newsom. The Governor's order sets back some recently opened businesses such as movie theaters, and in restaurant dining. Additionally, this order will not allow bars to reopen at the end of this month like previously planned.
This policy loosens restrictions on recruiting and training poll workers.

The order also enables certain adoption paperwork to be completed remotely, and for birth parents known or suspected to be COVID-19 positive, waives the requirement that relinquishment for adoption and other acts related to the process occur in-person.

Governor Gavin Newsom today signed an executive order to assist elections officials as they prepare for the upcoming election amid the COVID-19 pandemic and wildfires across the state.  The order extends the deadline for county elections officials to count and verify signatures submitted for initiative petitions seeking to qualify for the November 2022 ballot, giving the elections officials needed flexibility to focus on preparations for the General Election this November.
intended_duration: Through the November election prep process

policy_description: Outlines that indoor dining in Del Norte may now reopen at 50% capacity, bars can open to outside services, and museums can move indoors again.

Introduces to Del Norte the state's new tiered, color-coded plan that replaced the county monitoring list. This blueprint for a safer economy allows counties to have more flexibility in their reopening process.   Governor asks that we as a county continue to follow safe social distancing, wear masks, and limit all non-essential activities and travel.

The State of Colorado issues a "Safer at Home" strategy, including direction of the Colorado Department of Higher Education to work to identify those programs and courses at post-secondary institutions that cannot be taught remotely and require limited in-person instruction.
The State of Colorado issues a "Safer at Home" strategy.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: The State of Colorado issues a "Safer at Home" strategy, including permission of non-critical business to allow for the distribution of goods for off-premise use/consumption and to allow patrons to enter the premise if they abide by distancing guidelines

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: The State of Colorado issues a "Safer at Home" strategy, including a recommendation for all vulnerable Individuals should Stay at Home or in the vast, great outdoors and maintain social distancing when possible.
The State of Colorado issues a "Safer at Home" strategy, including a prohibition on gatherings of 10 or more persons in public or private commercial spaces.

policy_subtarget: Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: The State of Colorado issues a "Safer at Home" strategy, including requiring of businesses with 50 or more employees to abide by specialized sanitation and hygiene guidelines.

policy_subtarget: Criminal justice system/prisons/jails/incarcerated persons; Minors and children
policy_description: Executive Order D 2020 034, concerning the suspension of the use of seclusion in secured facilities managed by the Department of Youth Services, is amended and extended.
Executive Order D 2020 034, concerning suspension of juvenile transfer to state prisons, is amended and extended.
Executive Order D 2020 034, concerning suspension of the right to frequent visitors of those in behavioral health facilities, is amended and extended.
Executive Order D 2020 005, concerning limiting physical contact during the 2020 elections, is extended.
Executive Order D 2020 064, concerning the suspension of certain regulatory measures regarding signature collection for unaffiliated or independent candidates, is amended and extended.
Executive Order D 2020 065, concerning of ballot access, is amended and extended.
Executive Order D 2020 016, concerning the relaxation of certain regulatory statues of criminal justice with the intention of lowering incarcerated populations, is extended and amended.
Executive Orders D 2020 053 and D 2020 085, concerning the suspension of regulatory statutes that require petitioning for candidacy, are extended.
Local public health agencies are directed to work with child care providers and preschools to determine whether it is safe to continue operations.

Executive Order D 2020 091, Colorado's "Safer at Home" Strategy, is amended to include that bars are permitted to sell alcoholic beverages to-go for takeout or delivery consumption if the alcoholic beverages are sold with food and provided in containers approved by rule by the State Licensing Authority.
Executive Order D 2020 091, Colorado's "Safer at Home" Strategy, is amended to include mandatory isolation if an individual has tested positive for COVID-19 in the state of Colorado.
Executive Order D 2020 034, concerning the suspension of the use of seclusion in secured facilities managed by the Department of Youth Services, is amended and extended.
Executive Order D 2020 034, concerning suspension of juvenile transfer to state prisons, is amended and extended.
Executive Order D 2020 034, concerning suspension of the right to frequent visitors of those in behavioral health facilities, is amended and extended.

In relation to Executive Orders D 2020 065 and D 2020 103, concerning the suspension of certain regulatory measures are suspended to expand accessibility to mail-in ballots, the Colorado Supreme Court has ruled that the Colorado Constitution requires that ballot initiative petitions be signed in the presence of the petition circulator and that this requirement cannot be suspended by Executive Order. All of Executive Orders D 2020 065 and D 2020 103, exempting Section II.B., are stricken.

Exempt from the stricken of Executive Orders D 2020 065 and D 2020 103 is Section IIB., regarding the suspension of C.R.S. § 1-40-108(1) that a ballot issue petition must be filed with the Secretary of State within 6 months from the date that the titles and submissions clause have been fixed and determined provided that all ballot issue petitions must be filed with the Secretary of State at least three months before the general election at which they are to be voted on. This section is extended by 30 days.

Executive Orders D 2020 005, D 2020 008, D 2020 036, D 2020 061, and D 2020 095, concerning limitations of physical contact during elections are amended and extended.  The amendment to these ordinances is the striking of Sections II.A, II.B, II.C, II.D, and II.E.

Executive Orders D 2020 064 and D 2020 102, concerning the suspension of certain regulatory measures regarding signature collection for unaffiliated or independent candidates, are amended and extended.
Executive Order D 2020 016, concerning the relaxation of certain regulatory statues of criminal justice with the intention of lowering incarcerated populations, is extended and amended.
Executive Order D 2020 091 is amended to prohibit the sale of alcohol after 10 PM. Executive Order D 2020 091 is extended as modified.
Executive Order D 2020 091 is amended to prohibit the sale of alcohol before 7:00 AM and 10:00 PM, this does not apply to deliveries. Executive Order D 2020 091 is extended as modified.
Executive Orders D 2020 053, D 2020 085, and D 2020 119, concerning the suspension of regulatory statutes that require petitioning for candidacy, are extended.
Executive Order D 2020 034, concerning suspension of juvenile transfer to state prisons, is amended and extended.
Executive Order D 2020 034, concerning suspension of the right to frequent visitors of those in behavioral health facilities, is amended and extended.
