Executive Order D 2020 034, concerning the suspension of the use of seclusion in secured facilities managed by the Department of Youth Services, is amended and extended.

Executive Orders D 2020 005, D 2020 008, D 2020 036, D 2020 061, and D 2020 095, concerning limitations of physical contact during elections are amended and extended.  The amendment to these ordinances is the striking of Sections II.A, II.B, II.C, II.D, and II.E.

Executive Orders D 2020 064, D 2020 102, and D 2020 135, concerning the suspension of certain regulatory measures regarding signature collection for unaffiliated or independent candidates, are amended and extended.
Executive Order D 2020 016, concerning the relaxation of certain regulatory statues of criminal justice with the intention of lowering incarcerated populations, is extended and amended.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: The State of Colorado revises its definition of vulnerable persons in relation to its "Safer at Home" strategy.
Executive Order D 2020 034, concerning suspension of juvenile transfer to state prisons, is amended and extended.
Executive Orders D 2020 005, D 2020 008, D 2020 036, D 2020 061, D 2020 095, D 2020 129, and D 2020 155, concerning limitations of physical contact during elections are amended and extended.

This Executive Order temporarily suspends statute to facilitate learning pods due to the presence of COVID-19 in Colorado, and to balance health and safety with needed flexibility for supervision and care of children who are learning remotely during this pandemic
Executive Order D 2020 016, concerning the relaxation of certain regulatory statues of criminal justice with the intention of lowering incarcerated populations, is extended and amended.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: The State of Colorado revises its definition of vulnerable persons in relation to its "Safer at Home" strategy.
Executive Order D 2020 034, concerning suspension of juvenile transfer to state prisons, is amended and extended.

Extending Executive Orders D 2020 005, D 2020 008, D 2020 036, D 2020 061, D 2020 095, D 2020 129, D 2020 155, and D 2020 179, concerning limitations of physical contact during elections are amended and extended. This extension will allow 2020 election activity to continue safely and without interruption while minimizing the risk of spreading COVID-19.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: The State of Colorado removes the suspension of alcohol sales after 11 PM as part of its "Safer at Home" strategy.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: The State of Colorado revises its definition of vulnerable persons in relation to its "Safer at Home" strategy.

Executive Order D 2020 188, concerning the temporary suspension of statute to facilitate learning pods due to the presence of COVID-19 in Colorado, and to balance health and safety with needed flexibility for supervision and care of children who are learning remotely during this pandemic, is extended.
Executive Order D 2020 016, concerning the relaxation of certain regulatory statues of criminal justice with the intention of lowering incarcerated populations, is extended and amended.

Executive Orders D 2020 005, D 2020 008, D 2020 036, D 2020 061, D 2020 095, D 2020 129, D 2020 155, and D 2020 179, concerning limitations of physical contact during elections, are amended and extended. This extension will allow 2020 election activity to continue safely and without interruption while minimizing the risk of spreading COVID-19.

The Executive Director of the Colorado Department of Higher Education is ordered to continue to work with CDPHE to identify programs and courses at postsecondary institutions that cannot be taught remotely and require limited in person instruction, and to supplement these programs with protocols to control the spread of COVID-19.
The Colorado Department of Public Health and the Environment is granted power to set a curfew on all alcohol sales.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Public sector/government employees
policy_description: All Coloradans who reside in counties under Level Red of the Colorado Department of Public Health and the Environment's (CDPHE) “Dial” framework are ordered to stay at home.
Executive Order D 2020 034, concerning suspension of juvenile transfer to state prisons, is amended and extended.

Executive Order D 2020 188, concerning the temporary suspension of statute to facilitate learning pods due to the presence of COVID-19 in Colorado, and to balance health and safety with needed flexibility for supervision and care of children who are learning remotely during this pandemic, is extended.
Executive Order D 2020 016, concerning the relaxation of certain regulatory statues of criminal justice with the intention of lowering incarcerated populations, is extended and amended.

Executive Orders D 2020 005, D 2020 008, D 2020 036, D 2020 061, D 2020 095, D 2020 129, D 2020 155, D 2020 179, D 2020 209, and D 2020 231, concerning limitations of physical contact during elections, are amended and extended. This extension will allow 2020 election activity to continue safely and without interruption while minimizing the risk of spreading COVID-19.
Executive Order D 2020 034, concerning suspension of juvenile transfer to state prisons, is amended and extended.

Executive Order D 2020 188, concerning the temporary suspension of statute to facilitate learning pods due to the presence of COVID-19 in Colorado, and to balance health and safety with needed flexibility for supervision and care of children who are learning remotely during this pandemic, is extended.

Executive Order D 2020 016, concerning the relaxation of certain regulatory statues of criminal justice with the intention of lowering incarcerated populations, is extended and amended. This is implemented to ensure the DOC to continue to manage its inmate intake process to prevent the introduction of inmates who may be symptomatic or asymptomatic with COVID-19 to DOC, in compliance with CDPHE and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention guidance.
The Commissionner of Public Health is permitted to limit the visitors of nursing homes.
Gatherings of 250 people or more are prohibited.
The 180 school-day-requirement is waived for the 2019-2020 public school year.
Connecticut Grants Department of Public Health's Commissioner is granted authority to restrict visitors at nursing homes and similar facilities
In-person open meeting requirements are to be suspended.
DMV operations will be conducted remotely.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Retail stores (not including food)
policy_description: Firearm transactions are to be by appointment only.
School testing assessments for 2019-20 school year are suspended.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Entrance into state parks and other properties will be limited.
Municiple in-person voting requirements for critical and time sensitive fiscal deadlines are suspended.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Retail stores (not including food)
policy_description: Each retail establishment that opens 4/03/2020 in the State of Connecticut shall take additional protective measures to reduce transmission of COVID-19.

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist)
policy_description: Hearings for the authorizing of temporary rate increases by health care providers are suspended.

policy_subtarget: Essential workers (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Every workplace in the State of Connecticut shall take additional protective measures to reduce the risk of transmission of COVID-19.
Extended distancing measures through 05/20/2020.

policy_subtarget: Confirmed cases; Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services
policy_description: Designation of COVID-19 recovery facilities.
Governor Ned Lamont further postpones the presidential preference primary to 08/11/2020.
For the protection of public health and safety during COVID-19 pandemic procedures for local appointments and elections that formerly required in person vote have been suspended or modified.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Operations of museums and zoos may recommence pursuant to the Sector Rules for Museums and Zoos
Outdoor dining shall be permitted at any food and beverage establishment, with conditions.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Some offices may begin processes for reopening, but largely must continue to abide by Executive Order No. 7H, concerning the requirement of businesses to conduct operations remotely.
Outdoor dining must implement certain hygiene and sanitation requirements.

policy_subtarget: Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare); Outdoor recreation or space; Secondary education; Primary education
policy_description: To limit the spread of COVID-19 and promote and secure the health and safety of children and staff in summer school (summer educational programs), all summer school programs operated by local or regional boards of education shall not begin operations until 07/06/2020.
Specialized procedures for absentee and distanced voting are enumerated.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Hair salons and barbers may open 06/01/2020.
Executive Order No. 7Q is amended to provide that child care facilities may provide care for up to 50 children without any additional approval measures.
Regulatory statutes concerning the petitioning process for ballot access for petitioning candidates are revised.

policy_subtarget: Higher education; Primary education; Secondary education
policy_description: “Drive-in” graduation ceremonies are permitted given that certain distancing guidelines are met.
Executive Order No. 7TT is amended to provide that “drive-in” religious, spiritual and worship gatherings may be permitted if they follow distancing guidelines.

policy_subtarget: Government/public buildings; Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Executive Order No. 7G is amended to presume court and appellate proceedings.
Executive Order No. 7G is repealed. All businesses or services subject to that order shall be permitted to operate pursuant to distancing guidelines.
Executive Order No. 7T, concerning a prohibition on temporary lodging, is lifted.
Executive Order No. 7D is amended to permit indoor dining pursuant to distancing guidelines.
Executive Order Nos. 7D and 7N, are amended to permit social and recreational gatherings pursuant to distancing guidelines.

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Executive Order No. 7D is partially repealed so that businesses subject to that order shall be permitted to operate pursuant to distancing guidelines.
Executive Order No. 7D, prohibiting operations at Off-Track Betting Facilities, is extended through 07/20/2020.

Executive Order No. 7Q, concerning population size in Child Care centers, is modified to enable the Commissioner of Early Childhood to modify or remove the limitation on the number of children permitted in one space within a child care facility.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Retail stores (not including food)
policy_description: Executive Order No. 7ZZ is modified in respect to Places of Public Amusement. Following such revisions Executive Order No. 7F, Section 2 is repealed. Places of Public Amusement, as defined by that order, shall be permitted to operate pursuant to the Department of Economic Community Development Sector Rules applicable to each business.
Candidates withdrawing from the Presidential Primary may do so on a revised timeline.

All travelers entering Connecticut from a state with a positive test rate higher than 10 per 100,000 residents, or higher than a 10% test positivity rate over a seven-day rolling average, shall self-quarantine for a period of 14 days.

Connecticut (simultaneously and in coordination with New York and New Jersey) required all travelers to quarantine for 14 days upon arrival if they are coming from a U.S. state with a large number of cases (test positivity rate >10% or >10 positive tests per 100,000 residents, both on a 7-day rolling average).
Executive Order No. 7BBB, Section 1, concerning an advisory of self-quarantine, is repealed.

Any person who spends 24 hours within 14 days of entering the State of Connecticut in an “Affected State” with a positive test rate higher than 10 per 100,000 residents, or higher than a 10% test positivity rate over a seven-day rolling average, is subject to a 14-day mandatory quarantine.

All Affected Travelers, prior to or upon arrival in Connecticut, shall complete a Travel Health Form requiring such persons to disclose (1) their name; (2) the last Affected State in which such Affected Traveler has spent twenty-four hours or longer; (3) last date of stay in such Affected State, date of arrival in Connecticut; (4) address of designated self-quarantine location in Connecticut; (5) length of stay; (6) address in home state; (7) cell phone number; (8) contact phone number while in Connecticut; (9) method of travel into Connecticut; and (10) information regarding accompanying minors.  minors
An elector’s attestation on the inner envelope shall be interpreted to include the sickness of COVID-19 as an illness.

For the August 11, 2020 primary, election officials are authorized to accept and count absentee ballot sets issued pursuant to Executive Order No. 7QQ if either the outer or the inner envelope contains the following information: the elector’s name, an address, voting district, the date of the primary at which the ballot is to be cast, the name of the party holding the primary, and the serial number associated with the elector’s absentee ballot application. Absentee ballot sets postmarked on or before August 11, 2020 and delivered via U.S. mail to election officials on or before August 13, 2020 shall be counted and included in the totals provided by the head moderator for each municipality.

policy_subtarget: Restaurants/bars; Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Executive Order No. 7MM and any approvals issued under it shall be extended through 11/12/2020.
Sale of alcohol without food will continue to be prohibited.

Pursuant to the emergency declarations issued on September 1, 2020, all executive orders issued pursuant to the public health and civil preparedness emergencies declared on March 10, 2020 and renewed on September 1, 2020 (COVID-19 Orders) that are unexpired and currently in effect as of the date of this order are hereby reissued.

All Affected Travelers shall self-quarantine for a period of fourteen days from the time of last contact with such Affected State or such Affected Country, for any portion of such fourteen-day period they spend in Connecticut. An Affected Traveler is exempt from the self-quarantine requirement if he or she has had (1) a test with a negative result for COVID-19 in the seventy-two hours prior to arrival in Connecticut, and (2) such Affected Traveler submits written proof of such negative test result to the Commissioner or her designee; or if he or she is an essential worker.
Prohibition of the sale of alcohol without the sale of food is extended.

policy_subtarget: Higher education; Primary education; Secondary education
policy_description: “Drive-in” graduation ceremonies are permitted given that certain distancing guidelines are met.

policy_subtarget: Churches/places of worship; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Religious, spiritual, or worship gatherings, if held indoors, are limited to no more than 50 percent of the building’s capacity or a maximum of 200 people, whichever is lower.  Outdoor gathers may occur at any size so long as social distancing is enforced.

Municipal authorities are ordered to revert to the more restrictive pre-10/08/2020, size and capacity limitations and rules for certain businesses and gatherings if they report more than 15 cases per day.

Municipal authorities are ordered to revert to the more restrictive pre-10/08/2020, size and capacity limitations and rules for certain businesses and gatherings if they report more than 10 cases per day.
Executive Order No. 7D, concerning the prohibition of the sale of alcohol by certain permittees without the sale of food, shall remain is extended
All indoor gatherings, including religious, spiritual, or worship gatherings, are limited to no more than 50 % of the building’s capacity or a maximum of 100 people, whichever is smaller.
The Commissioner of Economic and Community Development is authorized to establish  mandatory rules for the safe conduct of sports, in consultation with the Commissioner of Public Health.

Large gatherings, if held, must allow 6 feet between individuals, adequate air flow, warm water and soap as well as hand sanitizer, signage that emphasize that ill individuals shall not attend and a process to manage an ill individual safely.
All state of Delaware employees able to telecommute shall telecommute.

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Nursing homes/assisted living facility
policy_description: All medical certification of death are to be completed electronically.
The presidential primary election scheduled for 06/02/2020 is rescheduled for 07/07/2020 in the State of Delaware. Local elections are also rescheduled.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Retail stores (not including food); Outdoor recreation or space; Personal care facilities; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Enumerated non-essential businesses are permitted to begin activities with curbside pickup.  Other businesses may begin activities by appointment-only.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: The Tenth Modification to the State of Emergency Declaration is modified to allow multiple persons from the same household to drive a gold cart at golfing facilities.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Effective 05/15/2020, ice cream and custard shops may recommence services to provide goods for off-premise consumption.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Effective 05/22/2020, those who have been in the State of Delaware for at least 14 days are permitted to attend the beach under the condition that they follow distancing guidelines. Beach goers over the age of 13 years are required to wear a face covering. Specific regulations regarding the precautions to be taken by cities, beach vendors and other businesses are listed.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Effective 05/22/2020, pools in the State of Delaware may recommence activities under the conditions of operating at 20% capacity. Swim lessons and swim teams may not recommence on-premise activities.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); General population (inclusive)
policy_description: Effective 05/22/2020, consumer rental services, exempting beach goods, are permitted to recommence activities under the condition that distancing guidelines are followed.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Fifteenth Modification of the State of Emergency is modified to add that the florists, previously identified as a non-essential business, are permitted to recommence business activities on premise.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Phase 1 Business Guidance allows for up to 30%  of stated fire occupancy residents. Arts and Culture, Museums, Galleries, and Historical Attractions may open at this capacity. Food and Drink Establishments may open at this capacity under certain conditions. Retail Establishments may open at this capacity. Malls may open at this capacity. Retail Establishments such as salons may open at this capacity under certain additional conditions. Realty may presume practice if no more than 10 persons are in a room at once. Casinos may open at 30% of stated fire occupancy residents. Parks and Recreation Facilities shall remain open under modified conditions.
The Seventh Modification to the COVID-19 State of Emergency declaration, concerning the out-of-state  traveler 14 day quarantine is stricken.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Paragraph 2 of the Ninth Modification to the COVID-19 State of Emergency declaration related to the operation of businesses, is stricken.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: Campgrounds may reopen.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Gatherings or events in fully unenclosed outdoor spaces, or tents, only as described below, of up to 250 persons. These events must follow enumerated guidelines and must notify the state of Delaware beforehand.
The Fifth Modification to the COVID-19 State of Emergency declaration, requiring Delawareans to shelter in place, is stricken.
The Eighteenth Modification to the COVID-19 State of Emergency declaration regarding houses of worship is hereby stricken in its entirety.

All public meetings of public bodies governed by 29 Del. C. §§10001 et seq. may be conducted in person in public buildings, provided that, (1) the total number of individuals permitted in a room at one time shall not exceed 30% of stated fire occupancy requirements; (2) a 6 foot distance between individuals is maintained; (3) attendees wear cloth face coverings . Public bodies are encouraged to conduct meetings electronically, either by means of telecommunication. Any in-person meeting must also provide a telephone or video conference option for any member of the public body or the public who does not wish to attend in person.
Until 04/15/2020, all persons are prohibited from gathering indoors or in partially enclosed spaces in groups of 10 or more.
In the case of a speaker to an audience, if face coverings cannot be used the speaker must maintain a 13 foot distance from the audience.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Churches/places of worship; Retail stores (not including food); Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare)
policy_description: The following business categories may continue operations or reopen subject to the responsibilities listed in the Phase 2 Reopen Plan: Arts and Culture, Museums, Galleries, and Historical Attractions; Food and Drink Establishments, Retail Establishments; Malls; Exercise Facilities; Realty; Casinos; Racetracks; Parks and Recreation Facilities; Child Care; Summer Camps; Youth Sports and Adult Recreational Sports; Commercial Lodging; Private Instruction; Campgrounds; Auction Houses; Houses of Worship; Swimming Facilities; Golf Courses; Convention Centers & Meeting Facilities; Ice Cream and Custard Shops; Commercial offices and residential buildings with at least 50 units.

Gatherings or events of up to 250 people (e.g. weddings and receptions, graduations, funerals, etc.) are permitted in under the enumerated conditions. Larger gatherings are hereby prohibited at all locations and venues, except that hosts of large gatherings and events may apply to host a large gathering or event by submitting a plan to covid19faq@delaware.gov at least 7 days prior to the anticipated event.

“Minimum Social Distancing Requirements” means maintaining at least 6 foot social distancing from any individual who is not a member of the same household or a caregiver to someone in that household, washing hands with soap and water for at least twenty (20) seconds as frequently as possible or using hand sanitizer composed of at least sixty percent (60%) ethanol or 70% isopropanol, covering coughs or sneezes with something other than one’s hands (e.g., elbow, handkerchief), regularly cleaning high-touch surfaces, and not shaking hands.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: The following business categories may not continue operations or reopen in the Phase 2 Reopen Plan: Sporting facilities and venues; Indoor children’s play areas; Water parks, unless they can create a facility-specific plan to observe the industry guidance provided for water parks;

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space; Gym/workout facility/fitness center
policy_description: Concerning Youth and Recreational Sports, sports may resume, provided that all players, staff, coaches, officials and spectators must comply with social distancing guidelines of 6 feet or more to the greatest extent possible and no tournaments are held. Tournaments may resume subject to organizers receiving prior approval of a tournament-specific plan by the Division of Public Health.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Indoor children’s play areas may not operate, unless they can create a facility-specific plan to observe the industry guidance provided for indoor children’s play areas, including that that the total number of guests permitted in a facility at any one time shall not exceed 30% of that facility’s stated fire occupancy requirements.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Personal care services may resume provided that the total number of guests permitted in an establishment at any one time shall not exceed 30% of that facility’s stated fire occupancy requirements.

Taprooms, brewpubs and restaurants may not permit patrons to sit or stand at a bar, but may open the bar to prepare drinks to be brought to diners seated at tables. Taprooms, brewpubs and restaurants that choose to use designated bar space for seating patrons must arrange tables consistent with the Phase 2 Reopen Plan to allow for minimum social distancing, as enumerated.

Personal driving schools and instruction may reopen, provided that at a maximum the vehicle may contain one adult and one student in front driver and passenger seats, and one additional person in the back seat. All occupants must wear face coverings at all times. Windows should be open as much as possible to help air exchange within the vehicle to reduce viral load.

policy_subtarget: Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare); Primary education; Secondary education
policy_description: Local education authorities will follow the school reopening instructions provided by the Delaware Department of Education.

policy_subtarget: Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare); Primary education; Secondary education
policy_description: Effective 09/01/2020,  group sizes in child care homes and centers may increase from 15 to 25 for school age children, under the conditions that social distancing and mask-wearing procedures are met.

policy_subtarget: Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare); Primary education; Secondary education
policy_description: An initial in-person screening or WIDA Remote Screening assessment of English language proficiency shall be conducted as soon as practicable, but not later than 45 school days after enrollment and shall be conducted by qualified personnel trained in the administration of the assessment instrument.

policy_subtarget: Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare); Primary education; Secondary education
policy_description: In person educational settings must implement  preventative measures to mitigate the spread of COVID-19. This includes access to handwashing facilities and supplies and hand sanitizer, desk configuration, discontinuation of off-site field trips, health status and monitoring procedures, limited bus occupancy, modified requirements for in-person attendance,
All youth and amateur adult sports facilities, organizations and leagues must review this document and follow all mandated terms for operation.
Social distancing and sanitary regulations to be upheld by both towns and beach-goers are enumerated.
Long term care facilities must implement enumerated measure to mitigate transmission of COVID-19 and to limit gathering sizes within facilities.

All public meetings of public bodies governed by may be conducted in person in public buildings, provided that (1) the total number of individuals permitted in a room at one time shall not exceed 60% of stated fire occupancy requirements; (2) a 6 foot radius around individuals is maintained, and (3) attendees wear face coverings. Public bodies are encouraged to conduct meetings electronically, either by means of telephone conference call or video conference call. Any in-person meeting must also provide a telephone or video conference option for any member of the public body or the public who does not wish to attend in person.
As part of phase two opening for the State of Delaware, businesses are responsible for upholding and enforcing social distancing and sanitation measures.
Group sizes in child care centers may increase from 15 to 25 for school age children (space  permitting).

Gatherings and events of up to 250 people must comply with enumerated measures to mitigate transmission of COVID-19. Schools may apply to host a large gathering or event at the discretion of the Department of Education.

As part of phase two opening for the State of Delaware, businesses must comply with the stated fire occupancy requirements (e.g. 30 to 60%). This includes salons, houses of worship, swimming facilities, golf courses, convention centers, ice-cream trucks, commercial offices and larger residential buildings, private instruction, campgrounds, auction houses, commercial lodging, personal driving schools, parks and recreation facilities, exercise facilities, retail establishments, and malls.

In person educational institutions must abide by enumerated sanitation and hygienic measures, such as accessible hand-washing stations and distanced placement of desks. Bus capacity must be limited by the number of students  that can be seated 3 or more feet apart on the school bus with face coverings.
Local Education Agencies will follow the school reopening instructions provided by the Delaware Department of Education on its website.
Sporting facilities and venues, indoor children's play areas, and water parks may not pen during phase 2.
Effective 12/01/2020 at 8:00 a.m. E.D.T., any individual who participates in an out-of-state tournament or competition must immediately self-quarantine.

Effective 12/07/2020 at 8:00 a.m. E.D.T., and until further notice, tournaments plans may be submitted but will not be approved by DPH, except that tournaments having received prior approval from the Division of Public Health to play.

Under Phase 2, retail establishments of  5,000 sq. ft. or less may continue operations or reopen provided, however, that the total number of individuals within the retail establishment shall not exceed 40% of that facility’s stated fire occupancy requirements.

From 12/14/2020 to 01/11/2021, unless expressly extended, Delaware residents are advised and strongly encouraged to stay home as often as possible and to only leave home to go to work or school, or for necessary needs such as seeking medical care, going to the grocery store or pharmacy, or picking up food.

Under Phase 2, indoor gatherings or events at any business or indoor space open to the public may do so up to the lesser of 30% stated fire occupancy or ten 10 people.  This includes business offices.

Under Phase 2, the total number of guests permitted in a food court at any one time shall not exceed 20% of that facility’s stated fire occupancy requirements or 100 individuals, whichever is less. On-site premise consumption of food and beverages may not occur between the hours of 10 pm and 5 am.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Retail stores (not including food)
policy_description: Under Phase 2, businesses with less than 100,000 sq. ft. and retail establishments having 5,001 sq. ft. but no more than 100,000 sq. ft. may continue operations or reopen provided, however, that the total number of individuals within them shall not exceed 30% of that facility’s stated fire occupancy requirements.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Retail stores (not including food)
policy_description: Under Phase 2, all businesses, including retail establishments, having 100,001+ sq. ft. may  continue operations or reopen provided, however, that the total number of individuals within the business shall not exceed 20% of that facility’s stated fire occupancy requirements.

Under Phase 2, group exercise classes are limited to a maximum of 10 individuals, excluding staff. Staff must be on-site to monitor patrons entering the facility, to ensure social distancing throughout the facility, and to ensure the use of face coverings in compliance with this order.

Under Phase 2, Houses of Worship may continue operations or reopen provided, however, that the total number of guests permitted in a House of Worship at any one time shall not exceed 40% of that House of Worship’s stated fire occupancy.

All games, matches, and competitions are hereby suspended, except that any game, match, or competition that received approval from the Division of Public Health prior to 12/14/2020 is hereby granted an exception to the additional restrictions that became effective in this Modification. The maximum occupancy for any indoor practice is thirty percent (30%) of stated fire occupancy requirements, including athletes, coaches, and other employees or staff.

The Office of Planning, Deputy Mayor for Education, and the Department of Health, are directed to implement a campus plan approval process for colleges and universities by July 1, 2020 to plan a safe reopening.
The Department of Parks and Recreation is authorized to reopen parks, dog parks, tennis courts, tracks, and fields. Indoor facilities, playgrounds, public pools, and recreation centers remain closed.

Barbershops and hair salons may provide services by appointment only. No waiting inside the shop is permitted. There may be one customer per worker. Customer stations must be at least six feet apart. Some close-contact services are prohibited.
Farmer's markets may request waivers to sell non-food items and food prepared on site, allow customers to select their own produce, and provide non-essential information and education.
Individuals living in, working in, and visiting the District are no longer ordered to stay in their residences as the District enters Phase One of reopening.

This section outlines requirements/dates for absentee ballots and their requests (including overseas ballots), electronic petitions, and other election information. For the June 2, 2020, Primary Election, every registered qualified elector in DC will be mailed an absentee ballot application and a postage-paid return envelope. For the Primary Election and the June 16, 2020, Ward 2 Special Election, revised plans/polling places for those elections will be promoted.
The owner of a housing accommodation must clean common areas of the facility on a regular basis.
Defendants may be awarded good time credits. If certain criteria are met, inmates may also be rewarded with compassionate release. Non-custodial arrest rules have also been made more flexible.
Farmer's markets operating under a waiver granted under Mayor's Order 2020-058 or 2020-067 are not affected by this order.
Non-essential, non-retail businesses should continue to have employees telework to the greatest extent possible consistent with their business operations.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Receiving visitors inside the a nursing home or assisted living facility is restricted. DOH provides guidance on allowable procedures for receiving visitors.

Nonessential retail businesses may open to customers for indoor shopping, so long as they limit the number of people to 50% occupancy and establish processes to allow for social distancing. They must follow all DOH protocols.
Mass gatherings of over 50 people are prohibited. The prohibition on mass gatherings over ten individuals is repealed.

In addition to the barbershops and hair salons that were allowed to operate in Phase One, tanning, waxing, threading, electrolysis, cryotherapy, facial, other skin services, and nail salons may open under the same conditions as barbershops and nail salons.

Camps and aftercare activities may reopen provided that no more than ten campers/participants are in a single indoor space at any one time. Protocols must allow for social distancing and handwashing. There must be no mixing of ten-child cohorts.

Childcare centers may resume operations with the same staff/child ratios as applicable prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, with enhanced social distancing and hygiene practices as may be prescribed by the Office of the State Superintendent of Education or DOH.

Restaurants and other licensed food establishments may open for indoor dining with the following safeguards: all indoor diners must be seated and served at tables of no more than 6 persons separated by at least six feet; bar seating is prohibited if a bartender is working at that bar; sanitation and disinfection protocols must be implemented, and any activities not carried out at seated tables are prohibited; no indoor queuing is allowed; only 50% of indoor capacity is allowed. Restaurants and other food establishments may continue to operate with seated outdoor eating and drinking.
Playgrounds may open. Low to moderate contact sports are allowed on a casual basis.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Limited group activities may occur in nursing homes and assisted living facilities per DOH guidelines. Communal dining inside facilities shall remain restricted per Mayor's Order 2020-063.
Libraries may reopen for indoor service, with capacity limits of 50%. Libraries may set time limits for users.

Fitness establishments such as gyms, health clubs, yoga, dance, and workout studios may open with capacity limits of five persons per 1000 square feet. See section XI.3 for more applicable restrictions.

Recreational facilities such as recreation centers, bowling alleys, climbing gyms, squash or racquet clubs, skating rinks, and skateboard parks may open with no more than 50% of capacity or 50 persons per room, whichever is fewer.

Places of worship may operate with expanded capacity limits. No service may exceed 50% of facility capacity or one hundred persons, whichever is fewer. Each group must be seated at least six feet from each other group. Facilities must be cleaned between services.

Museums and the National Zoo may reopen, provided that they do not offer guided tours where social distancing cannot be achieved, and do not permit more than 50 persons at one time into a self-contained facility.
Colleges and universities may reopen in accordance with plans and processes accepted by the Office of Planning.
Open houses may be held. Developers may resume hosting ground-breakings, grand openings, and other events. Further restrictions are laid out in section XII.1.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Nursing homes and assisted living facilities shall maintain a dedicated space for cohorting and managing care for residents with COVID-19 and residents who are developing symptoms.

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: All individuals residing in a community-based nursing home or assisted living facility must stay at their residence except to engage in Essential Activities, obtain medical care, obtain food and essential goods, to work at Essential Business, to access Essential Government Functions, to engage in Essential Travel, or engage in Allowable Recreational Activities.
Masking, queuing, and capacity measures previously established for essential businesses such as grocery stores and pharmacies are unchanged.
When leaving their residence or visiting the District, all individuals must continue to maintain a distance of at least six feet from persons not in their household.

policy_subtarget: Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Activities that remain closed include: hookah bars and cigar bars; bars, nightclubs, and mixed use facilities unless they are serving food consistent with the Mayor's Orders; hot tubs, saunas, and steam rooms; high contact sports; organized club team sports in all District parks and fields; and spray parks.

All residents and persons traveling to or from "high-risk areas" for non-essential travel must self-quarantine for fourteen days following their return or arrival to the District. Persons traveling through a high-risk area such as an airport or by vehicle are not subject to the quarantine requirement.  Maryland and Virginia are exempt; otherwise, high-risk areas are locations where the 7-day moving average daily new COVID-19 case rate is ten or more per 100,000 persons.

Persons returning to or arriving in the District for essential travel are required to self-monitor for symptoms of COVID-19 and seek medical care or testing if they show symptoms. They must also limit their contact with other persons for fourteen days to only the essential purpose for their travel.
Term One (Fall 2020) for DC Public Schools will be all virtual for students in Pre-K through 12th grade.
Defendants may be awarded good time credits. If certain criteria are met, inmates may also be rewarded with compassionate release. Non-custodial arrest rules have also been made more flexible.

This section outlines requirements/dates for absentee ballots and their requests (including overseas ballots), electronic petitions, and other election information. For the June 2, 2020, Primary Election, every registered qualified elector in DC will be mailed an absentee ballot application and a postage-paid return envelope. For the Primary Election and the June 16, 2020, Ward 2 Special Election, revised plans/polling places for those elections will be promoted.
The owner of a housing accommodation must clean common areas of the facility on a regular basis.

This section outlines requirements/dates for absentee ballots and their requests (including overseas ballots), electronic petitions, and other election information. For the June 2, 2020, Primary Election, every registered qualified elector in DC will be mailed an absentee ballot application and a postage-paid return envelope. For the Primary Election and the June 16, 2020, Ward 2 Special Election, revised plans/polling places for those elections will be promoted.
The owner of a housing accommodation must clean common areas of the facility on a regular basis.
Defendants may be awarded good time credits. If certain criteria are met, inmates may also be rewarded with compassionate release. Non-custodial arrest rules have also been made more flexible.

District residents returning to DC must limit activities and self-monitor for 14 days, or limit activities until they test negative for COVID-19 within 3 to 5 days after their return.  Travelers returning from Maryland, Virginia, or low risk states/countries are exempt. Essential workers are exempt unless they have recently been exposed to COVID-19.

All residents, especially those returning from travel, should self-monitor for symptoms of COVID-19 for 14 days after travel, and isolate and obtain a test if they show a symptom. They should continue to isolate until symptoms subside and they are confirmed to be negative.

Visitors who cannot or do not provide proof of a negative COVID-19 test to District officials must self-quarantine for 14 days upon arrival. At all times, all visitors should self-monitor for COVID-19. If they develop symptoms, they must remain in their accommodations, leaving only to obtain medical care or a COVID-19 test, until they test negative.

DC Public Schools will open a limited number of CARE Classrooms at 29 elementary schools on November 18, with capacity to serve 600+ students. These classrooms will operate five days per week with a half day on Wednesday.
Gyms, private trainers, and recreation centers must suspend all indoor group exercise classes. Outdoor group exercise classes are limited to less than 25 persons.
Houses of worship may only have 500 persons or 50% of maximum occupancy attending an indoor service, whichever is less.

Restaurants and other licensed food establishments may continue to operate for patrons until midnight, but alcohol sales, service, and consumption must stop at 10:00 PM. Delivery and carry-out orders are exempt.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: The number of people allowed at an outdoor mass gathering is reduced from 50 to 25 persons. Houses of worship are exempt from outdoor gathering limits.

Indoor gatherings may not exceed 10 people, including social gatherings in private spaces.  Indoor spaces are defined as structures with more than two walls. Spaces that are subject to more specific rules (e.g. restaurants or houses of worship) are exempt, as are households with more than 10 persons.
The maximum indoor occupancy of restaurants is reduced from 50% to 25%.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Secondary education; Gym/workout facility/fitness center
policy_description: Recreation centers and sports clubs must suspend organized athletic activities, including practices, clinics, and competitions for high-school aged athletes.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space; Secondary education; Higher education
policy_description: High-contact sports (defined by the DOH as basketball, boxing, football, hockey, lacrosse, martial arts, rugby, soccer, and wrestling) are prohibited in the District. '  Universities and professional leagues may continue to practice so long as their health and safety plan is approved by their governing bodies. All high school sports and competitions are suspended at public, private, and parochial schools.   Department of Parks and Recreation permits may be used for non-contact workouts by children younger than high school age or by adults. Athletes may not be in groups of more than 12, and all players must maintain social distance.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Primary education; Secondary education
policy_description: Physical education classes should not involve activities where students might come within six feet of one another. Classes may include 25 persons outdoors and 10 persons indoors. DPR shall suspend issuance of new permits for organized sports and team play on DPR fields.

Certain individuals are prohibited from visiting facilities. For purposes of this order, a facility includes nursing homes, assisted living facilities, adult family-care homes, long-term care facilities, and adult group homes.
Each facility type named, characterized by their care for the elderly, are to limit or prohibit entry of individuals who may pose a threat to the health and safety of residents.
All persons entering the State of Florida from an area with substantial community spread of COVID-19 are ordered to isolate or quarantine for 14 days from the time of entry into the State.

All persons entering the State of Florida from an area with substantial community spread of COVID-19 are ordered to isolate or quarantine for 14 days from the time of entry into the State. They are also mandated to inform any individual in Florida with whom they have had direct physical contact in the past 21 days that they have traveled from an area with substantial community spread.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: The State of Florida Surgeon General and State Health Officer is ordered to issue a public health advisory to all persons with serious underlying medical conditions or who are of 65 year of age or older.
The State Surgeon General of Florida is to issue a public health advisory against all social or recreational gatherings of 10 or more people.
Brown County and Palm Beach beaches are ordered to close.
Upcoming elections in the State of Florida are to be rescheduled to as soon as practical
As part of the "phase 1" opening of the State of Florida, museums and libraries may open if they abide by distancing guidelines and limit operations to 25% of the building's capacity.

policy_subtarget: Restaurants/bars; Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: As part of the "phase 1" opening of the State of Florida, restaurants and food establishments may allow on-premise consumption of food in beverage so long as they follow distancing guidelines and hold their capacity at 25% of the building's maximum capacity.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Retail stores (not including food)
policy_description: As part of the "phase 1" opening of the State of Florida, retail establishments may open storefronts if they abide by distancing guidelines and limit operations to 25% of the building's capacity.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Personal care facilities
policy_description: Executive Order 20-112, regarding the State of Florida's "phase 1" of reopening, is extended to include barbershops and cosmetology salons in the permitted business activities.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Museums and libraries may operate at up to 50% of maximum occupancy.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Counties may seek to recommence rental business by submitting a request to the Department of Business and Professional Regulation.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Retail stores (not including food)
policy_description: Retail stores may operate at up to 50% of maximum occupancy.
Restaurants and food establishments may serve patrons in indoor setting at a 50% of maximum occupancy.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Gym/workout facility/fitness center
policy_description: Gyms and fitness centers may operate at up to 50% of maximum occupancy.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Professional sports may host training, competitions, events and games.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Amusement parks may submit a re-open
Previously delayed municipal elections are to be further delayed to 6/30/2020.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare)
policy_description: Youth sport teams, youth clubs and programs, child care, summer camps, and youth recreation camps, may all operate.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Personal services may operate with appropriate safety guidelines.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Entertainment businesses may operate at 50% of their maximum capacity.

Executive Orders 20-80 and 20-82, concerning the requirement of persons traveling into the State of Florida, are modified to exempt those traveling for school, athletics or business.  This supersedes Executive Order 20-86, concerning the implementation of checkpoints for interstate travelers.
Bar areas may be open with seated service. Outdoor seating is permissible with appropriate social distancing.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Government/public buildings; Public sector/government employees
policy_description: Canvassing Boards are permitted to begin canvassing of Vote-By-Mail ballots earlier on the 22nd day before the election.
Supervisor of Elections shall ensure social distancing and cleaning procedures for Early Voting and Election Day, insofar as is practicable.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Government/public buildings; Public sector/government employees
policy_description: Governor Ron DeSantis suspends the authorization of Administrative Leave for any state employee to serve as a poll worker in the county which they are an elector. State employees are strongly encouraged to serve as poll workers in their home county.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Government/public buildings; Public sector/government employees; Primary education; Secondary education
policy_description: Governor Ron DeSantis encourage all school district faculty, staff, and instructors to serve as poll workers on Election Day.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Government/public buildings; Public sector/government employees
policy_description: The Supervisor of Elections is ordered to provide timely notice to the public regarding any changes in voting locations or procedures in a manner designed to ensure widespread dissemination of voting information to members of the public.

policy_subtarget: Government/public buildings; Primary education; Secondary education
policy_description: Governor Ron DeSantis encourages each Superintendent of Schools, in coordination with the Commissioner of Education, to close all K-12 schools on 08/18/2020 for use on Primary Election Day and on 11/03/2020 for use on General Election Day as precinct polling locations.
All schools boards and charter school governing boards must open brick and mortar schools at least five days per week
Florida Statute that requires a quorum or supermajority of the membership to be present in person or requires the local government body to meet at a specific public place are suspended.

The Florida Department of Business and Professional Regulation shall ensure all restaurants implement employee screening protocols pursuant to guidance developed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Residents and visitors of Georgia who meet given criteria for higher risk of severe illness are required to shelter in place.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: No businesses, establishments, corporations or other organizations shall permit gatherings  in groups greater than 10 persons if, to be present, persons are required to stand or be seated within 6 feet of any other person.

policy_subtarget: Restaurants/bars; Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: This overrides the formerly enforced "stay-at-home" order of Georgia, Executive Order 03.23.20.01., concerning the closure of all Bars and restriction of dine-in services in the state of Georgia.
Optometrists shall provide the full scope of their services.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: In instances where persons are working outdoors without regular contact with other persons, these persons shall only be required to implement social distancing measures as described by the CDC.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: This overrides the formerly enforced "stay-at-home" order of Georgia, Executive Order 04.02.20.01., concerning the closure of all businesses or minimization of operations.

policy_subtarget: Restaurants/bars; Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Restaurants and Dining rooms are permitted to resume dine-in services so long as they implement the listed procedures to mitigate the spread of COVID-19.
All bowling alleys and theaters shall begin in-person operations.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space; Restaurants/bars; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Live performance venues, operators of amusement rides and bars in the State of Georgia shall not open in-person operations for the duration of this order.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Higher education
policy_description: Nothing in 05.28.20.02 shall inhibit the capacity for schools and universities to operate for the 2020-2021 school year.
No business or establishment shall allow gatherings of persons, defined as a group of 25 or more persons who are capable of maintaining a distance of 6 feet from one another.
In restaurants, no more than 10 patrons shall be present in a 300 square-foot sized space. All restaurants shall implement guidance for the mitigation of COVID-19 spreading.
All essential and non-essential entities that continue to operate are to implement measures to mitigate the exposure and spread of COVID-19.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); General population (inclusive); Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Bowling alleys shall implement measures to mitigate the spread of COVID-19.

policy_subtarget: Essential business (inclusive); Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Grocery store; Restaurants/bars
policy_description: All food establishments, including groceries, shall implement additional measures to mitigate the spread of COVID-19. This includes regular sanitation and disinfection, specialized hours for vulnerable populations, enforcing social distancing measures, etc.
Child care centers shall implement measures to mitigate the spread of COVID-19.

policy_subtarget: Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); General population (inclusive); Restaurants/bars; Retail stores (not including food)
policy_description: Retailers and food venues shall implement measures to mitigate the spread of COVID-19. This includes limiting occupancy, regular disinfection, and encouragement of patrons to use hand sanitizer.
Residents and visitors of the State of Georgia are ordered to follow sanitation guidelines distributed by the CDC.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); General population (inclusive); Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Gyms and fitness centers shall implement measures to mitigate the spread of COVID-19.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Higher education
policy_description: When these schools do operate, they should do so under measures that mitigate the spread of COVID-19.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); General population (inclusive); Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Indoor movie theaters and cinemas shall implement measures to mitigate the spread of COVID-19.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); General population (inclusive); Personal care facilities
policy_description: Body art and cosmetic salons shall implement measures to mitigate the spread of COVID-19.

policy_subtarget: Pharmacy; Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist); Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services
policy_description: Medical workers in dentistry, optometry, and ambulatory centers shall operate under measures that mitigate the spread of COVID-19.
Live performance venues shall not host events prior to 07/01/2020.
When live performance operations begin, they must adhere to sanitation and distancing guidelines.
No conventions shall operate in the State of Georgia prior to 07/01/2020.
In-person appearances before a county board may occur online.
Summer camps shall implement explicit measures to mitigate the spread of COVID-19. This includes screening and isolation of suspected cases.
No business or organization shall permit the gathering of persons.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); General population (inclusive); Restaurants/bars
policy_description: All restaurants and business shall implement enumerated hygienic and sanitation measures, including worker hygienic strategies and the implementation of a plexiglass divider between workers and patrons.

Summer schools in the State of Georgia shall implement explicit measures to mitigate the spread of COVID-19. This includes regular disinfection and sanitation practices and social distancing when possible.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Persons required to shelter in place shall not receive visitors except if the visitors are there to provide a service or end-of-life care.
All residents and visitors of the State  of Georgia shall adhere to social distancing and practice sanitation as outlined by the CDC.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); General population (inclusive); Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Temporary amusement rides and organizations, such as circuses, shall implement explicit measures to mitigate the spread of COVID-19. This includes minimizing populations on premise and providing accessible sanitation procedures.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Persons particularly vulnerable to COVID-19 are required to shelter at their place of residence, except to perform critical services or activities.

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Nursing homes/assisted living facility
policy_description: To the extent possible, medical facilities in the State of Georgia shall offer dine-in facilities.

Live performance venues shall not operate before 07/01/2020. When operation resumes, venues will comply with guidance that is unique to the size of the venue per fire regulations. Fire capacity of venue will place it in one of three 'Tiers', each with specialized guidance for the mitigation of COVID-19 transmission.

Childcare centers in the State of Georgia shall implement explicit measures to mitigate the spread of COVID-19. This includes the minimizing of populations on premise, limited group transportation and the screening for suspected cases of COVID-19.

policy_subtarget: Housing sector; Criminal justice system/prisons/jails/incarcerated persons; Public sector/government employees
policy_description: The landlord/tenant and small claims calendars scheduled for the month of July are cancelled due to increasing cases in the state.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Persons particularly vulnerable to COVID-19 are required to shelter at their place of residence, except to perform critical services or activities.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Persons particularly vulnerable to COVID-19 are required to shelter at their place of residence, except to perform critical services or activities.

Childcare centers in the State of Georgia shall implement explicit measures to mitigate the spread of COVID-19. This includes the minimizing of populations on premise, limited group transportation and the screening for suspected cases of COVID-19.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Persons required to shelter in place shall not receive visitors except if the visitors are there to provide a service or end-of-life care.

School districts in the State of Georgia shall not have to comply with restrictions on gatherings but must comply with listed, screening, precautionary and response measures to mitigate the spread of COVID-19. Such measures include enhancing sanitation, ensuring proper ventilation, and discouraging physical contact between students.

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Nursing homes/assisted living facility
policy_description: To the extent possible, medical facilities in the State of Georgia shall offer dine-in facilities.

policy_description: All restaurants and business shall implement enumerated hygienic and sanitation measures, including worker hygienic strategies and the implementation of a plexiglass divider between workers and patrons.

Conventions shall operate with additional measures to mitigate the spread of COVID-19, these include placing signage that expresses that individuals may not enter the convention if they have been exposed to COVID-19 in the previous 14 days, enhanced sanitation measures, and discouragement of physical contact.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); General population (inclusive); Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Temporary amusement rides and organizations, such as circuses, shall implement explicit measures to mitigate the spread of COVID-19. This includes minimizing populations on premise and providing accessible sanitation procedures.

The Governors office of State of Hawaii supplements his emergency proclamation with a requirement that all persons entering the state to self-quarantine for a period of 14 days.
The Emergency Management Agency of the State of Hawaii orders all persons entering the state to self-quarantine for a period of 14 days.
All persons traveling between the islands of Hawai'i shall be subject to mandatory self quarantine.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Grocery store; Retail stores (not including food)
policy_description: Third Supplementary Proclamation signed on 3/23/2020, requiring all persons in the state of Hawaii to stay at their place of residence though 04/30/2020, is amended to include extended time periods for applications for arms and restrictions on farmers markets.

policy_subtarget: Suspected cases; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Confirmed cases
policy_description: High-risk populations and those who are sick are urged to remain at their place of residence to the extent possible.

policy_subtarget: Essential business (inclusive); Transportation sector/shipping/logistics; Travelers; Public transportation
policy_description: Airlines, taxis, transportation network providers (such as Uber and Lyft), vehicle rental services, paratransit, and other private, public, and commercial transportation and logistics are identified as essential services

Persons subject to self-quarantine are prohibited from renting motor vehicles in the State.  All persons who provide motor vehicles shall be responsible for ensuring that they do not rent, lease, or otherwise provide any motor vehicle to any person subject to a self-quarantine.
A series of regulatory statutes are suspended in the State of Hawai'i to facilitate emergency management. This includes suspension of disposition of convicted defendants.

Persons experiencing homelessness, though exempt from requirements to remain at their place of residence, shall comply with the social distancing requirements to the fullest extent possible and are strongly urged to obtain shelter.
All hosts of any guest or guests within the State of Hawai‘i shall be responsible for ensuring their guest or guests abide by the mandatory self-quarantine.
Restaurants may operate for consumption off-premises.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: Beaches in Hawaiʻi are closed, unless opened in accordance with executed guidelines regarding COVID-19.
All persons in the State of Hawai'i shall maintain a minimum of six-feet of physical separation from all other persons to the fullest extent possible.
All persons traveling between any of the islands in the State of Hawai‘i shall be subject to mandatory self-quarantine, exempting those traveling for medical care.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: No group of more than two persons may engage in shore fishing, unless all in the group are part of a single residential or family unit sharing the same address.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: No more than two persons are allowed in any boat on Hawaiʻi’s waters for recreational purposes unless they are part of a single residential or family unit sharing the same address. All boats shall maintain a distance of 20 feet from other boats.

Businesses shall implement safety precautions that enable patrons to maintain 6-foot distances. This includes limiting the business occupancy, regular disinfection of the premise, accommodations for at risk individuals, requirements of patrons to wear a face covering, informational signage and options for delivery or pick-up options.
All persons entering the State of Hawaiʻi shall be subject to mandatory self-quarantine, exempting those who have been at-sea for recreational purposes for longer than 14 days.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: No group of more than two persons is allowed to hike on state trails, unless all hikers in the group are part of a single residential or family unit sharing the same address. All hikers shall maintain a 20 foot distance from other groups.
A series of regulatory statutes are suspended in the State of Hawai'i to facilitate emergency management. This includes suspension of disposition of convicted defendants.

Persons subject to self-quarantine are prohibited from renting motor vehicles in the State.  All persons who provide motor vehicles shall be responsible for ensuring that they do not rent, lease, or otherwise provide any motor vehicle to any person subject to a self-quarantine.
All hosts of any guest or guests within the State of Hawai‘i shall be responsible for ensuring their guest or guests abide by the mandatory self-quarantine.

All persons entering the State of Hawai‘i shall submit to the mandatory health screening process identified in the Rules Relating to COVID-19 Health Screening Process and Travel Self-Quarantine.

A county may establish an Enhanced Movement Quarantine (EMQ) program through agreements with resort or hotel facilities. Travelers who enter the State as part of an EMQ  program must comply with all State, county and industry safety and health standards applicable to such program and complete all mandatory documentation.

All persons traveling from within the State to the Islands of Kaua‘i, Hawai‘i, and the Islands comprising the Counties of Maui and Kalawao, in the State of Hawai‘i shall be subject to mandatory self-quarantine.

policy_subtarget: Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Public sector/government employees; Non-governmental organizations
policy_description: Businesses that may operate in the state of Hawaii include: businesses or operations that are part of the federal critical infrastructure sectors, including essential workers supporting the 2020 Census, as identified by the U.S. Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency, and the businesses or operations operating in each county in accordance with the State Roadmap to Recovery and Resilience.

All persons traveling from within the State to the Islands of Kaua‘i, Hawai‘i, and the Islands comprising the Counties of Maui and Kalawao, in the State of Hawai‘i shall be subject to mandatory self-quarantine.

Persons subject to self-quarantine are prohibited from renting motor vehicles in the State.  All persons who provide motor vehicles shall be responsible for ensuring that they do not rent, lease, or otherwise provide any motor vehicle to any person subject to a self-quarantine.

All persons entering the State of Hawai‘i shall submit to the mandatory health screening process identified in the Rules Relating to COVID-19 Health Screening Process and Travel Self-Quarantine. In two instances, these persons may be exempt from quarantine:  (1) persons who enter by recreational boats into the State’s small boat harbors which have been at sea for at least 14 consecutive days before entering State waters and have no persons on board who are ill or are exhibiting symptoms of COVID-19 or (2) persons who, upon entry into the State, provide written confirmation from a State approved COVID19 testing facility of a  negative test result from an observed test administered to the traveler within 72 hours from the final leg of departure.

policy_subtarget: Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Public sector/government employees; Non-governmental organizations
policy_description: Businesses that may operate in the state of Hawaii include: businesses or operations that are part of the federal critical infrastructure sectors, including essential workers supporting the 2020 Census, as identified by the U.S. Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency, and the businesses or operations operating in each county in accordance with the State Roadmap to Recovery and Resilience.

A county may establish an Enhanced Movement Quarantine (EMQ) program through agreements with resort or hotel facilities. Travelers who enter the State as part of an EMQ  program must comply with all State, county and industry safety and health standards applicable to such program and complete all mandatory documentation.

Persons subject to self-quarantine are prohibited from renting motor vehicles in the State.  All persons who provide motor vehicles shall be responsible for ensuring that they do not rent, lease, or otherwise provide any motor vehicle to any person subject to a self-quarantine.

All persons traveling from within the State to the Islands of Kaua‘i, Hawai‘i, and the Islands comprising the Counties of Maui and Kalawao, in the State of Hawai‘i shall be subject to mandatory self-quarantine.

All persons entering the State of Hawai‘i shall submit to the mandatory health screening process identified in the Rules Relating to COVID-19 Health Screening Process and Travel Self-Quarantine. In two instances, these persons may be exempt from quarantine:  (1) persons who enter by recreational boats into the State’s small boat harbors which have been at sea for at least 14 consecutive days before entering State waters and have no persons on board who are ill or are exhibiting symptoms of COVID-19 or (2) persons who, upon entry into the State, provide written confirmation from a State approved COVID19 testing facility of a  negative test result from an observed test administered to the traveler within 72 hours from the final leg of departure.
All hosts of any guest or guests within the State of Hawai‘i shall be responsible for ensuring their guest or guests abide by the mandatory self-quarantine.
