The Open Meeting Act of section 74-203(5), Idaho Code is partially suspended. Citizens continue to have the right to attend any meetings of governing bodies, both only through telecommunication attendance.
Primary Election and Consolidated Elections shall be conducted in accordance with the existing absentee voting by mail process in the State of Idaho.
A legislative session regarding mail-in voting for upcoming elections to mitigate spread of COVID-19 is ordered to occur.
Re-issues and extends the suspension of admissions to the Illinois Department of Corrections from all Illinois county jails.
Re-issues and extends the suspension of admissions to the Illinois Department of Corrections from all Illinois county jails.

policy_subtarget: Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Places of public amusement may resume services consistent with DCEO guidance for indoor and outdoor recreation.
Businesses that offer food or beverages for on-premises consumption may resume service for on-premises consumption, as permitted by DCEO guidance.

All schools serving pre-kindergarten through 12th grade students may open for limited in-person educational purposes after the 2019-2020 school term in accordance with IDPH guidance; the number of people in one space cannot exceed fifty.
Businesses offering outdoor recreation, youth day camps, and youth sports may open in accordance with DCEO guidance.
Mass gatherings of more than 50 people are prohibited.
Gyms may open at maximum fifty percent capacity, subject to restrictions including social distancing.
Individuals must maintain a distance of six feet from any other person who does not live with them, including outdoors.
Personal service facilities may open with restrictions including face coverings, social distancing, and use of capacity limits in accordance with DCEO guidance.
Re-issues and extends the suspension of admissions to the Illinois Department of Corrections from all Illinois county jails.
Re-issues and extends closure of James R. Thompson Center to members of the public.
Extends order that mass gatherings of more than 50 people are prohibited.
Extends order that individuals must maintain a distance of six feet from any other person who does not live with them, including outdoors.

Re-issues and extends closure of James R. Thompson Center to members of the public. Specifies that the Department of Central Management Services may designate points of ingress and egress and control traffic flow in the James R. Thompson Center for State employees and members of the public attending to State business or patronizing the businesses and food court.

All schools serving pre-kindergarten through 12th grade students may open for in-personal educational purposes following the 2019-2020 school term, with restrictions including limiting the number of people in one space to 50 or fewer, social distancing, and requiring symptom screenings and temperature checks.
Extends order that businesses that offer food or beverages for on-premises consumption may resume service for on-premises consumption, as permitted by DCEO guidance.
Extends order that personal service facilities may open with restrictions including face coverings, social distancing, and use of capacity limits in accordance with DCEO guidance.
Re-issues and extends the order cancelling the state fairs in Springfield and DuQuoin scheduled for 2020.
Extends order that gyms may open at maximum fifty percent capacity, subject to restrictions including social distancing.
Re-issues and extends the suspension of admissions to the Illinois Department of Corrections from all Illinois county jails.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Minors and children
policy_description: Announces updated guidance for youth and adult recreational winter sports. The youth sports guidance puts sports into three risk levels, lower, medium, or higher, based on the amount of contact between athletes and their proximity during play. The guidance sets four levels of play allowed based on current public health conditions. In all levels, some form of play is allowed ranging from practice and trainings in level 1 to tournaments and conference play in level 4.  • In level 1, only no-contact practices and training are allowed. • In level 2, intra-team scrimmages are allowed with parental consent for minors but there can be no competitive play. • In level 3 intra-conference, intra-EMS-region or intra-league play is allowed and there may be state- or league-championship games allowed for low-risk sports only. • In level 4, tournaments, out-of-conference/league play, and out-of-state play are allowed. Championship games would also be allowed in level 4

This does not apply to fitness centers.

Announces statewide move to Tier 3:  - Gaming and casinos close - Indoor recreation centers, including theaters, performing arts centers and indoor museums and amusement centers, close - Live streaming of performances encouraged with social distancing of performers and minimum operational staff - Outdoor activities allowed at 25% capacity or less - Outdoor group activities limited to 10 persons or less, participants/guests must wear face coverings at all times - Reservations required for each guest for outdoor activities

Announces statewide move to Tier 3:  - Hotel room occupancy should be limited to registered guests only, with the maximum allowance being the number of individuals permissible per existing fire code for each applicable guest room - Fitness centers should be closed, or operated only on a reservation model with capacity limited to 25% of the maximum occupancy for the room - Grab and go food allowed - Event and meeting space closed

Announces statewide move to Tier 3:  - Limit in home gatherings to household members - Meeting rooms, banquet centers, private party rooms, private clubs and country clubs may not host gatherings - No party buses - Funerals are limited to 10 family members of the decedents, not including staff, see IDPH guidance -All employees who can work remotely should work remotely

Announces statewide move to Tier 3:  - Operate at no more than 25% capacity - No indoor group classes - Face coverings must be worn at all times, including while engaged in individual exercise regardless of person or machine spacing - Reservations required - Locker room areas should be closed

Announces statewide move to Tier 3:  - Operate at no more than 25% capacity, including general merchandise stores, "big box" stores that offer groceries and pharmacy, and convenience stores - Grocery stores and pharmacies may operate at up to 50% capacity - Encourage delivery or curbside pickup options wherever possible - When in-store shopping is necessary, promote efficient trips and consistent circulation

Announces statewide move to Tier 3:  - Operate at lesser of 25 clients or 25% capacity - Face coverings must be worn at all times by clients and service providers - Suspend services where a face covering cannot be worn (e.g. facials, beard trims) - Physical, occupational and massage therapy allowed as deemed necessary by a medical provider, but appointments must be spaced by a minimum of 15 minutes and facilities should take steps to sanitize and circulate clean air through service rooms before and after each service - Virtual consultations recommended

Announces statewide move to Tier 3:  - Additional COVID training for all employees required even if previous training occurred - Operators should coordinate with IDPH to implement testing protocols and contact tracing, upon request, consistent with available testing supplies - All employees must wear face coverings at all times unless eating or drinking. - Exemptions only for safety purposes. - Only manufacturing staff and key personnel allowed in facilities. - - Non-production employees must work remotely. Non-essential staff and visitors are not permitted. Exemptions only for critical equipment repairs, supply deliveries and safety reasons (“critical visitors”). - All critical visitors must have an Employee Health and Safety (EHS)-approved risk-assessment done in advance, including travel history, tracking, and temperature check prior to entrance. - Implement additional workstation realignment when feasible - Stagger and space shifts, and designate shift entrances and exits (when possible) to minimize interactions of employees across unique shift groupings - Station sanitation required at beginning and ending of shifts - Operators must suspend COVID-related incentive pay and promote staying home when sick or showing symptoms- Implement temporary leave policies to accommodate workers who are sick - Develop and implement safety protocols for employee travel vans to promote spacing, require face coverings, temperature checks, air circulation, and vehicle sanitization

Announces statewide move to Tier 3:  -Pause all indoor group sporting and recreational activities including youth and adult recreational sports, individual training may remain (with facility reservation) - Includes park districts and travel leagues - Outdoor sports and recreation allowed - Participant groups and practices outdoors limited to 10 persons or less with social distancing - Face coverings required for all activities at all times - Locker rooms should be closed

Announces statewide move to Tier 3:  - All bars and restaurants close at 11pm and may reopen no earlier than 6am the following day - No indoor service - All bar and restaurant patrons should be seated at tables outside - No ordering, seating, or congregating at bar (bar stools should be removed) - Tables should be 6 feet apart - No standing or congregating outdoors while waiting for a table or exiting - No dancing or standing indoors - No tables exceeding 6 people - Reservations required for each party - No seating of multiple parties at one table - Indoor gaming terminals must suspend operations - Includes private clubs and country clubs
Delay non-essential public meetings. Essential meetings may have one person physically present, but other members can participate electronically.
Indiana's primary elections have been moved from May 5 to June 2.
Stage 2 of reopening: Restaurants can open to 50% capacity. Personal services can also open with public health measures.
Stage 4: Retail, commercial business, and malls may open at full capacity.
Stage 4: Outdoor visitation may take place with nursing homes, and hospital visitations with precautions are encouraged.
Stage 4: gatherings of 250 or more are prohibited.

policy_subtarget: Restaurants/bars; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Stage 4: Dining room food service may open to 75%. Bars, nightclubs, entertainment, cultural, movie theaters, amusement parks, and other similar facilities may open to 50% capacity.
All 92 counties in Indiana will advance to Stage 4 of the reopening (Safer at Home).
Stage 4: Contact sports may begin games.
Stage 4.5: K-12 school operations may begin the 2020-21 academic year
Bars will be closed for two weeks, restaurants will be limited to 25% of pre-pandemic capacity indoors
State will remain in Stage 4.5: All state government buildings, offices, facilities restricted to appointment only following health and face covering guidance
State will remain in Stage 4.5: Overnight camps may commence subject to employee and camper health screening, wearing face covering, and following adult to child ratio
State will remain in Stage 4.5: K-12 school operations begin the 2020-21, extra curricular and co-curricular activities may resume
State will remain in Stage 4.5: Fairs festivals, parades, conventions, horse racing, may resume with social distancing and capacity requirements
stage 5: Classrooms should be configured to allow for social distancing

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: stage 5: people at high risk are encouraged to continue to stay home

stage 5: Bars, restaurants, nightclubs, taverns, and other establishments serving in-person food and drink can open as long as all patrons remain seated on premises, and seating is arranged to ensure six feet apart between parties. And self service stations are permitted but not recommended unless a staff members serves patrons
stage 5: Gatherings with more than 500 individuals need to submit a written mitigation plan to the local health department 14 days before the event

Indiana now in stage 5 and implement zones with 4 levels of monitoring system where blue zone is continue with all stage 5 activities, yellow is spread risk remains low but increased vigilance are needed, orange is spread is high, and red is ISDH may order action to mitigate spread

stage 5: Businesses must have a COVID-19 response plan, follow social distancing and sanitation requirements, comply with IOSHA standards, and encourage employees to remote work when possible, ensure sick leaves are up to date, and and ask employees to stay home if they are experiencing symptoms.
People working as poll workers receiving unemployment compensation benefits will not have their unemployment benefits reduced

extends stage 5: Gatherings with more than 500 individuals need to submit a written mitigation plan to the local health department 14 days before the event

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions

The state will implement a color-coded system for the level of COVID-19 monitoring in all Indiana counties, with blue counties having the least restrictions, followed by yellow, orange, and red with the most restrictions. The commissioner of the ISDH will monitor the levels of COVID-19 weekly and update the color-coded assessment.
Summer school activities may resume on June 1.

policy_subtarget: Restaurants/bars; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Casinos/gambling facilities; Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Personal care facilities; Non essential business (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space; Retail stores (not including food); Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Restaurants and bars, fitness centers, casinos, senior centers, personal care services, theaters, malls, and other locations may open to full capacity as long as there are with social distancing and other requirements.

Restaurant, including wedding venue, winery, brewery, distillery, country club, and other social clubs can open to serve food on premises, and sell alcohol during 6am-1pm Monday to Saturday and 8am-10pm sunday
Venues selling alcohol closed except for takeout/slavery, private rental, restaurants, and bars in hotel, casinos, theaters sporting venues

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Nursing homes/assisted living facility
policy_description: Require hospitals, assisted living programs to screen staff for symptoms

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Casinos/gambling facilities; Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Personal care facilities; Non essential business (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space; Retail stores (not including food); Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Fitness centers, casinos, senior centers, personal care services, theaters, malls, and other locations may open to full capacity as long as there are with social distancing and other requirements.
For counties other than Johnson and Story, restaurant or bars can reopen to serve food and beverage on premises if it complies with social distancing guidelines.

policy_subtarget: Churches/places of worship; General population (inclusive); Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Social, community, recreational, leisure, religious, or sporting gathering or event, of more than 10 people may be held but only if it complies with social distancing and other public health measures
Restaurants in Johnson and Story counties can open as long as no more half of revenue is in alcohol sale, which can only occur on premise 6am-10pm Monday to Thursday, or 8am-10pm Sunday.

Schools can reopen as long as it complies with health guidance and prepare for a virtual learning environment. Though the state allows brick-and-mortar school district or accredited nonpublic school to provide instruction primarily though remote-learning opportunities temporarily

Bars, taverns, wineries, breweries, distilleries, night clubs in Johnson and Story counties continue to be closed, but can sell alcohol for off premise consumption, for private rentals, if at least half of revenue is in sale of food. But hotel, casino, theater, and sport venue bars are closed to the public.
Restaurants that prepare and serve food (which results in over 50% of sales) may remain open.

Carry out, drive through, and delivery are permitted to sell food and beverages taken from the premises. Establishments, such as restaurants, that are closed to the general public may still serve food and beverages to private gatherings hosted at the establishment such as a wedding reception.
A restaurant, including a wedding reception venue, winery, brewery, distillery, country club, or other social or fraternal club, may reopen or remain open to serve food and beverages on its premises.
Alcohol sales are permitted only form 6:00 am to 10:00 pm Monday through Saturday, or from 8:00 am to 10:00 pm on Sunday. if such sales are authorized by the establishment's license.

All bars, taverns, wineries, breweries, distilleries, night clubs, and other establishments located in Johnson and Story counties that sell alcoholic beverages for consumption on their premises shall be closed to the public.
Restaurants must ensure that at least 6 feet of physical distance is maintained between each group dining.
Bars located in hotels, casinos, movie theaters, or sporting venues must close. However, these establishments may continue to allow customers to consume alcohol.
Restaurants serving alcoholic beverages must also prepare and serve food to customers, which totals at least 50% of their total sales.
Require hospitals, assisted living programs to screen staff for symptoms

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Higher education
policy_description: In person instruction is the presumed method of instruction for all school districts and accredited nonpublic schools during the 2020-2021 school year. All state agencies, school districts, and other local governmental bodies must take all efforts to prepare to safely welcome back students and teachers to school in-person this fall.

Restaurants and bars, including wedding reception venues, wineries, breweries, distilleries, country clubs, or other social or fraternal clubs, may reopen or remain opened so long as they follow social distancing guidelines and other hygiene and public health measures.
Any enclosed malls may reopen or remain open as long as play areas remain closed and social distancing and other public health measures are followed.
Salons or barbershops may reopen so long as they follow social distancing, hygiene and other public health measures. Medical spas may also remain open.
Other establishments, such as museums, aquariums, swimming pools, etc. may reopen or remain open as long as they follow social distancing and other public health measures.

Theaters or performance venues at which motion pictures are shown or live performances are held may reopen or remain open, so long as they comply with social distancing, hygiene, and other public health measures.
Race tracks may reopen so long as social distancing and other public health measures are followed.

policy_subtarget: Churches/places of worship; Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Social, community, recreational, leisure, religious, or sporting gathering or event, of more than 10 people may be held but only if it complies with social distancing and other public health measures.

Fitness centers, health clubs, health spas or gyms may reopen or remain open so long as social distancing is followed, hygiene and public health measures are followed, and group activities are limited.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Higher education
policy_description: A brick-and-mortar school district or accredited nonpublic school is still authorized to provide instruction primarily through remote learning opportunities only if there is parental consent, the Iowa Department of Education approves a temporary building or district closure, the school chooses to move online due to public health conditions, there is inclement weather, or there is damage caused by derecho natural disaster.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: All vulnerable Iowans are encouraged to limit their activities outside of their home, including their visits to businesses and other establishments and their participation in gatherings of any size and any purpose. All Iowans are also encouraged to limit their in-person interactions with vulnerable Iowans.
Require hospitals, assisted living programs to screen staff for symptoms

Casinos or other facilities conducting pari-mutuel wagering or gaming operations can remain open as long as they follow social distancing and other hygiene and public health measures, and follow restrictions of bars and restaurants.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Senior citizen centers and adult daycare facilities may reopen.

Salons, barbershops, bowling alleys, bingo halls, arcades, medical spas, theaters and performance venues, malls, and other establishments may remain open or reopen so long as they follow social distancing guidelines.

There may be gatherings of more than 10 people only if social distancing can be maintained and if groups attending are no larger than 8 people unless they are all from the same household. This includes sporting and recreational activities, wedding receptions, and spiritual and religious gatherings.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Higher education
policy_description: A brick-and-mortar school district or accredited nonpublic school is still authorized to provide instruction primarily through remote learning opportunities only if there is parental consent, the Iowa Department of Education approves a temporary building or district closure, the school chooses to move online due to public health conditions, there is inclement weather, or there is damage caused by derecho natural disaster.

All state agencies, school districts, and other local governmental bodies must take all efforts to prepare to safely welcome back students and teachers to school in-person this fall.

Fitness centers, health clubs, health spas or gyms may reopen or remain open so long as social distancing is followed, hygiene and public health measures are followed, and group activities are limited.

Restaurants and bars, including wedding reception venues, wineries, breweries, distilleries, country clubs, or other social or fraternal clubs, may reopen or remain opened so long as they follow social distancing guidelines and other hygiene and public health measures.

All Iowans are encouraged to avoid events that do not adhere to social distancing and mask recommendations, such as weddings, funerals, bridal showers, baby showers, birthday parties, holiday celebrations, conventions, indoor entertainment, spectator sports, private parties, tailgating, and vacationing.
Employers must take steps to ensure that as many employees who can work at home work remotely. Businesses may reopen only if social distancing can be maintained and employees are protected.

All Iowans are also encouraged to limit their in-person interactions with vulnerable Iowans.

policy_description: Sporting events, except for high school, collegiate, or professional sporting is prohibited. This includes youth sports and adult group sports, including swimming lessons, dance, gymnastics, etc.. At high school sports, there may be no more than 2 spectators permitted per athlete, and they must be socially distant.

Indoor gatherings of more than 15 people are prohibited as are outdoor gatherings of more than 30 people.
Religious gatherings shall implement reasonable measures to ensure social distancing, increased hygiene practices, and other public health measures to reduce the risk of transmission of COVID-19.

Fitness centers, health clubs, health spas, or gyms may reopen or remain open as long as social distancing is maintained, any group activities are limited, and other hygiene and public health measures are implemented.

The Kansas statehouse will limit access to only individuals conducting official business, beginning March 16.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; General population (inclusive); Minors and children
policy_description: Face coverings are to be worn by all staff, students, and visitors in K-12 schools (exceptions listed in the order).

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; General population (inclusive); Minors and children
policy_description: All individuals entering K-12 schools shall have their temperature checked before entering the building for the first time each day.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; General population (inclusive); Minors and children
policy_description: All individuals in K-12 schools shall maintain 6 feet of social distancing. This does not apply to classroom instruction when masks are worn.

This executive order outlines disease mitigation measures for K-12 schools in Kansas for the upcoming school year. These mandatory measures include face coverings (with outlined exceptions), 6 feet of social distancing, hand sanitizer in every room (with student and faculty use no less than once every hour), and temperature checks upon building entry.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; General population (inclusive); Minors and children
policy_description: Hand sanitizer must be made available in all K-12 classrooms and other areas of school facilities. Students and faculty to sanitize their hands once per hour.
Government offices will be closed to in-person services beginning March 17.
All mass gatherings are prohibited.
Mass gatherings continue to be limited to under 10 people
All businesses that are not life-sustaining will cease operations on Thursday March 26. The order prohibits in-person work that is unnecessary to protect or sustain life.
Governor Beshear expanded a recent order restricting travel to include people from out of state, who must quarantine for 14 days when arriving in Kentucky.
The Natural Bridge and Cumberland Falls state resort parks have been ordered closed
Phase 1: Manufacturing, construction, vehicle and vessel dealerships, professional services (at 50% of pre-outbreak capacity), horse racing (without spectators), pet grooming and boarding may restart

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Churches/places of worship
policy_description: Phase 1: Retail, houses of worship may restart, but in-person solicitation are prohibited
Phase 1: Social gatherings of no more than 10 people are allowed.
Phase 1: Barbers, salons, cosmetology businesses and similar services may restart
Phase 2: Restaurants may reopen with limited 33% capacity and outdoor seating
Phase 2: Movie theaters, fitness centers may reopen
Phase 2: Campgrounds, public and private may reopen
Phase 2: Child care, with reduced capacity; and potentially low-touch and outdoor youth sports, may reopen

Not life-sustaining businesses are permitted to reopen. Namely, manufacturing, distribution, and supply chain businesses, vehicle and vessel dealerships, horse racing tracks, pet care, grooming and boarding businesses, photography businesses, office-based businesses
Groups of 10 people or fewer may gather

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: Open Kentucky State resort parks, recreational parks, lodges and cabins to the public for normal business hours
Businesses that are opening May 22 at 33% capacity can expand to 50% capacity a month later, on June 22, if they meet the guidelines.
Bars, gatherings with 50 people or fewer and venues that hold 50 people or fewer can reopen June 29 if they meet guidelines
People can begin gathering in groups of 50 or fewer people, including at restaurants, bars, and other venues.

Cabinet for Health and Family Services Secretary Eric Friedlander announced that starting Monday, June 29, the state will resume visitation at assisted living and personal care homes, group activities (10 or fewer) in facilities, communal dining and off-site appointments
Limits gatherings to 10 people or fewer
Both bars and restaurants can operate at 50% of capacity, as long as people can remain six feet from anyone who is not in their household or group
Schools should wait to begin in-person classes until Sept. 28
Second, bars and restaurants will be required to halt food and beverage service by 10 p.m. and close at 11 p.m. local time.
Kentuckians concerned about contracting or spreading COVID-19 can vote via absentee ballot
State Board of Elections shall promulgate emergency regulations providing that voters who are unable to obtain photographic identification because of COVID-19 are able to vote
Restaurants and bars will be allowed to have last call at 11 p.m. and close at midnight
Schools may open in-person learning, provided they use a new online portal to self-report COVID-19 data from Monday through Friday for all days that school is in session.

policy_subtarget: Restaurants/bars; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: All indoor dining at restaurants and bars is prohibited. Delivery of food or carry-out is strongly encouraged. Outdoor dining with a maximum of 8 people per table is allowed, as long as only 2 households are represented. All indoor gatherings are limited to a maximum of 8 people and 2 households. Gyms and fitness centers must reduce indoor capacity to 33% of maximum occupancy. Indoor group activities are prohibited. Indoor venues and theaters are restricted to have audiences of no more than 25 people. Professional must ask all employees who are able to work from home do so and ensure that no more than 33% of employees are physically present in the office any given day.

All public and private elementary, middle, and high schools must cease in-person instruction and transition to virtual or remote learning between November 23. Middle and high schools must remain so until January 4, 2021, but elementary schools may offer in-person classes if the school is not in a Red Zone county and they follow all KDE Healthy at School guidelines.
The April 4 2020 election have been rescheduled to June 20 2020
The May 9 2020 election have been rescheduled to  July 25 2020

Mandates that all nursing facilities implement CMS Guidance for Infection Control and Prevention of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) in Nursing Homes, as Revised March 13, 2020. This includes the restriction of visitation of all visitors and non-essential health care personnel.
Lousiana's presidential primary elections are now rescheduled from June 20 2020 to July 11 2020 (it was originally March 13). The July 25 2020 election has been rescheduled for August 15 2020.
Extends closure of ADC/ADHC/PACE providers.

Extends mandate that all nursing facilities implement CMS Guidance for Infection Control and Prevention of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) in Nursing Homes, as Revised March 13, 2020. This includes the restriction of visitation of all visitors and non-essential health care personnel.
intended_duration: until further notice from the State Health Officer

policy_description: Extends closure of ADC/ADHC/PACE facilities.
intended_duration: until further notice from the State Health Officer

policy_description: Tanning facilities may re-open for the limited purpose of touchless/contactless tanning methods, provided that they adhere to the Office of the State Fire Marshall's Open Safely Phase I guidelines for Beauty Shops, Salons, Barber Shops, or Tanning Salons (Contact Tanning Only).
intended_duration: until further notice from the State Health Officer

policy_subtarget: Personal care facilities; Casinos/gambling facilities; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Retail stores (not including food); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Beauty shops, salons, barber shops, shopping malls, faith-based organizations, casinos, fitness centers, and all other businesses may operate at 50% total occupancy. Outdoor services at faith-based organizations may continue.
Bars without an approved food service permit from the LDH may reopen, but cannot exceed 25% of total occupancy.
Essential businesses may remain in full operation; employees must maintain social distancing between themselves and members of the public.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Places of public amusement will remain closed to the public, unless a reopening plan is submitted to and approved by the State Fire Marshal.

Restaurants, cafes, and coffee shops may continue drive-up or curb-side delivery service; restaurants, cafes, coffee shops, and bars with an approved food service permit may begin dine-in service at 50% capacity.
Extends closure of public schools.

Mass gathering limit of no more than 250 people for large indoor gatherings where strict social distancing cannot be maintained. People should avoid gatherings where social distancing cannot be practiced.
Bars may not allow on premises consumption of food or drinks. Take out is permitted through drive-thru or curbside delivery.
Limits indoor gatherings to no more than 50 people. Limits outdoor gatherings where strict social distancing cannot be maintained to no more than 50 people.

Extends order that restaurants, cafes, and coffee shops may continue drive-up or curb-side delivery service. Dine-in service is permitted at 50% capacity. Waiting areas must be closed, as well as buffets or common food stations.

policy_description: Extends order that places of public amusement will remain closed to the public, unless a reopening plan is submitted to and approved by the State Fire Marshal.

Extends order that all other businesses or organizations may continue operations.
Extends order that churches and other faith-based organizations may operate. Outdoor services may continue.
Gyms and fitness centers may not exceed 50% capacity. Waiting rooms, lobbies, or other areas where members of the public may congregate must be closed to the public.

Extends order that beauty shops, salons, and barber shops may operate.

All other businesses and organizations may not exceed 50% capacity. Waiting rooms, lobbies, and other areas where members of the public may congregate must be closed to the public.
Indoor funeral services are limited to 50% capacity.

Casinos, racetracks, and video poker establishments may not exceed 50% capacity. No more than 75% of gaming positions may be in use at any time. All gaming positions must be at least 6 feet apart or separated by physical barriers. All establishments must have approved reopening plans from the Louisiana Gaming Control Board or the Louisiana Racing Commission. Lobbies or other areas where members of the public may congregate must be closed to the public.
Beauty shops, salons, and barber shops may not exceed 50% capacity. Waiting areas must be closed.

Bars may provide takeout through drive-thru or curbside delivery, including alcoholic beverages.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Encourages those at risk of more severe illness from COVID-19 to stay at home.
All restaurants and cafes are allowed to continue drive-up or curbside delivery.
Funeral directors are considered essential workers in order to obtain access to PPE. Directed to cremate COVID-19 positive decedents within 5 days, if practical.
Gyms and workout facilities may reopen if:  - they are at 75% capacity - all waiting rooms and lobbies are closd - they follow sanitation guidance
Churches/places of worship may reopen if:  - they are below 75% capacity (while social distancing between households) - they follow all Fire Marshal guidelines - they follow all sanitation guidelines
Places of public amusement must remain closed until they submit a plan of reopening to the State Fire Marshal.
Shopping malls may reopen if:  - they are below 75% capacity (including workers) - their food stores follow all restaurant guidelines - they follow all sanitation guidelines

Restaurants and cafes are allowed to open for dine-in services if: - they do not exceed 75% occupancy - waiting areas remain closed - buffets and self-service remain closed - they follow Dept of Health's sanitation guide
Event centers and reception halls may reopen if: - under 50% capacity - waiting rooms, lobbies are closed - they follow all sanitation guidelines  - no selling alcoholic beverages after 10pm
Crowd sizes limited to less than 50% (with a maximum of 250 people)

All other businesses or organizations may open if: - under 75% capacity - waiting rooms, lobbies are closed - they follow all sanitation guidelines  - no selling alcoholic beverages after 10pm
Indoor funeral services are limited to 75% capacity.

Allows bars to open if: - they are in a county with less than 5% for 2 weeks (and will be shut down if they are at 10% or more for 2 weeks) - they have under 25% occupancy or 50 people - all patrons remain seated and socially distanced - they close by 11pm
Allows higher education to substitute in-person and clinical/lab courses for online learning.
Suspends requirements for daily exercise/play time, vision and hearing tests, etc. for schoolchildren, and reserves emergency rules for Board of Elementary and Secondary Education.
Alcoholic beverages shall only be sold from 8 to 11pm
Orders nursing homes and assisted living facilities to implement CMS guidance on documenting visitation. Homes have the right to institute stricter measures as they see fit.

Shopping malls may reopen if: - they are below 75% capacity (including workers) - their food stores follow all restaurant guidelines - they follow all sanitation guidelines

Restaurants and cafes are allowed to open for dine-in services if: - they do not exceed 75% occupancy - waiting areas remain closed - buffets and self-service remain closed - they follow Dept of Health's sanitation guide - sale of alcoholic beverages only between 8am and 11pm
All other businesses or organizations may open if: - under 75% capacity - waiting rooms, lobbies are closed - they follow all sanitation guidelines  - no selling alcoholic beverages after 11pm
