policy_description: For all other businesses, crowd sizes limited to less than 50% (with a maximum of 250 people)
Gyms and workout facilities may reopen if: - they are at 75% capacity - all waiting rooms and lobbies are closed - they follow sanitation guidance

Churches/places of worship may reopen if: - they are below 75% capacity (while social distancing between households) - they follow all Fire Marshal guidelines - they follow all sanitation guidelines  Outdoor services may continue. Not limited by crowd size restrictions

Casinos/gambling facilities/video poker establishments may reopen if: - they are at 50% capacity - no more than 75% of total gaming used at one time  - all lobbies and public areas are closed. - they submit a reopening plan to be approved by the Racing Commission - no sale of alcoholic beverages after 11pm
Beauty shops, salons, and barbers are allowed to open if: - they are under 75% capacity - waiting areas are closed - they follow the sanitation guidelines"

Bars may open if: - they are in a parish with <5% case positivity rate - do not exceed 25% of total occupancy - must be seated and socially distanced - outdoor seating at maximum 50 people - all bars must close at 11pm

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Higher risk individuals should stay home unless traveling for an essential reason

All places of public amusement (arcades, parks, fairs and festivals, concert and music halls) must close.  They may petition the state Fire Marshal for reopening, but cannot reopen at more than 50% capacity.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Secondary education; Primary education
policy_description: Allows elementary and secondary school athletic events to open up to 50% if <5% case positivity rate - if case positivity >10% for 2 weeks, must return to 25%  Otherwise same rules: - limited alcohol sales  - must wear face masks, social distance, etc

Allows elementary and secondary school athletic events to open up to 50% if <5% case positivity rate - if case positivity >10% for 2 weeks, must return to 25%  Otherwise same rules: - limited alcohol sales  - must wear face masks, social distance, etc

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Individuals who are at higher risk of severe illness should stay at home unless for an essential activity.

Churches/places of worship may reopen if: - they are below 75% capacity (while social distancing between households) - they follow all Fire Marshal guidelines - they follow all sanitation guidelines  Outdoor services may continue. Not limited by crowd size restrictions

Bars may open if: - they are in a parish with <5% case positivity rate - do not exceed 25% of total occupancy - must be seated and socially distanced - outdoor seating at maximum 50 people - all bars must close at 11pm
Beauty shops, salons, and barbers are allowed to open if: - they are under 50% capacity - waiting areas are closed - they follow the sanitation guidelines"

Casinos/gambling facilities/video poker establishments may reopen if: - they are at 50% capacity - no more than 50% of total gaming used at one time  - all lobbies and public areas are closed. - they submit a reopening plan to be approved by the Racing Commission - no sale of alcoholic beverages after 11pm
Event centers and reception halls may reopen if: - under 25% capacity - waiting rooms, lobbies are closed - they follow all sanitation guidelines  - no selling alcoholic beverages after 11pm

Restaurants and cafes are allowed to open for dine-in services if: - they do not exceed 50% occupancy - waiting areas remain closed - buffets and self-service remain closed - they follow Dept of Health's sanitation guide - sale of alcoholic beverages only between 8am and 11pm

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor spaces
policy_description: For all other businesses, crowd sizes limited to less than 25% (with a maximum of 75 people) in indoor spaces, and <25% (max of 150 people)
All other businesses or organizations may open if: - under 50% capacity - waiting rooms, lobbies are closed - they follow all sanitation guidelines  - no selling alcoholic beverages after 11pm
Gyms and workout facilities may reopen if: - they are at 50% capacity - all waiting rooms and lobbies are closed - they follow sanitation guidance
Shopping malls may reopen if: - they are below 50% capacity (including workers) - their food stores follow all restaurant guidelines - they follow all sanitation guidelines
The primary election has now been moved from June 9 2020 to July 14 2020.
intended_duration: 30 days after the state of emergency

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Churches/places of worship; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: The DECD shall implement the Restarting Plan, granting businesses and activities with adequate restrictions to receive a conditional approval. These include drive in theaters, outdoor recreation, personal services such as hair salons, drive in religious services, and others. Other non-essential  businesses remain closed.
Lodging providers can begin accepting future reservations with an arrival date of June 1 or beyond for Maine residents and non-residents complying with quarantine.

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Retail stores (not including food); Restaurants/bars; Outdoor recreation or space; Hotels/lodging
policy_description: Gyms, all retail, restaurants, lodging (for Maine residents), and certain outdoor recreation can open if they meet the checklist standards of safety precautions put in place by the DECD.
The directives in the previous stay safer at home orders are relaxed to the extent that people may now engage in activities and services authorized by this order (reopening phase 2).
Restrictions on mass gatherings of 50 or more.
Lodging providers can serve out-of-state visitors who meet 14 day quarantine requirement of state testing alternative on June 26 rather than July 1
Postponing indoor bar service from July 1 until further notice
Under stage phase 3 of the reopening plan, spas and skin care establishments, outdoor amusements, indoor amusements, movie theaters, performing arts venues can voluntarily resume on July 1
Created Framework for Returning to Classroom Instruction
Voters may vote in person by absentee ballot without specifying a reason until 5pm on second business day before election day
intended_duration: 30 days after termination of state of emergency

policy_description: limitation on processing absentee ballots up to four days prior to election day is suspended to permit processing up to seven days prior to election
intended_duration: 30 days after termination of state of emergency

policy_description: limit number of people inside polling place to 50
intended_duration: 30 days after termination of state of emergency

policy_description: For establishments that provide and require seating, the indoor limit is 50% of the occupancy limit or 100 persons, whichever is less. For establishments that do not provide and require seating for all invitees, the indoor gathering limit is 50.

Owners and operators of indoor public settings need to display visible signs notifying entrants of the requirement to wear a mask, and may deny service or entry for non-compliance with the Governor's face coverings requirement.
Indoor gathering limit of 50 people.
Quarantine upon arrival in Maine is determined by the recommended quarantine period by the Director of the Maine CDC.
The Maryland Dept of Public Safety and Correctional Services is discontinuing visits for individuals in infirmaries
Visits to correctional facilities is suspended immediately. Free phone calls and video visitation will be provided.
Enables Maryland municipalities to postpone elections.
All Retail Establishments shall designate six-foot spacing for persons waiting in line using signage, tape, or other means.
Authorizes process for release of eligible prisoners through "accelerated parole," "early mandatory supervision," or "expedited home detention."
Self-quarantine for a minimum of 14 days is required immediately upon release on early mandatory supervision, placement in expedited home detention, or accelerated parole.

The permitted outdoor activities on the Stay at Home Order has been expanding to include individual and small group sports, as well as state beaches and parks. Local governments are allowed to take similar actions.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Personal care facilities; Churches/places of worship; Retail stores (not including food); Manufacturers
policy_description: Religious facilities, retail establishments, outdoor recreation, manufacturing facilities, and certain personal care services may reopen if in accordance with mitigation measures and local orders and mitigation measures.
Restaurants, bars, and social clubs may serve food and beverages to customers in outdoor seating areas and/or sell food and beverages for take-out and delivery.
Drive-in movie theaters, outdoor pools, outdoor day camps, and tour boats may reopen.

Restaurants, bars, and social clubs which serve food to customers in outdoor areas shall require all staff to wear Face Coverings in accordance with the Face Coverings Order, ensure patrons are seated at least six feet away from each other (except for households seated together), prohibit groups larger than six persons from being seated together (except members of the same household), not serve food in a buffet format, and clean and disinfect each table between each seating in accordance with CDC and MDH guidelines.
Personal services may resume operations up to 50% capacity
State government will resume normal operations, with requirements of wearing face coverings and other public health measures in place.
Non-essential businesses may now be open. However, localities may issue stricter orders..
Gatherings of 10 or more are prohibited.
Child care providers may begin to reopen.
Indoor dining may now open at 50% capacity and with social distancing. Outdoor amusement may reopen with health measures.
Indoor fitness facilities may open with health measures, as well as casinos, arcades, and malls.
School buildings may begin to reopen.

policy_subtarget: Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Senior centers and theaters must continue to remain closed.
Nursing homes must perform health screenings on all who enter facility.
Safety measures to be taken for the canvassing of ballots from the primary election, which had been postponed from April 28th to June 2nd.

policy_subtarget: Non essential workers (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Staff and owners of facilities that are required to be closed may continue to be on-site for the purposes of facilitating remote working by other staff, maintaining essential property, preventing loss of, or damage to property, including without limitation, preventing spoilage of perishable inventory, performing essential administrative functions, including without limitation, picking up mail and processing payroll, and caring for live animals.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Bingo halls, bowling alleys, pool halls, roller and ice skating rinks, social and fraternal clubs (including without limitation, American Legion posts, VFW posts, and Elks Clubs) may reopen at maximum 50% capacity of the facility in accordance with local orders.
Political subdivisions may reopen outdoor public spaces after consultation with Local Health Officers.
Manufacturing businesses and facilities may reopen in accordance with local orders.

Retail establishments may open to the general public, provided that the total number of persons permitted at any one time shall not exceed 50% of that Retail Establishment’s Maximum Occupancy as defined in the order.
Campgrounds, drive-in movie theaters, outdoor day-camps, amusement parks, outdoor pools, marinas, and golf courses may open to the public in accordance with local orders.

Religious facilities may open to the general public, provided that the total number of persons permitted  at any one time does not exceed 50% of that Religious Facility’s Maximum Occupancy as defined in the order.

Personal care businesses may reopen in accordance with local orders. These businesses include beauty salons, barber shops, tattoo parlors, tanning salons, massage parlors, and establishments that provide esthetic services or provide nail technician services. Service by appointment only.
Retail facilities shall designate with signage, tape, or by other means at least six-foot spacing for persons in line. They shall also post signage regarding face covering requirements.
Fitness centers, health clubs, health spas, gyms, aquatic centers, and self-defense schools may open to the general public. They shall operate at maximum 50% facility capacity.
Food establishments may serve food in both indoor and outdoor seating areas, in accordance with other guidelines.
Termination of 3/15/2020 Order entitled “Closing Casinos, Racetracks, and Simulcast Betting Facilities”.
Select casinos, racetracks, and simulcast betting facilities (listed in the order) may reopen to the public at maximum 50% facility capacity.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Non essential business (inclusive); Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Theaters (including live performance theaters and movie theaters) and senior citizen activity centers are to remain closed.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Private sector; Non essential business (inclusive); Personal care facilities
policy_description: Personal care businesses allowed to re-open may operate at maximum 50% facility capacity and must follow CDC and Maryland DOH sanitation guidelines.

Government buildings and facilities with an expected occupancy or attendance of more than 10 people shall: post in the building or facility a copy of the MDH recommendations for social distancing and provide all occupants and attendees with the capability to wash their hands.

Food establishments may operate at maximum 50% facility capacity for indoor/outdoor seating. Buffet style dining is prohibited. Tables must be disinfected between seatings according to CDC and MDH guidelines.
The State Board of Elections may establish in-person voting centers for the November 3rd General Election. Any eligible voter may vote at a voting center in the voter's county of residence.
Voting centers for the November 3rd General Election shall comply with CDC and Maryland DOH guidelines.
Subject to Local Orders, listed casinos may be open to the public. Listed racetracks may be open racing operations, but not for public attendance.
Subject to Local Orders, fitness centers, health clubs, health spas, gyms, aquatic centers may be open to the public.
Personal Services, including salons, barbers, and tattoo parlors, may be open to the general public.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Listed indoor and outdoor recreation facilities may be open to the public.

Religious facilities in Maryland may be open to the general public, subject to local orders, provided that the total number of persons permitted in a Religious Facility at any one time shall not exceed 75% of maximum occupancy.

Restaurants, bars, nightclubs, and other similar establishments that sell food or beverages for consumption on-premises may, to the extent permitted by Local Orders, may serve food indoors and outdoors. These establishments may also serve food for takeout and delivery.
All manufacturing businesses and facilities in Maryland may open.

Retail businesses, organizations, establishments, and facilities may be open to the general public provided that the total number of persons permitted in a Retail Establishment at any one time shall not exceed 75% of maximum occupancy.
Subject to Local Orders, indoor and outdoor theaters for live performances or motion pictures may be open to the public.

The total number of persons permitted in an Indoor Theater (per individual auditorium or performance stage) shall not exceed 50% of that Indoor Theater’s maximum occupancy or 100 persons. The total number of persons permitted in an Outdoor Entertainment Venue shall not exceed 50% of that Outdoor Entertainment Venue’s maximum occupancy or 250 persons.
The total number of persons permitted in a Gaming Facility at any one time shall not exceed 50% of the facility's maximum occupancy.

State and local government buildings and facilities with an expected occupancy or attendance of more than 10 people shall: i. Promptly and conspicuously post in the building or facility a copy of the MDH recommendations for social distancing; and ii. Provide all occupants and attendees with the capability to wash their hands.

All retail establishments shall designate with signage, tape, or by other means at least six-foot spacing for persons in line. Retail establishments must also post signage at each entrance advising customers about the requirement to wear face coverings. Retail establishments must also  provide staff and customers with a means to sanitize hands as well as carts and basket handles.

Food service establishments shall not allow the number of persons in the establishment to exceed 50% of maximum capacity. These establishments shall not serve food in buffet style, nor shall they serve food to patrons who are not seated. The establishments shall clean and disinfect each table between each seating in accordance with CDC and MDH guidelines
Fitness centers, gyms, health spas, and aquatic centers must limit the number of people in their facilities to 50% of maximum capacity.
Indoor recreation facilities must limit occupancy to 50% of maximum occupancy.

Personal Service establishments, including salons, barbers, tattoo parlors, must limit the occupancy of the establishments to 50% of maximum capacity. Service must be provided by appointment only. Disinfection measures must be implemented according to CDC and MDH guidelines.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: All senior citizen activities centers shall remain closed.

State Board of Elections may establish, as alternate voting locations or systems, voting centers for the use of any eligible voters who would like to cast a ballot for the November 3 general election in person. CDC and Maryland DOH guidelines for voting shall be complied with to the maximum extent possible
Outdoor sporting events may open to the public with restrictions on capacity.

Outdoor entertainment venues with a maximum capacity of 2500 persons or less shall operate at no more than 50% capacity or 250 persons. Outdoor entertainment venues with a maximum capacity larger than 2500 shall operate at no more than 10% of capacity.

Personal care businesses may reopen in accordance with local orders. These businesses include beauty salons, barber shops, tattoo parlors, tanning salons, massage parlors, and establishments that provide esthetic services or provide nail technician services.
Outdoor entertainment venues are permitted to open to the public with restrictions, subject to local orders.
All manufacturing facilities are permitted to open, subject to local orders.

Retail facilities shall designate with signage, tape, or by other means at least six-foot spacing for persons in line. They shall also post signage regarding face covering requirements. Restrooms stocked with with soap must be provided to staff and customers. High-touch surfaces such as carts and baskets must be sanitized.

Government buildings with an expected occupancy of 10 or more persons shall post signage with Maryland Department of Health recommendations for social distancing and provide a means for all occupants to wash their hands.

Gaming facilities shall not exceed 50% of maximum capacity. The number of spectators in an indoor area of a racing facility shall not exceed 50% capacity nor 250 people. Outdoor areas of racing facilities shall not exceed 10% of the areas maximum capacity.
Casinos and racing facilities are permitted to open to the public with restrictions, subject to local orders.
Indoor and outdoor theaters may open to the public with restrictions, subject to local orders.

Outdoor entertainment and outdoor sporting venues with a maximum capacity of 2500 persons or less shall operate at no more than 50% capacity or 250 persons. Outdoor entertainment and outdoor sporting venues with a maximum capacity larger than 2500 shall operate at no more than 10% of capacity.
Outdoor sporting events may open to the public with restrictions on capacity.
Indoor theaters may not exceed 50% capacity nor 100 persons.

Retail establishments may open to the general public, subject to local orders, provided that the total number of persons permitted at any one time shall not exceed 75% of that Retail Establishment’s Maximum Occupancy as defined in the order.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Senior centers must remain closed.
Fitness centers are permitted to open to the public with restrictions, subject to local orders.
Various indoor recreation facilities may open to the public at 50% capacity, subject to local orders, including bingo halls, bowling alleys, roller and ice skating rinks, and social clubs.
Food service establishments are permitted to open for indoor and outdoor dining with restrictions, subject to local orders.
Personal care businesses may provide services by appointment only. Facilities must remain under 50% of maximum capacity, and surfaces must be sanitized between clients.
Various outdoor recreational facilities may open to the public, subject to local orders, including golf courses, swimming pools, drive-in movie theaters, amusement parks, campgrounds, and marinas.

Religious facilities in Maryland may be open to the general public, subject to local orders, provided that the total number of persons permitted in a Religious Facility at any one time shall not exceed 75% of maximum occupancy.
Fitness centers may not exceed 50% of maximum capacity.
Indoor dining capacity reduced from 75% to 50% of maximum capacity. Buffet service and is prohibited. Customers must be seated to be served. Tables must be disinfected between seatings.

Nursing homes shall screen all persons who enter the facility (including volunteers, vendors, and visitors when permitted) for signs and symptoms of COVID-19, including temperature checks. Facilities shall refuse entrance to anyone screening positive for symptoms of COVID-19.
Nursing homes must follow CDC, CMS, and Maryland Department of Health guidelines.
Authorizes process for release of eligible prisoners through "accelerated parole," "early mandatory supervision," or "expedited home detention."
Indoor theaters may not exceed 50% capacity nor 100 persons.

Government buildings with an expected occupancy of 10 or more persons shall post signage with Maryland Department of Health recommendations for social distancing and provide a means for all occupants to wash their hands.
Various outdoor recreational facilities may open to the public, subject to local orders, including golf courses, swimming pools, drive-in movie theaters, amusement parks, campgrounds, and marinas.
All manufacturing facilities are permitted to open, subject to local orders.
Fitness centers are permitted to open to the public with restrictions, subject to local orders.
Personal care businesses may provide services by appointment only. Facilities must remain under 50% of maximum capacity, and surfaces must be sanitized between clients.
Outdoor entertainment venues for which entrance is limited to ticketed customers may open to the public with restrictions, subject to local orders.
Casinos and racing facilities are permitted to open to the public with restrictions, subject to local orders.
Gaming facilities shall not exceed 50% of maximum capacity.

Retail facilities shall designate with signage, tape, or by other means at least six-foot spacing for persons in line. They shall also post signage regarding face covering requirements. Restrooms stocked with with soap must be provided to staff and customers. High-touch surfaces such as carts and baskets must be sanitized.
Indoor theaters may open to the public with restrictions, subject to local orders.
Food service establishments are permitted to open for indoor and outdoor dining with restrictions, subject to local orders.

Personal care businesses may reopen in accordance with local orders. These businesses include beauty salons, barber shops, tattoo parlors, tanning salons, massage parlors, and establishments that provide esthetic services or provide nail technician services.
Fitness centers may not exceed 50% of maximum capacity.
Various indoor recreation facilities may open to the public, subject to local orders, at 50% capacity including bingo halls, bowling alleys, roller and ice skating rinks, and social clubs.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Senior centers must remain closed.

All visitors must have proof of a negative COVID-19 test result within 72 hours prior to their visit. If the facility is currently in outbreak status, then indoor visitation shall be suspended except for cases of compassionate care. Each facility may determine on an individual basis requests for compassionate care visitation.
Self-quarantine for a minimum of 14 days is required immediately upon release on early mandatory supervision, placement in expedited home detention, or accelerated parole.
Retail facilities may remain open to the public. Capacity permitted at retail facilities reduced from 75% to 50% of maximum capacity.
All bars, restaurants, and venues serving food and alcohol must close between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m., except for the purposes of carryout and delivery.

No fans or crowds are permitted at racetracks or professional and collegiate stadiums across the state. The governor’s order reverts back to the previous order allowing no more than 250 non-spectators onsite.
Religious facilities may remain open to the public. Capacity at religious facilities now reduced from 75% to 50% of maximum capacity.
Outdoor entertainment and outdoor sporting venues may not exceed 50% of maximum capacity nor 250 persons.

The Baker-Polito Administration modified the state's open meeting law to allow state, quasi and local governments to continue essential functions. It suspends the requirement for public access to the physical location where a public meeting is taking place, provided there are other means of access available.

The Baker-Polito Administration released policies restricting visitors to nursing homes. Visitors who are sick, have been in contact with anyone who tested positive for COVID-19 or traveled internationally in the last 14 days.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Grocery store
policy_description: Grocery stores must provide an hour of shopping for adults over 60 years old.
Beginning March 27, all travelers arriving to Ma are instructed to self quarantine for 14 days.
Groceries are required to limit occupancy to 40% of their maximum occupancy.
A "Safer at Home" Advisory will replace the Stay at Home advisory, meaning that everyone stay home unless they are headed to a newly opened facility or activity.
A Phase II enterprise that is authorized to open its premises  will not be subject to the 10-person limitation on gatherings. However, they must comply with COVID-19 workplace safety rules.
intended_duration: Until rescinded or until the state of emergency is ended

policy_description: Programs for contact sports must limit activities exclusively to no-contact drills and practices. Games scrimmages, and tournaments are not permitted. There cannot be groups of more than 10 participants, including coaches and staff. Indoor athletic facilities can open for exclusive use of supervised sports programs.
intended_duration: Until rescinded or until the state of emergency is ended

policy_description: Restaurants will be allowed to provide outdoor table service at the start of Phase II.
intended_duration: Until rescinded or November 1, whichever comes first

policy_description: Businesses and other organization that are included within Phase II of the re-opening plan may open workplaces and facilities to workers for the purpose of preparing for a Phase II re-opening when authorized. Phase II enterprises may not open their premises to customers and the public generally until authorized to do so by subsequent Order.
intended_duration: Until rescinded or until the state of emergency is ended

policy_description: Organizers of sports activities and programs for youths and adults and facilities that host such programs or activities may open their premises to employees to begin preparations, consistent with the provisions of Section 1, for authorized Phase II activities. This pertains to amateur sports.
intended_duration: Until rescinded or until the state of emergency is ended

policy_description: Any licensed, approved, or exempt child care program that was closed by COVID-19 Order No. 10 may open its physical workplaces and facilities to workers for the purpose of preparing for opening when authorized.
intended_duration: Until rescinded or until the state of emergency is ended

policy_description: Professional sports organizations may open premises to employees and other workers for the activities provided in section 1 and may also open to employees for on-premises athletic practices/training. Professionals sports organizations may not engage in inter-team games within Commonwealth.
intended_duration: Until rescinded or until the state of emergency is ended

policy_description: Businesses and other organizations that are Phase II enterprises are permitted to open and operate their physical workplaces to workers, customers, and the public under the two-step schedule.
intended_duration: Until rescinded or until the state of emergency is ended

policy_description: Any person who has reached or will reach their 16th birthday between March 1, 2020 and June 30, 2020 can, upon or following their birthday and the successful completion of an online learner's permit examination, operate a Class D motor vehicle for up to 90 days within the Commonwealth.
Childcare Programs can open, if they meet the necessary safety standards.

All travelers arriving to Massachusetts, including Massachusetts residents returning home, are instructed to self-quarantine for 14 days, except that, beginning July 1, 2020, travelers from Rhode Island, Connecticut, Vermont, New Hampshire, Maine, New York, and New Jersey arriving in Massachusetts are exempt from this directive and need not self-quarantine for 14 days.
Workers designated by the federal government as essential critical infrastructure workers are exempt from the directive to self-quarantine for 14 days if traveling to Massachusetts for work purposes.
The Massachusetts Gaming Commission, with consultation of with the Department of Public Health, may amend COVID-19 safety rules for the operation of all casinos, race tracks, and related facilities.
intended_duration: Until rescinded or until the state of emergency is ended

policy_description: Professional sports organizations can have organized games, tournaments, and other competitions within the Commonwealth, if they have adopted COVID-19 approved safety measures. No spectators are allowed to attend.
intended_duration: Until rescinded or until the state of emergency is ended

policy_description: Indoor gatherings are limited to 8 people per 1,000 sq. feet. and never more than 25 people. Outdoor gatherings in enclosed spaces are limited to 25% of the maximum capacity. Outdoor gatherings in unenclosed spaces are not limited to the same limitations but may also not have recreational or festival gatherings. Different restrictions apply to businesses.
intended_duration: Until rescinded or until the state of emergency is ended

policy_description: Day programs overseen by agencies under the Executive Office of Health and Human Services may provide services in a congregate settings, if they have met EOHHS safety requirements.
intended_duration: Until rescinded or until the state of emergency is ended

policy_description: Indoor gatherings are limited to eight people per 1,000 square feet, but should not exceed 25 people in a single enclosed, indoor space. Outdoor gatherings in enclosed spaces are limited to 25 percent of the facility’s maximum permitted occupancy, with a maximum of 100 people in a single enclosed outdoor space.

All visitors and Massachusetts residents returning home, including students returning to campuses, must fill out a “Massachusetts Travel Form” and quarantine for 14 days unless they are coming from a COVID-19 lower risk state or they can produce a negative COVID-19 test result administered no more than 72 hours prior to arriving in Massachusetts
Indoor gatherings are limited to 8 persons per 1,000 square feet of accessible, indoor floor space, and never more than 25 persons in a single enclosed indoor space.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Outdoor gatherings are limited to 25% of the maximum permitted occupancy of the facility. If there is no occupancy limitation on record, there can never be more than 50 people in a gathering in a single outdoor space. Outdoor gatherings for the purpose of political expression or religious activities are not subject to these outdoor limitations.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: All participants in indoor and outdoor gatherings must maintain at least 6 feet of physical distance from every other participant in the gathering aside from participant who are members of the same household.

policy_subtarget: Indoor spaces; Outdoor recreation or space; Private sector; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: With the exception of events and gatherings subject to the Indoor and Outdoor Events Guidance issued by the Department of Labor Standards, any Phase I, II, and III enterprise shall not be subject to the limitations of this Order if this enterprise is operating in compliance with applicable sector-specific COVID-19 safety rules and any applicable capacity limitations issued under the authority of an executive order.

policy_subtarget: Indoor spaces; Outdoor recreation or space; Private sector; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Churches/places of worship
policy_description: Gatherings for religious activities shall not be subject to the limitations of this Order; provided, however, that such gatherings shall follow the COVID-19 safety rules and capacity limitations set forth in the Places of Worship sector-specific rules. Outdoor gatherings for the purpose of political expression shall also not be subject to the Order's limitations. Indoor gatherings for the purposes of political expression must follow the indoor capacity limitations.
Outdoor gatherings at private residences and in private backyards and at any other venue or location not included in tis Order are limited to 50 people.

policy_subtarget: Indoor spaces; Outdoor recreation or space; Private sector; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: All participants in indoor and outdoor gatherings, including gatherings at private residences, must maintain at least 6 feet of physical distance from every other participant in the gathering except where participants are members of the same household. A gathering shall violate this provision where, no matter the number of participants present, conditions or activities at the gatherings are such that is not reasonably possible for all participants to maintain a degree of separation.

policy_subtarget: Indoor spaces; Outdoor recreation or space; Private sector; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: All indoor and outdoor events shall be required to comply with both the limitations and requirements of this Order and sector-specific safety rules for Indoor and Outdoor Events, except if gathering or event is exempt from this Order.

policy_subtarget: Indoor spaces; Outdoor recreation or space; Private sector; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Indoor and outdoor gatherings, as well as indoor gatherings for the purposes of political expression, must follow the indoor capacity limitations. Workers and staff shall not count towards limitations set forth by the Order.

The capacity limitation apply to outdoor gatherings held in settings open to the public and at event venues, clubs, parks, and other outdoor venues or spaces, public or private, that are regularly used or available for gatherings through lease, license, permit, contract, reservation, or similar arrangement. In communities that do not qualify as Lower Risk Communities, gatherings at event venues and in public settings are limited to a maximum of 50 persons in a single venue or space.
All indoor gatherings are limited to 25 persons in a single enclosed, indoor space.

The capacity limitation apply to outdoor gatherings held in settings open to the public and at event venues, clubs, parks, and other outdoor venues or spaces, public or private, that are regularly used or available for gatherings through lease, license, permit, contract, reservation, or similar arrangement. In Lower Risk Communities, gatherings at event venues and in public settings are limited to a maximum of 100 persons in a single venue or space.

Gatherings for religious activities shall not be subject to the limitations of this Order; provided, however, that such gatherings shall follow COVID-19 safety rules and capacity limitations set forth in the Places of Worship sector-specific rules. Outdoor gatherings for the purpose of political expression shall not be subject to these restrictions, but indoor gatherings for the purpose of political expression will be subject.

policy_subtarget: Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: With the exception of events and gatherings subject to the Indoor and Outdoor Events Guidance issued by the Department of Labor Standards, any Phase I, II, or III enterprise shall not be subjected to the limitations of this Order if the enterprise is operating in compliance with applicable sector-specific COVID-19 safety rules and any applicable capacity limitations issued by a regulating agency under the authority of an executive order.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Outdoor gatherings at event venues or in public settings, in Lower Risk Communities, are limited to a maximum of 100 persons in a single venue or space. In communities that do not qualify as Lower Risk Communities, gatherings are limited to a maximum of 50 persons in a single venue or space.
Indoor gatherings at event venues or in public settings are limited to a maximum of 25 people.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor spaces
policy_description: In addition to the capacity restrictions, all participants in indoor and outdoor gatherings, including gatherings at private residences, must maintain at least 6 feet of physical distance from every other participant in the gathering, except where participants are members of the same household. A gathering will violate this provision where, no matter the number of participants present, conditions or activities at the gathering are such that it is not reasonably possible for all participants to maintain this degree of separation.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: For outdoor gatherings in Lower Risk Communities where more than 50 attendees are anticipated, the operator of the event venue shall provide notice to the Local Board of Health in the municipality where the gathering is located at least 1 week before the event is scheduled, or otherwise as soon as possible where 1 week noticed is not practicable due to the nature of the event (e.g. memorial services). For events held in public places like parks where more than 50 attendees are anticipated, the event organizer shall be responsible for providing this notice. The notification shall include, at minimum, the location and time of the planned event, the name, and contact information of the event organizer, the number of anticipated attendees, and any other information reasonably requested by the Local Board Health.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Indoor spaces; Outdoor recreation or space; Churches/places of worship
policy_description: All gatherings, no matter size or location, must end and participants must disperse by 9:30 pm, with the exceptions of religious gatherings and political.
Indoor gatherings at private residences and in any other place not falling within the definition of an event venue or public setting are limited to a maximum of 10 people.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Outdoor gatherings at private residences and in any other place not falling within the definition of an event venue or public setting are limited to a maximum of 25 people.

Enterprises in municipalities that qualify as "Lower Risk Communities" may operate according to rules applicable to Step 2 of Phase III of the Commonwealth's phased Re-Opening Plan. Enterprises in municipalities that do not qualify as Lower Risk Communities must comply with rules applicable to Step 1 of Phase III. For the purposes of this Order, a "Lower Risk Community" shall mean a municipality that meets criteria established by the Commissioner of the Department of Public Health as published on the Massachusetts COVID-19 response website (the "Lower Risk metric"). The Commissioner may from time to time publish adjustments to the metric as warranted by changes in the available public health data and the developing of the nature of COVID-19 virus.

Within a municipality determined to be a Lower Risk Community and authorized to advance to or remain in Step 2 of Phase III: Businesses and other organizations identified as Phase III, Step 2 enterprises in Schedule A may open their brick and mortar premises to workers, customers and the public.

Phase I, II, and III enterprises, as identified in Schedule A, may not operate pursuant to revised Sector-Specific COVID-19 workplace safety rules providing for increased capacity and other adjustments applicable to enterprises operating under Step 2 of Phase III.
Indoor gatherings at event venues or in public settings are limited to a maximum of 25 people.
Indoor gatherings at private residences and in any other place not falling within the definition of an event venue or public setting are limited to a maximum of 10 people.

policy_subtarget: Indoor spaces; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: This order is includes all indoor and outdoor events, conferences, conventions, fundraisers, and other similar events or assemblies. In addition to capacity restrictions, all participants in indoor and outdoor gatherings, including gatherings at private residences, must maintain at least 6 feet of physical distance from every other participant in the gathering, except where participants are members of the same household. A gathering shall violate this provision where, no matter the number of participants present, conditions or activities at the gathering are such that it is not reasonably possible for all participants to maintain this degree of separation. Religious activities and outdoor political gatherings are not restricted to these limitations.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Private sector
policy_description: All gatherings, no matter the size or location, must end and participants must disperse by 9:30 pm, with the exceptions of religious gatherings and political gatherings.
Outdoor gatherings at event venues or in public settings are limited to a maximum of 50 persons in a single venue or space.
Outdoor gatherings at private residences and in any other place not falling within the definition of an event venue or public setting are limited to a maximum of 25 people.
Elections on May 5 should be conducted to the greatest extent possible by absent voter ballots, by providing absentee ballots directly to new registrants.
Low risk jobs such as real estate and construction may return back to work.
Allows laboratory research to resume
Personal care facilities will reopen in regions 6 and 8
Allows for the reopening of salons, movie theaters, and gym in regions 6 and 8

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; General population (inclusive); Private sector; Personal care facilities; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Reopen some private businesses with social distancing guidelines
Lifts restrictions on overnight summer camps

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Allows professional sports to return
Prevents indoor service at bars in regions 1-5 and 7 of Michigan
Requires all businesses and operations to provide any communication and training on COVID-19 in the languages that are common in their employee population.
Implementation of new workplace rules governing meat and poultry processing plants to mitigate the spread of COVID-19
Updates the rules on restaurants and bars to track new safeguards added by Executive Order 2020-143.
Reopens the Detroit casinos, subject to a 15% capacity limit and strict workplace safeguards.
Creates workplace standards for casinos. An amended version of Executive order 2020-114, amended to include casinos.
Closes bars across the state, including in the Traverse City region and the Upper Peninsula.
Indoor gatherings of more than 10 people statewide are prohibited.
The Department must implement specific risk reduction protocols to address COVID-19.

All transfers from jails to prisons are temporarily suspended unless the transferring jail/lockup implements risk reduction protocols and testing protocols (described in sections 2 and 3, respectively).

policy_subtarget: Nursing homes/assisted living facility; Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Criminal justice system/prisons/jails/incarcerated persons; Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist)
policy_description: This extension continues the limited and temporary restrictions on the entry of individuals into health care facilities, residential care facilities, congregate care facilities, and juvenile justice facilities previously imposed by Executive Order 2020-156.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Gym/workout facility/fitness center
policy_description: Outlines strict workplace safety measures that gyms and pools must follow to protect people from the spread of COVID-19.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Gym/workout facility/fitness center
policy_description: Gyms and pools may reopen under strict safety measures. Gyms must require mask wearing at all times, implement protocols to enable six feet of distance between individuals at all times, provide equipment-cleaning products throughout the gym, and more.
Extends health and safety rules for grocery stores and pharmacies to limit the spread of COVID-19. Extension of Executive Order No. 2020-168

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Amends the Safe Start order (Executive Order 2020-176) to clarify that in order to participate in organized sports, athletes must either wear a facial covering or consistently maintain six feet of social distance.

Amendment to the Safe Start order (Executive Order 2020-176): subsection (d) is added to Section 8. Clarifies that indoor social gatherings and organized events among persons not part of the same household remain limited to 10 people or fewer statewide.
Except in Regions 6 and 8, any work capable of being performed remotely (i.e., without the worker leaving his or her home or place of residence) must be performed remotely.
Relaxes the restrictions on attendance at social gatherings and organized events.

Food service establishments must close common areas in which people can congregate and mingle and must close for indoor service if they earn more than 70% of their gross receipts from the sale of alcohol. The Michigan Liquor Control Commission will consider the temporary suspension of liquor licenses.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Sports organizers must set and organize rules to ensure the physical health of all participants. Athletes training for or competing in an organized sport must wear and mask or maintain 6 feet of social distance. Live audiences at sports competitions must be limited to the guests of the athletes with each athlete designating two guests. Outdoor parks and recreational facilities may be open with social distancing modifications.
The Department of Corrections facilities must implement risk reduction protocols.

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Criminal justice system/prisons/jails/incarcerated persons; Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist); Nursing homes/assisted living facility
policy_description: This extension continues the limited and temporary restrictions on the entry of individuals into health care facilities, residential care facilities, congregate care facilities, and juvenile justice facilities previously imposed by Executive Order 2020-174.
All transfers from jails to prisons are temporarily suspended unless the transferring jail or local lockup implements risk reduction protocols outline in section 2 of this order.
Extends health and safety rules for grocery stores and pharmacies to limit the spread of COVID-19. Extension of Executive Order No. 2020-178

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Subject to the exceptions in section 9 of this order, certain entertainment venues and recreation facilities are closed to entry, use, and occupancy by members of the public.

Section 6(b)(1) of Executive Order 2020-183 is amended to provide: in cases where the gathering or event occurs in a venue with fixed seating, limit attendance to 20% of seating capacity (or 25% of seating capacity in Region 6). Section 6(b)(2) is amended to provide: Otherwise, limit attendance to 20 people per 1,000 square feet of venue space, including no more than 20 people per 1,000 square feet of venue space, including no more than 20 people per 1,00 square feet in each room (or 25 people per 1,000 square feet in Region 6).

Section 1 of Executive Order 2020-183 is amended to provide that: Except in region 6, any work capable of being performed remotely (i.e., without the worker leaving his or her home or place of residence) must be performed remotely.

policy_subtarget: Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Manufacturers; Retail stores (not including food); Restaurants/bars; Veterinary clinics; Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist); Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Personal care facilities; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Casinos/gambling facilities
policy_description: All employers are required to provide/implement exposure determination, a COVID-19 preparedness and response plan, basic infection prevention measures, health surveillance, workplace controls, and personal protective equipment for employees. Industry specific requirements must be implemented for certain businesses/facilities.

Each state department director and autonomous agency head must develop policies and procedures ("return-to-work policies"). The Office of State Employer ("OSE") is responsible for reviewing and approving return-to-work policies to ensure completeness and consistency with statewide policies.

The chairs of each major political party may submit names of presidential electors and alternates nominated to be elected at the 2020 state general election  67 days prior to the date of the election.

The following special procedures may take place for the primary and state general elections in 2020: local authorities may designate polling places no later than July 1, train healthcare employees to administer absentee ballots to patients, extend the absentee ballot processing deadline, begin processing absentee ballots 14 days prior to the election, and accept electronic submissions for candidacy.
Set up a safe and effective summer learning program.
Replaces stay at home order with safer at home order that allows for gatherings of 10 people or less
Outdoor dining with less than 50 people is allowed
Allowing restaurants to open outdoor dining.

policy_subtarget: Public sector/government employees; Private sector; Public services
policy_description: All places of public accommodation remaining open or re-opening under Executive Order 20-74 must create and implement a COVID-19 Preparedness Plan.
Restaurants can start indoor dining at 50 percent
Outdoor entertainment venues, such as sporting events, concerts, and theaters may open at 25 percent capacity.
Gyms, personal fitness and yoga studios, and martial arts may open at 25 percent capacity.
Places of worship can increase occupancy rates to 50 percent.
Indoor entertainment venues, such as theaters and concert halls, can open at 25 percent capacity.
Indoor social gatherings can take place with 10 people or less; outdoor social gatherings can take place with 25 people or less.
Personal services, such as salons, tattoo parlors, and barbershops, may increase occupancy rates to 50 percent while requiring reservations.
Recreational indoor entertainment venues, such as bowling alleys, arcades, and museums may open at 25 percent capacity.
Requires that schools take specific measures provide a safe and effective learning environment for Minnesota students
Higher Ed Plans are required follow OHE and MDH guidance and ensure that sick students, staff, and instructors stay home.
During the Peacetime Emergency, Minnesota cooperatives and cooperative associations are allowed (but not required) to conduct director elections by mail.

policy_subtarget: Public sector/government employees; Private sector; Public services
policy_description: Paragraph 7.i of Executive Order 20-74 is rescinded. This paragraph required places of public accommodation to develop and implement a COVID-19 Preparedness Plan.
During the Peacetime Emergency, Minnesota cooperatives and cooperative associations are allowed (but not required) to forego their annual members' meetings if virtual meetings are not possible.

Higher education institutions must establish and implement a Higher Ed Plan. Each Higher Ed Plan must lay out the implementation of Minnesota OSHA Standards and MDH and CDC Guidelines in classrooms, labs, or other areas where students and staff visit. General guidance is available here: https://staysafe.mn.gov/

Higher education institutions (colleges, universities, private colleges, and other post-secondary schools) may offer in-person classes or activities consistent with Minnesota Department of Health guidelines.

The following changes/clarifications are applied to the Safe Learning Plan: school districts/charter schools must provide free care to Eligible Children during regular school hours, provided that all of the parents or legal guardians in the child’s household are workers in Tier 1 industries; school districts/charter schools may provide care to all other children and may charge a fee on its normal sliding fee scale, but should prioritize those who qualify for free and reduced-price lunch; fees can be charged for before and after school programs; school districts/charter schools are  encouraged to ensure mental health and telehealth services that are accessible on students’ school-issued devices; in-person instruction must be prioritized for students with disabilities at schools adopting a hybrid learning model; schools are discouraged from referring students to truancy programs; every child that has aged out of special education may continue to be eligible during the peacetime emergency;

A school district or charter school must count 30 minutes per day for teacher preparation to provide instruction to students in distance learning or a hybrid learning model, as instructional time toward meeting the minimum hours required by the State of Minnesota.
Venues providing indoor and outdoor entertainment that serve food, beverages, or alcohol must close on-premises consumption from 10 pm to 4am.

Restaurants, bars, and any other places that offer food and beverage may continue indoor and outdoor service with the following restrictions: indoor occupancy cannot exceed 50% capacity, with a maximum of 150 people; the combined occupancy of indoor and outdoor seating may not exceed 150 people; establishments must close each day for on-premises consumption from 10:00 p.m. to 4:00 a.m., excluding delivery and drive-up services.

policy_subtarget: Churches/places of worship; Outdoor recreation or space; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Venues that host gatherings including weddings, birthdays, funerals, private parties, etc. must abide by the following restrictions: food, beverages, and alcohol cannot be served between 10pm and 4am; from November 27th, gatherings may not exceed 50 people; from December 11th, gatherings may not exceed 25 people.
All social gatherings of more than 10 persons or involving more than three households are prohibited.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Restaurants/bars; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Indoor and outdoor social gatherings with members outside your own household are prohibited. Restaurants and bars must revert back to using only delivery and take-out services, all dining in person is prohibited. Gyms, fitness centers, indoor sports facilities, and indoor and outdoor entertainment venues must close.
Retail businesses shall limit capacity to 50%.
Groups gatherings at parks may not exceed 10 inside and 20 outside.
Customer capacity in restaurants  is limited to 50% seating capacity. Party sizes limited to 6 customers per table.
Gyms may not be open past 10:00 pm

Amends order 1460. All state agencies, boards, commissions, counties, municipalities, public school districts and other state/local entities are directed to begin returning employees who were previously deemed non-essential.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Amends Executive Order 1487 to allow outdoor sports complexes and organized youth sports subject to restrictions in paragraph I. Including Dugouts remain closed during practices, sharing of food or drinks is prohibited.Order 1477 is amended to allow libraries and museums to open subject to restrictions.Order 1477 is amended to allow movie theaters and auditoriums under limitations in section II.
Ticket sales for theaters  are limited to 50% seating capacity.Library/Museums are limited to 50% capacity and group tours shall be limited to 20 guests.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Government/public buildings
policy_description: Social distance shall be observed. Social distancing of 6 ft  shall be observed in Libraries/museums. Social distancing shall be observed in theaters.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space; Private sector; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; General population (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Government/public buildings
policy_description: Players shall be screened. Theaters shall screen employees. Libraries/ Museums shall screen employees.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: The number of players, coaches and spectators cannot exceed 100 people.
All businesses may reopen following restrictions. Retail business limited to 50% capacity.
Reception halls can reopen. The number of guests shall be no more than 25% max seating capacity. All events must be seated with 6ft separation between tables

policy_subtarget: Personal care facilities; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Salons, barber shops, spas, massage parlors, personal care facilities and fitness centers shall continue to operate under order 1480.Tattoo parlors and dance studios will continue to operate under order 1486. Libraries, Movie theaters, and auditoriums shall operate under order 1491.

Public and private gatherings where social distancing is not possible are limited to 20  people indoors and 50 outdoors. Where social distancing is possible groups are limited to 50 people indoors and 100 people outdoors.
School districts may open buildings and offer in person classroom activities.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Vulnerable individuals remain under a Safer at Home Order.

1478 is amended to allow bars that do not serve food to open at 50% occupancy. Restaurants and Bars may have live music  Restaurants and bars can offer in house dining according to order 1478 and 1486.
Indoor recreation such as play facilities, social clubs may open subject to limitations located in section (i) including a 50% max occupancy.

Outdoor recreation is permitted  according to the limits of orders 1473, 1476, 1480, 1487 and 1491. Order 1473 is amended to allow beaches and sandbars in the PRVWSD to open. Beaches and sandbars on state  lakes shall remain closed.

Consistent with order 1463 hospitals, nursing homes, retirement homes and long term care facilities shall not allow visitors except to provide assistance, to visit family receiving end of life care or directed by a healthcare professional
Order 1492 and 1480 are amended to allow fitness centers and gyms to increase occupancy to 50%.
Order 1492 amended to allow 25% occupancy for conference centers with social distancing and 50% occupancy for seating at dinners.
Pools may open 24 hours a day.
Order 1492 extended until July 6.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Concessions stands at multi field complexes may open. The number of guests in an arena is limited to 25% capacity.
Extension of the Safe return order

Order 1505 remains in effect. In select counties, All Businesses shall follow the Mississippi state department of health and CDC regulations including screening employees for symptoms and asking questions in Section II (i).
In select counties. Social gatherings are limited to a max of 10 individuals inside and 20 outdoors.
In select counties, All individuals shall maintain a distance of 6ft.
Order 1492 and 1500 are amended so pools can open 24 hours a day so long as they maintain social distancing and a max occupancy of 50% capacity.
In select counties. Social gatherings are limited to a max of 10 individuals inside and 20 outdoors. This does not apply to religious entities and students in classrooms.
In select counties, All individuals shall maintain a distance of 6ft.

Order 1507  remains in effect and now includes additional select counties. In select counties All Businesses shall follow the Mississippi state department of health and CDC regulations including screening employees for symptoms and asking questions in Section II (i).

Order 1507  remains in effect and now includes additional select counties. In select counties All Businesses shall follow the Mississippi state department of health and CDC regulations including screening employees for symptoms and asking questions in Section II (i).
In select counties, All individuals shall maintain a distance of 6ft
EO 1509 is amended to add Calhoun Holmes, Lamar, Montgomery, Winston and Yalobusha County.
In select counties. Social gatherings are limited to a max of 10 individuals inside and 20 outdoors. This does not apply to religious entities and students in classrooms.

Paragraph I(a) of EO 1492  is amended limiting the sale of alcohol in bars only to  seated individuals. Bars are still to follow other limits set by EO 1478.Restaurants and Bars shall not sell alcohol between 11:00 P.M. and 7:00 A.M.

Individuals shall maintain 6ft distance between individuals not in the same household during indoor and outdoor gatherings. his does not apply to religious entities, students in classrooms or gatherings in facilities with different capacity limitations.
Indoor Gatherings are limited to a maximum of 10 people. This does not apply to religious entities, students in classrooms or gatherings in facilities with different capacity limitations.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Outdoor group gatherings shall be limited to a max of 20 individuals. This does not apply to religious entities or gatherings in facilities with different capacity limitations.
Safe return order created by EO 1492 as amended by orders 1496,1500,1505,1508,and 1511 is extended.
Order 1509 now includes the counties of Carrol, Coahoma, Jones, Lee. Leflore, Lowndes, Noxubee, and Pontotoc.
In select counties, All individuals shall maintain a distance of 6ft
In select counties. Social gatherings are limited to a max of 10 individuals inside and 20 outdoors. This does not apply to religious entities and students in classrooms.

Order 1507  remains in effect and now includes additional select counties. In select counties All Businesses shall follow the Mississippi state department of health and CDC regulations including screening employees for symptoms and asking questions in Section II (i).

The start of the 2020-2021 academic year for public schools in Bolivar, Coahoma, Forrest, George, Hinds, Panola, Sunflower and Washington counties for grades 7-12 shall be delayed until Monday August 17
The safe return order as amended is extended.
Paragraph 1 of order 1492 is amended. K-12 outdoor events including athletic events and band performances may be permitted. Concessions may be open with limitations.

Paragraph 1 of order 1492 is amended. k-12 outdoor events including athletic events and band performances may be permitted with limitations.  attendance shall be limited to 2 attendees per student. Attendees shall attempt to follow 6 ft social distancing, Signage shall be required at entrances on face coverings. Concessions may be open with limitations such as face masks for workers, social distancing shall be enforced. Concession stands may open so long as all workers who come into contact with customers wear a face mask, social distancing is observed my customers, customers are not allowed to congregate in the area, and all concession stand employees are screened
Order 1492 is amended so that University and college outdoor stadiums are permitted to have events.

Bowl seating in university stadiums is limited to 25% seating capacity. Indoor club areas are limited to a maximum of 50% seating capacity and an addition 25% seating with an outdoor seating area. Suite capacity is limited to 50% capacity. Attendees shall attempt to maintain 6ft distancing. Signage about face coverings must be placed at all points of entry, concessions areas and restrooms. All stadium entry/exit gates shall be open. Hand sanitizing shall be available at all entry gates . The University or College shall designate a Safety Officer in order to ensure the Executive Order is followed
All game day/event day social gatherings outside college and university stadiums shall be strictly prohibited. This prohibition applies to all tailgating, picnics, fanfare areas and the like

The state wide safe return as amended is extended. Executive order 1492 is amended. K-12 extracurricular events shall be limited to 25% max venue occupancy excluding coaches, directors, teachers, officials, staff, press and medical personnel.
Retail business shall take measures to prevent spread including a max occupancy limit of 75%, and regular cleaning.

Public gatherings where social distancing is not possible are limited to 10 people indoors and 50 outdoors. Public gatherings where social distancing is possible are limited to 20 indoors and  100 outdoors. This does not apply to religious gatherings, students in classrooms or voting precincts

The number of guests in a reception halls limited to 25% max occupancy with social distancing. For seated dinners, reception halls/conference setting must limit halls to 75% of max seating capacity ensuring 6ft of separation between tables.
The number of customers in a gym are limited to 75% max capacity.
Gyms may open 24 hours a day.

For restaurants and bars the number of customers may be no more than 75% seating capacity. Floor plans must be updated to have 6ft separation between parties both indoor and outdoors. There is a maximum of 10 people per table.Self service buffets are prohibited.
Repeal of Executive order 1492 and Executive Order 1517

Businesses and non-profits are permitted to operate at 75% max occupancy so long as 6ft social distancing can be maintained.  This does not apply to religious entities, voting precincts, and students in school.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Primary education; Secondary education; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Attendance at K-12 extracurricular events is limited to 50% max at an outdoor venue and 25% max occupancy at an indoor venue

Outdoor sports complexes may continue to host organized practices and games so long as the the number of fans permits social distancing, signage is posted about covid-19 and every league has a dedicated safety officer.

Attendees shall attempt to social distance. Signage shall be posted at all entry points about face covering requirements. A safety officer must be designated and additional measures are listed in section k(iii)

The number of guests in a reception halls limited to 50% max occupancy with social distancing. For seated dinners, reception halls/conference setting must limit halls to 75% of max seating capacity ensuring 6ft of separation between tables and limit of 10 per table.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Outdoor and indoor arenas are limited to 25% max occupancy

All businesses and non-profits shall make reasonable efforts to comply with CDC and state regulations and guidelines including - adopting social distancing measures - screening of employees and sending sick employees home  - adopting and enforcing hand washing protocols and making hand sanitizer available - frequent cleaning of surfaces  -signage for customers on social distancing

Public and private social gatherings where social distancing is NOT possible are limited to 20 indoors and 100 outdoors. This does not apply to religious entities, voting precincts and students in school.

At college and University outdoor stadiums bowl seating is limited to 25% max occupancy. Indoor club areas are limited to 75% max occupancy with an additional 25% capacity in any outdoor seating areas. Suite capacity is limited to 75% max capacity.
Auditoriums and movie theatre ticket sales are limited to 50% max seating capacity.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: All activities and events shall limit attendance to max 75% capacity or limit capacity so that social distancing can be maintained.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Primary education; Secondary education; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Attendees shall attempt to social distance, signage shall be posted with the requirements, and every event shall have a safety officer.
Employees at close contact personal care services such as salons shall maintain social distancing , screen customers for illness, and have employees wash hands between customers
All game day/event day social gatherings outside college and university stadiums shall be strictly prohibited. This prohibition applies to all tailgating, picnics, fanfare areas and the like

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Indoor spaces; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Public and private gatherings are limited no more than 10 indoors and 50 outdoors where social distancing is not possible
The state wide safe recovery order 1525  is extended

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Indoor spaces; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Public and private gatherings are limited no more than 10 indoors and 50 outdoors where social distancing is not possible

policy_description: Public and private gatherings are limited no more than 10 indoors and 50 outdoors where social distancing is not possible

policy_description: Public and private gatherings are limited no more than 10 indoors and 50 outdoors where social distancing is not possible
