policy_description: Public and private gatherings are limited no more than 10 indoors and 50 outdoors where social distancing is not possible

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Indoor spaces; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Public and private gatherings are limited no more than 10 indoors and 50 outdoors where social distancing is not possible
Executive order 1527 is repealed.

Businesses and non-profits are permitted to operate at 75% max occupancy so long as 6ft social distancing can be maintained.  This does not apply to religious entities, voting precincts, and students in school.

All businesses and non-profits operating within Mississippi shall make efforts to comply with CDC and Mississippi state DoH regulations and guidelines. All businesses and non-profits shall  -implement screening protocols for employees/volunteers at the beginning of shifts -send home sick employees - limit the number of customers to  - adopting measures for social distancing and hand washing - cleaning high contact surfaces  -posting signage at all points of entry

Reception halls and conference centers are limited to 50% max occupancy. For seated dinners they shall limit the number of guest to 75% max occupancy and ensure 6ft separation between tables with a max of 10 per table.

Outdoor sports complexes may continue to host organized practices and games so long as the the number of fans permits social distancing, signage is posted about covid-19 and every league has a dedicated safety officer.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Primary education; Secondary education; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Attendance at K-12 events at outdoor venues shall he limited to a max of 50% max occupancy. Attendance at K-12 events at indoor venues shall be limited to either 4 attendees per student or 250 ticketed attendees (whichever is less)
All game day social gatherings shall be prohibited. This applies to tailgaiting picnics etc..
Repeal of Executive order 1525

Gatherings where social distancing is not possible are limited to 10 people indoors or 50 people outdoors. This does not apply to religious entities ,voting precincts, students in classrooms or facilities with other specified capacity limits
Auditoriums and movie theatre shall limit ticket sales to 50% max occupancy and provide 6ft of social distancing

Close contact facilities such as salons, tattoo parlors and barber shops should have employees wash hands between customers. The number of customers in side the facility shall ensure 6ft of social distancing. Customers shall be screened for illness.

At college and University outdoor stadiums bowl seating is limited to 25% max occupancy. Indoor club areas are limited to 75% max occupancy with an additional 25% capacity in any outdoor seating areas. Suite capacity is limited to 75% max capacity. Elevators capacity shall be restricted to 5 attendees or 1 family unit.

In addition to the general business protocols, restaurants and bars must update their floor plans to maintain at least 6 ft of separation. Tables are limited to a max of 10 per table. Customers shall be screened. Alcohol may only be served to seated customers and cannot be served between the hours of 11:00 pm and 7:00 AM.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Primary education; Secondary education; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: At k-12 events, all entry/exits and restrooms shall be open. Social distancing shall be observed and attendees are not permitted to congregate in entrances and exits. Every event shall have a designated safety office and signage shall be posted at all points of entry displaying face covering requirements. Additional adaptation measures located in section II (n)

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: All activities including outdoor events are limited to 75% max occupancy

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Number of guests in outdoor arenas shall be no greater than 25% max seating capacity. Additional requirements in II(k). Number of guests in indoor arenas are limited to less than 10% of the max seating capacity or indoor arena.  Additional requirements in II (l)
All staff in corrections facilities must be screened before beginning work.
Each mail-in ballot must be returned to the election authority in the ballot envelope and may only be returned by United States mail.

The Secretary of State may prescribe uniform regulations with respect to the printing of the ballot envelopes and mailing envelopes. Any ballot returned by mail will not require postage. All fees and costs for establishing and maintaining business reply and postage-free mail for ballots will be paid for by the secretary of state through state appropriations.

Before the sixth Tuesday prior to each election, the election authority shall print and make available a sufficient quantity of ballots, ballot envelopes, and mailing envelopes. The election official should also be ready to print ballots, ballot envelopes, and mailing envelopes, as soon as possible if a special state or county election is called.
Applications for mail-in ballot may be made by the applicant in person, by US mail, or on behalf of their guardian or close relative.
If a mail-in voter dies prior to the opening of polls on election day and the election authority is notified with sufficient evidence, the ballot of the deceased voter will be rejected.
The provisions of this section will apply only to elections which occur in the year 2020, to avoid the risks of contracting or transmitting COVID-19.

Each application for a mail-in ballot shall be signed by the applicant, or, if the application is made by a guardian or relative, the application shall be signed by the guardian or relative. If an applicant, guardian, or relative is blind, unable to read or write the English language, or incapable of signing, they shall sign by mark that is witnessed by the signature of an election official or witness.
As each mail-in ballot is received by the election authority, the election authority shall note its receipt on the list.

Each ballot envelope shall contain a formal statement (outlined in 115.302, subsection 7) to be signed by the voter in order to verify their identity. The provisions of this section shall apply only to an election that occurs during the year 2020, to avoid the risk of contracting or transmitting COVID-19.
All mail-in ballot envelopes received by the election authority will be kept together in a safe place and will not be opened except as provided under this chapter.
No information which encourages a vote for or against a candidate or issue will be provided to any voter with a mail-in ballot.

All votes on each mail-in ballot received by an election authority at or before the time fixed by law for the closing of the polls on election day will be counted. No votes on any mail-in ballot received by an election authority after this time will be counted.
Voting and ballot envelopes will be labeled "ELECTION BALLOT, STATE OF MISSOURI" and have US postage paid.

Each signed, valid application for mail-in ballot will be processed within three working days by the election authority. Voters whose applications are accepted will receive a mail-in ballot, ballot envelope, and instructions that are necessary for voting. If an application is rejected, the election authority must notify the applicant and state the reason they are not entitled to vote by mail-in ballot. Rejected applicants may file a complaint with the elections division of the secretary of state's office. Note that if the application is received before mail-in ballots are available, the application will be processed within five working days after the mail-in ballots are ready.
The voter will mark the ballot in secret, place the ballot in the ballot envelope, seal the envelope, and fill out the statement. This statement must be notarized.
No applications for a mail-in ballot will be processed beginning at 5:00 PM the second Wednesday prior to the election.
Any registered voter of the state may apply to cast a mail-in ballot.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: For an election that occurs during the year 2020, voters who have contracted or are in an at-risk category for contracting or transmitting COVID-19 may vote by absentee ballot. At-risk categories count as those: 65 years of age or older, living in a long-term care facility, with chronic lung disease or asthma, with serious heart conditions, who are immunocompromised, have diabetes, have chronic kidney disease and are undergoing dialysis, or have liver disease. This subdivision shall expire on December 31, 2020.
The provisions of this section terminate and will be repealed on December 31, 2020, and will not apply to any election conducted after that date.
Mail-in ballots shall be counted using the procedures set out in sections 115.297, 115.299, 115.300, and 115.303.

The false execution of a mail-in ballot is a class one election offense. The attorney general or any prosecuting or circuit attorney will have the authority to prosecute such an offense, either in the county of the accused or in Cole County circuit court.
Governor Steve Bullock mandated social distancing measures
Classifies childcare facilities as essential businesses, allowing them to remain open
Implements new measures at correctional facilities, including restricting all in-person visitation.
Deems the Easter Bunny, Tooth Fairy, unicorns, friendly dragons, and other magical creatures essential, and can travel freely through Montana to provide essential services.
Retail and similar businesses can become operational with reduced capacity and physical distancing measures.
Retroactively authorises pools at public accommodations such as hotels to open.
Authorzes gyms, fitness studios, museums and theatres to open.
Childcare facilities may increase capacity, with the 24-person cap no longer applying.
Restaurants and bars see an increase in their permitted capacity to 75%.
Non-work-related arrivals into the state are no longer required to undergo mandatory quarantine.
Increases the permissible group size to 50 people. Larger groups are permitted as long as physical distancing measures are adhered to.
Entertainment venues may operate as reduced capacity, and following physical distancing and sanitation measures.

Permits visitation in nursing homes and assisted care facilities that are able to follow infection control protocol from the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).
Release of a plan for flexible guidance to pubic schools regarding in-person instruction in the fall.

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Governor Bullock announces a partnership with Montana State University to expand surveillance testing of front-line workers, essential workers and other groups.
Places of worship remain subject to a 50 person limit provided in phase two where social distancing can be maintained (rather than the new 25 person limit)
Public gatherings are limited to 25 individuals where social distancing is not possible or observed.

Restaurants, bars, breweries, distilleries and casinos must operate at a maximum of 50 percent capacity, and must close no later than 10 p.m. Tables will be limited to six people per table and establishments are still required to maintain social distancing.
Places of worship have relaxed directed health measure requirements. They need to ensure 6 feet separation, prohibit items passed among worshipers
Places of worship statewide will no longer be subject to the 10-person social gathering limitation for their main services

Schools are permitted to open weight rooms for use by all student-athletes as long as they follow the same guidelines as fitness centers/clubs, gymnasiums, health clubs, and health spas. Organized team practices for baseball and softball may begin unless circumstances dictate a change in date.
Baseball and softball games may begin

Rodeos, limited and non-contact team sports, for both youth and adults, may resume practices on June 1st and games on June 18th. Contact sports like basketball, tackle football, soccer, and wrestling remain prohibited.
Phase 3: Contact team sports begin practices and games on July 1st
Any elected officials who have been ordered to isolate may fully participate, vote, and be counted if they are attending by videoconference.
All governing bodies may hold conferences virtually so long as the meeting is made available to the public and to members of the media.

Any employer required to provide housing to an employee or worker and who provides congregate or shared housing to employees must post signage of public health measures, disinfect the house daily, perform health screening on the individuals, and provide alternative housing arrangements for any employee who tests positive for COVID-19 or who has been exposed.

Any employer required to provide housing to an employee or worker and who provides congregate or shared housing to employees must post signage of public health measures, disinfect the house daily, perform health screening on the individuals, and provide alternative housing arrangements for any employee who tests positive for COVID-19 or who has been exposed.
All businesses must follow any COVID-19 related safety guidelines established or published by their respective professional, regulatory, or advisory associations or agencies.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Churches/places of worship; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Restaurants/bars
policy_description: Any one party may not exceed 8 people. Gatherings are restricted to 50% occupancy for indoor facilities (not exceeding 10,000 people) and 100% occupancy for outdoor facilities (not exceeding 10,000 people). These restrictions apply to youth sports, restaurants, beauty/nail salons, daycare facilities, gyms, etc..
