All Department of Motor Vehicles facilities to remain closed to the public until at least April 16, 2020.
Golf, pickleball, and tennis may resume as long as they are operating under social distancing guidelines and abide by all guidance to reduce the spread of COVID-19
Offices of the Board of Parole Commissioners shall remain closed to the public. Measures taken to facilitate remote parole hearings via telephone or video conferencing.
Summer camps may continue to operate pursuant to all applicable licensure, regulatory, and statutory requirements and are encouraged to following guidelines issued by the LEAP.
Breweries, distilleries, and wineries not licensed to serve food may open to the public in accordance with safety provisions listed in Section 26 of Emergency Directive 021.

Houses of worship may conduct indoor in-person services in a manner so that no more than fifty persons are gathered, and all social distancing requirements are satisfied. Encouraged to provide online services.
Nevada general public shall not gather in groups of more than fifty in any indoor or outdoor area

Museums, art galleries, zoos, and aquariums may reopen to the public. Capacity shall be limited to the lesser of 50% based on listed fire code capacity or fifty persons. Interactive exhibits which encourage touching must remain closed. Facilities must ensure that employees wear face coverings.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Non-retail indoor venues, including without limitation, indoor movie theaters, bowling alleys, or arcades may reopen to the public, so long as occupancy does not exceed 50% of the listed fire code capacity and measures are taken to ensure that all social distancing requirements are satisfied.

Musical performances, live entertainment, concerts, competitions, sporting events, and any events with live performances may resume, but shall remain closed for public attendance. Events held pursuant to this section may be recorded, filmed, streamed or broadcast to the public.

Restaurants and food establishments shall continue to operate under the Phase One conditions set forth in Section 17 of Directive 018, but may additionally utilize tables and serve food within the bar area. Must follow specific distancing and sanitation measures.
Public, charter, and private schools to present plans for 2020-2021 academic year reopening by 20 days before start of school year.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Schools may reopen school athletic fields and facilities, including tennis courts, golf courses, swimming pools, and gyms to the public in accordance with NV OSHA and CDC guidelines.
Summer or extended school year instruction may be offered in-person, online, or a combination of both. A distance education option must be available for credit-bearing learning opportunities.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Schools may reopen school athletic fields and facilities for student athletics training, practices, and competition

Schools that are reopening must follow guidelines provided by NV OSHA, the CDC,  and the Local Empowerment Advisory Panel. Schools and facilities may remain closed at their discretion in the interest of the health and safety of their school community.

All Pre-kindergarten through 12th grade school facilities may re­open to students, staff, and parents/ guardians in accordance with the conditions of Directive 021, and guidelines issued by the Nevada Department of Education. Occupancy not to exceed the lesser of 50% of fire code capacity of a single space within a school site or fifty persons.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Youth contact sports may resume on a limited basis for athletic conditioning, drills, and practices in which athletes do not come into contact with other players.
Local governments may permit the use of outdoor soccer fields, outdoor baseball and softball facilities, and other outdoor athletic fields by organized youth sporting leagues. No spectators.

Authorizes state counties, state agencies, and local municipalities to adopt additional protective measures intended to combat the spread of COVID-19, including without limitation, stay at home and face covering orders, so long as those measures are at least as restrictive as those imposed by the Declaration of Emergency for COVID- 19

Authorizes local, city, and county governments, and state agencies to enforce this Directive and regulations including penalties and license suspensions for activities which jeopardize the health, safety, or welfare of the public
Extension of Directive 021 "Phase Two of the Nevada United: Roadmap to Recovery plan" to July 31, 2020.
Directive 007 (amended by Directive 21) is extended to July 31, 2020. No gatherings of 50 or more persons (exception: those residing in the same household).
Directive 006 is extended to July 31, 2020. Public body meetings must continue to be held remotely, ensuring that supporting materials are available to disseminate to the public.
Directive 007 is extended to July 31, 2020. Distance of six feet must be kept between persons in public spaces.

Rescindment of Section 26 of Emergency Directive #021.  Bars, pubs, taverns, breweries, distilleries, and wineries in a county with an Elevated Disease Transmission, and according to the criteria published by the Department of Health and Human Services, not licensed to serve food shall close and remain closed as required by Section 18 of Directive 18

Rescindment of Section 25 of Emergency Directive #21. When located in a county with an Elevated Disease Transmission and according to the criteria published by the Department of Health and Human Services, bars, restaurants, and other food service establishments are to operate under Phase One conditions outlined by Section 17 of Emergency Directive #18.
Restaurant seating parties limited to no more than six people.

Bar tops and bar areas in any establishment in a county with an Elevated Disease Transmission and according to the criteria published by the Department of Health and Human Services shall be closed to customers, but bar beverages may be served at tables for onsite consumption.

EXTENDED: Trade schools and technical schools may reopen to the public. Occupancy in classrooms and instructional areas shall be limited to the lesser of 50% of maximum occupancy of based on listed fire code capacity or fifty persons, and must abide by all guidelines promulgated by NV OSHA.
EXTENDED: In-person gaming operations to begin phased and incremental reopening no sooner than June 4th, 2020.

EXTENDED: Houses of worship may conduct indoor in-person services in a manner so that no more than fifty persons are gathered, and all social distancing requirements are satisfied. Encouraged to provide online services.
EXTENDED: Summer camps may continue to operate pursuant to all applicable licensure, regulatory, and statutory requirements and are encouraged to following guidelines issued by the LEAP.

EXTENDED: Guidance for phase II reopening. All Nevadans, especially vulnerable individuals, are strongly encouraged to stay in their residences to the greatest extent possible, unless they are essential workers.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: EXTENDED: Non-retail indoor venues, including without limitation, indoor movie theaters, bowling alleys, or arcades may reopen to the public, so long as occupancy does not exceed 50% of the listed fire code capacity and measures are taken to ensure that all social distancing requirements are satisfied.
EXTENDED: Nevada general public shall not gather in groups of more than fifty in any indoor or outdoor area
EXTENDED: Gyms, fitness facilities, and fitness studios, including but not limited to dance and yoga studios, may reopen to the public.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Personal care facilities
policy_description: EXTENDED: Hair and nail salons continue to operate under Phase I guidance.

EXTENDED: Museums, art galleries, zoos, and aquariums may reopen to the public. Capacity shall be limited to the lesser of 50% based on listed fire code capacity or fifty persons. Interactive exhibits which encourage touching must remain closed. Facilities must ensure that employees wear face coverings.
EXTENDED: Body art and piercing may reopen to the public under strict distancing and hygiene protocols.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Personal care facilities
policy_description: EXTENDED: Estheticians and salons or businesses that provide aesthetic skin services, including without limitation, facials, hair removal, tanning, eyelash services, professional make-up artist services, eyebrow threading, and salt therapy, may continue to operate.

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: EXTENDED: All businesses that engage in retail sales may continue to provide retail sales on a curbside or home delivery basis, or continue to allow onsite customer access, with a maximum occupancy of 50% based on listed fire code capacity.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: EXTENDED: Non-retail outdoor venues, including without limitation, miniature golf facilities, amusement parks, theme parks may reopen to the public. Businesses operating pursuant to this section must ensure that occupancy shall not exceed 50% of the listed fire code capacity, and implement measures to ensure that all social distancing requirements are satisfied.
EXTENDED: All public aquatic venues, may reopen to the public including pools and waterparks.
EXTENDED: The following non-essential businesses shall remain closed during Phase Two of the Nevada United: Roadmap to Recovery plan: Nightclubs, Day clubs, Brothels, Adult entertainment facilities
EXTENDED: Cannabis dispensaries shall continue to operate under the Phase One conditions set forth in Section 22 of Directive 018.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Personal care facilities
policy_description: EXTENDED: Estheticians and salons or businesses that provide aesthetic skin services, including without limitation, facials, hair removal, tanning, eyelash services, professional make-up artist services, eyebrow threading, and salt therapy, must operate under strict distancing and sanitation protocols.
EXTENDED: All public aquatic venues shall be limited to a maximum occupancy of 50% based on listed fire code capacity. Distancing and sanitation measures mandated.
EXTENDED: Massage establishments must operate under NV OSHA sanitization guidelines. All therapists must wear masks. Clients must have an appointment.

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: EXTENDED: Establishments providing services to more than ten patrons at a time shall limit customer access so as not to exceed a maximum occupancy of 50% based on listed fire code capacity. These facilities must abide by strict NV OSHA distancing and sanitation regulations to protect employees and patrons.
Extension of Nevadas Phase 2 reopening plan.

EXTENDED: Musical performances, live entertainment, concerts, competitions, sporting events, and any events with live performances may resume, but shall remain closed for public attendance. Events held pursuant to this section may be recorded, filmed, streamed or broadcast to the public.

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: EXTENDED: All businesses that engage in retail sales may continue to provide retail sales on a curbside or home delivery basis, or continue to allow onsite customer access, with a maximum occupancy of 50% based on listed fire code capacity. Businesses must adopt measures promulgated by NV OSHA to minimize the risk of spread of COVID-19 including social distancing and sanitation measures.

EXTENDED: Persons testing positive for COVID-19 shall stay at home and "self quarantine" for a minimum of two weeks, except as necessary to care for themselves or seek medical care. Persons determined to be in contact with an individual who tested positive for COVID-19 must quarantine and stay at home for two weeks, or until a negative test result has been received.

EXTENDED: Restaurants and food establishments shall continue to operate under the Phase One conditions set forth in Section 17 of Directive 018, but may additionally utilize tables and serve food within the bar area. Must follow specific distancing and sanitation measures.

Restrictions on restaurants, bars, and similar businesses from Declaration of Emergency Directive 027 have been declared to end on August. The new statewide mitigation measures and restrictions on service and capacity for these establishments are those outlined in Declaration of Emergency Directive 021.

All businesses and venues subject to capacity limitations must post signs at public entrances identifying their COVID-19-adjusted capacity based on the occupancy limitations imposed by the state. Guidelines for these signs will come from the Nevada Department of Business and Industry or its agencies.
Capacity limitations at venues and events shall not include staff, workers, performers, broadcast personnel, or other personnel necessary to conduct business, perform services, or host events.

Public gatherings are restricted to the lesser of 250 persons, or 50% of the listed fire code capacity of the area of the gathering. This restriction shall not apply to any area with a listed fire code capacity of less than 100 persons, which may allow up to 50 persons to gather, provided that this may occur without violating social distancing requirements.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Non-retail indoor and outdoor venues may allow access to the public. Occupancy shall not exceed 50% of the listed fire code capacity, and all social distancing requirements must be satisfied. Food and beverage sales are limited to prepackaged products only. Relevant businesses with a listed fire code capacity of fewer than 100 persons may allow access to up to 50 persons if they are able to do so in a manner consistent with social distancing guidelines
In-person showings and open houses of single family and multi-family residences currently occupied and on the market for sale, may resume, subject to state-issued limitations.

Restaurants, food establishments, breweries, distilleries, and wineries may utilize tables and serve patrons within the bar area. Establishments operating under this provision shall follow state-issued provisions and mitigation measures.

Museums, art galleries, zoos, and aquariums are able to open with occupancy that shall not exceed 50% of the listed fire code capacity, and all social distancing requirements must be satisfied. Interactive exhibits which encourage touching must remain closed and inaccessible to the public.

Occupancy in classrooms and instructional areas at trade schools, and technical schools operating pursuant to this Section shall be limited to the lesser of 250 persons or 50% of maximum occupancy of based on listed fire code capacity and must abide by state-issued guidelines.

Musical performances, live entertainment, concerts, competitions, sporting events, and any events with live performances may permit public attendance subject to state-issued provisions/mitigation guidelines. This Directive defines fixed seat capacity.

Houses of worship may conduct indoor in-person services, but occupancy may not exceed the lesser of 50% of the listed fire code capacity or 250 persons, and all social distancing requirements must be satisfied. It is recommended that the services follow other state-issued mitigation measures.
Local governments may allow public access to playground equipment if, in consultation with their local health authority, they determine it is safe to do so.

Conventions, trade shows, conferences, professional or educational seminars, large business meetings or corporate retreats, and other similar event activities may resume under certain limitations and provisions. Events are limited to no more than 1,000 attendees per venue or site. Events with greater than 250 attendees are subject to additional provisions.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Sporting events are subject to gathering restrictions, and event organizers must ensure that all spectators maintain social distancing and comply with facial covering requirements (Directives 33 & 34). Leagues and associations beginning competition, games, matches, or league play or facilities and venues intending to host competitions must adopt a Preparedness and Safety Plan that conforms to guidelines. The plans must be approved by the Nevada Department of Business and Industry. Teams, coaches and athletes are responsible for abiding by the rules and requirements set forth in their Preparedness and Safety Plan. Organized teams are strongly encouraged to adopt their own team specific Preparedness and Safety Plan. County school districts, charter schools, and private schools may permit the use of their athletic fields, facilities, and sporting venues as determined by their governing authority. Student athletics training, practices, and competition may reopen in accordance with guidance from the NIAA and any state-issued conditions/limitations.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Youth and non-professional adult organized minimal-contact and non-contact sporting activities may resume, subject to limitations. Full-contact sports may resume on a limited basis for athletic conditioning, drills, and practices in which dummy players, sleds, punching bags, and similar equipment are used, but athletes do not come into contact with other players.

Public gatherings are limited to 50 people. Private gatherings are limited to 10 people from up to 2 households, and non-exempt individuals must wear face coverings. Places of worship may gather up to 50 people, but must follow mitigation measures and are encouraged to offer online & drive-up services.

policy_subtarget: Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Restaurants/bars
policy_description: Non-retail indoor and outdoor entertainment venues, gaming properties, museums/art galleries/zoos/aquariums, and concerts/conferences/sporting events may operate in limited capacities. Gyms/physical fitness centers may operate with mitigation measures and limited capacities. Sporting tournaments are prohibited. Restaurants, food establishments, breweries, distilleries, and wineries may utilize tables and serve patrons within the bar area. Establishments operating under this provision shall follow state-issued provisions and mitigation measures.

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Grocery store
policy_description: Large retail and grocery stores that may operate with public access are required to station employees at the entrances to monitor capacities, and they are encouraged to perform health screenings and temperature checks on customers before entry. These businesses must post health screening signage at their entrances. All businesses with revised capacities also must post these.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Minors and children
policy_description: Loosens restrictions on the use of software for remote learning. Schools may implement software which meets minimum requirements for data privacy.
All grocery stores are to transition to store-provided single use plastic or paper bags when bagging groceries for customers.
All assisted living and nursing facilities for elderly and infirm patients will prohibit visitors for an additional 21 days.

Voters seeking to change political party affiliation no longer required to appear in person at town/city clerk. Outlines procedure for mail-in application and option to apply at State Primary polling stations.

School districts are to hold Individualized Education Plan "IEP" meetings (no later than June 30th) for students with special education requirements to discuss remote (or potentially in-person) Extended-School Year services. School districts are also to hold IEP meetings no later than 30 days into the 2020-2021 academic school year to discuss Compensatory Education Services to make up for services not provided during remote instruction.
Signage must be prominently posted throughout the establishment to ask customers if they are experiencing COVID-19 symptoms

Lodgings are open to the public, including short-term rentals, and may accept overnight reservations from New Hampshire residents, or out of state visitors who have met the 14 day quarantine requirement. Reservations may be accepted by phone, online, or in person.
Funeral homes may resume operation according to the guidance in Emergency Order #52.
Amateur and youth sports limited to outdoor, low-physical contact sporting events.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Public and commercial pools are allowed to be opened according to the guidelines of Emergency Order #52.

Authorizes indoor dining in Belknap, Coos, Carrol, Cheshire, Sullivan and Grafton Counties. However, seated dining areas are limited in capacity to the number of people where table spacing (6 ft between patrons at adjacent tables) is able to be maintained. The same applies to Rockingham, Hillsborough, Merrimack and Strafford County, however, seated dining is also limited to 50 percent capacity of the permitted occupancy based on New Hampshire’s Building and Fire Code. Staggered reservations to avoid congregation and maximum six guests per table.
Campground reservations must be done in advance online or by phone.

All dental patients will be pre-screened for symptoms of COVID-19 and with an in-office temperature check prior to treatment. Patients with an elevated temperature or symptoms of COVID-19 should be instructed to contact their primary care provider and rescheduled for their dental procedure.

Campgrounds may be open to New Hampshire residents, members, or out of state visitors who have met the 14-day quarantine requirement. Campsites must be limited to 6-8 occupants depending upon campground and campsite configuration
Summer day camps/playground programs may resume operation according to the guidelines listed in Emergency Order #52.
Overnight may open if they operate following the guidelines of Emergency Order #52 Exhibit B.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: A limited number of spectators can be allowed at swim events but they must be limited to close/immediate family members of the athletes. Swim events will not be open to the public and should not be advertised publicly.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: People must maintain a physical distance of at least 6 feet from others at all times even when in the pool.

Fitness center and gym members who do not comply with requirements must be asked to leave the facility. Repeat offenders must not have access the facility or classes until the facility is allowed to return to normal operations
Practices and training sessions may begin and are allowed for groups of up to 50 participants
If fitness class equipment or machines cannot be physically moved to accommodate spacing and distance requirements, then fitness class equipment or machines should be taken out of order.

Elevators, if present in the facility, should be limited to one person or associated reservation group at a time. Lines for elevator use should be clearly marked with demarcations on the floor spaced at least 6 feet apart for where people should stand to wait for an elevator.
Tissues and no-touch trash cans should be made readily available for drying eyes and blowing noses with hand sanitizer readily available.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: All mouth-based activities that are often encountered during swim events, such as spitting in the pool or filling one’s mouth with water and then releasing the water back into the pool, shall not be allowed.

Close contact with others (e.g. hugging or shaking hands) is discouraged. Condolences should be provided from a distance of at least 6 feet. Funeral homes should develop ways for attendees to be able to show condolences that do not require close contact within 6 feet of a person.

Staff, athletes, and volunteers must be screened on arrival to each competitive sporting event, training session, or practice. All staff, athletes and volunteers must have their temperatures taken and shall be asked regarding signs, symptoms, and travel risk factors.
Group recreational activities outside of structured classes are allowed (i.e., pick-up games of racquetball, volleyball, basketball, group sparing sessions, etc.) for groups of 10 or less.

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: At least 30 minutes between classes to allow for appropriate ventilation of the fitness room and cleaning and disinfection of the floor and commonly touched surfaces.

A limited number of spectators will be allowed at competitive sporting events, and must be limited to close/immediate family of athletes. Competitive sporting events will not be open to the public and should not be advertised publicly.

“Mass Starts” are allowable where all participants have enough space to remain at least 6 feet apart. In cases where space limitations prohibit a mass start, a staggered start format will be necessary to reduce the number of people at start line.
Golf course may remain open under certain restrictions.
Cars must be spaced at least 10 feet apart.
Golf course must follow strict social distancing and sanitation guidelines listed in Exhibit B of Emergency Order #52. Caddie programs and club rentals must be suspended.

policy_subtarget: Suspected cases; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare)
policy_description: Any person who develops symptoms of COVID-19 while at the day camp must be masked if they are over 2 years of age, removed from contact with others, and be immediately sent home.

policy_subtarget: Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); General population (inclusive)
policy_description: Employees must maintain at least 6 feet of distance between one another at all times.
Measures to be taken to limit occupancy at in-land beaches.

policy_subtarget: Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Employers must develop a process for screening all employees reporting for work for COVID-19 related symptoms. An employee must be assigned to take and document the temperatures of all employees before they enter the workplace. The screener must also ask the questions regarding symptoms and contacts listed in Exhibit A of the policy. Employees found to have signs and symptoms must be instructed to leave the premises and seek medical advice. Employers must maintain the confidentiality of their employees' health information.

Places of worship should develop a system and process that builds in social distancing at all times so that participants are separated by at least 6 feet of space when entering, kneeling/sitting/standing and participating in worship, and leaving the service.

Authorizes outdoor dining. Outdoor dining areas must be disinfected. If the outdoor expansion is in a shared space, the business or organization must coordinate and seek approval from applicable local authorities.
People under 65 advised to practice social distancing consistent with State and National public health guidelines.
Asymptomatic food service workers who have had contact with a suspected or confirmed case must quarantine themselves at home for 14 days from their last exposure before returning to work.

policy_subtarget: Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare); Minors and children
policy_description: Childcare employees must supervise children to ensure proper hand-washing and safe use of alcohol based hand sanitizer. Hand sanitizer should be kept out of reach of children.

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Retail stores should consider dedicated shopping hours or appointment times for the elderly and medically vulnerable persons.

policy_subtarget: Public sector/government employees; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Parks must make hand washing stations and alcohol-based hand sanitizer readily available where able.
Develop drop-off and pick-up processes which stagger arrivals/departures of children and parents/guardians to avoid interaction and congregation.

Facilities must have a defined process for screening all employees and patients for symptoms of COVID-19, whether in-house or referral to another testing provider, before reinstating healthcare services including elective procedures.

Day camps should attempt to divide staff and children into small groups of ideally no more than 10 people total, including children and staff. Groups should be kept consistent (no floating staff) and separated from other groups. Each group should have its own activity equipment. Campers should be kept outdoors as much as possible.
Menus must be sanitized between uses (disposable menus encouraged). No "self-serve" utensils or buffet style dining.

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Manufacturers
policy_description: Manufacturing companies should stagger shifts, breaks, and meals, in compliance with wage and hour laws and regulations to maintain social distancing. If possible, have employees take breaks outside, weather permitting.

policy_subtarget: Public sector/government employees; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Parks must post signage and messaging about COVID-19 and the need for social distancing, frequent hand hygiene/washing, and cloth face covering use when in public places.

Retail stores must assign task management-level employees within the store (i.e. a safety officer) to monitor and enforce compliance with face-covering, distancing, and other COVID-19 safety policies.

policy_subtarget: Non essential workers (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Employers must allow employees to work from home as much as is practical.

policy_subtarget: Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Suspected cases; Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Employers must require all employees who are sick or not feeling well to stay home, and employees must notify their supervisor by phone.

Where lines of people may form (e.g., entry, exit, receiving sacraments, veneration of religious objects, processionals) the floor should be clearly marked to delineate 6 feet distances between participants.

Food service workers who are sick must stay home and seek out COVID-19 testing. Suspected or confirmed cases must self-isolate at home for a minimum of 10 days from the onset of symptoms and at least three days from the resolution of fever (without the use of fever reducing medications) and the improvement of other symptoms.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: People over 65 and with underlying health conditions are strongly advised to stay in their homes. They are advised to leave their homes only for essential purposes and to wear a face covering when doing so.

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); General population (inclusive)
policy_description: Retail stores must develop a process for limiting the number of customers inside a store at a given time, implement one-way aisles (or other traffic patterns) if possible, and  implement pay-ahead and curbside pickup and/or delivery service options if possible.
Retail stores must use plastic shields or barriers between customers and clerks at service counters and clean them frequently.

policy_subtarget: Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare); Minors and children
policy_description: Frequently touched surfaces, including door handles, toys, chairs, tables, must be disinfected frequently. Childcare facilities must have a Safety Data Sheet (SDS) for each chemical used in the facility.
Places of worship must not use shared or communal religious items that require physical contact. Ex: hand-held donation receptacles, shared bibles, shared cups and plates.

Pick-up/drop-off times should be staggered to reduce congregation. Facilities should consistently keep the same groups of children and staff together and avoid intermixing or interaction between groups. They should increase outdoor play time, but stagger groups.
Employers must implement workplace cleaning and disinfection practices following CDC guidelines. They must also promote frequent hand-washing and make hand sanitizer readily available.
Camps must plan for systematically perform daily temperature and symptom screenings on all staff, adults, teenagers, and children on the camp.

Any person requiring quarantine due to COVID-19 exposure should leave the camp and can either drive themselves home (for staff and volunteers), or be picked up by family. People under quarantine shall not be allowed on public transportation. If a person is unable to leave the camp or be picked up immediately, they should undergo quarantine on the camp premise.
Campers must be divided into small cohorts with the same counselors for the duration of the camp session. These counselor/camper groups must not exceed 10 total people.

Any campers coming from out-of-state must quarantine in NH for at least 14 days before camp, or attest to home quarantine in their home state in the 14 days before start of camp session and not go out in public places or interact with others outside of their household during their home quarantine or en-route to camp.
Camps must plan for isolation of symptomatic people and quarantine of anybody exposed to a person who is undergoing COVID-19 testing or has confirmed COVID-19.
Visitors will not be allowed on camp property during periods of group quarantine. Visitors will be limited to essential service providers for the duration of the camp session.
Beds must be arranged so that campers and staff sleep head-to-toe and are at least 6 feet apart.

Campers and and staff are to undergo a pre-arrival health screening concerning symptoms and risk factors related to COVID-19. This screening must be completed in the 7 days before arrival at camp. Campers and staff are to be screened again upon arrival.
Termination of Emergency Order #10. Grocery stores are no longer required to use single-use plastic or paper bags.

Authorizes indoor dining in Belknap, Coos, Carrol, Cheshire, Sullivan and Grafton Counties. However, seated dining areas are limited in capacity to the number of people where table spacing (6 ft between patrons at adjacent tables) is able to be maintained. The same applies to Rockingham, Hillsborough, Merrimack and Strafford County, however, seated dining is also limited to 50 percent capacity of the permitted occupancy based on New Hampshire’s Building and Fire Code. Staggered reservations to avoid congregation and maximum six guests per table.
Public and commercial pools are allowed to be opened according to the guidelines of Emergency Order #52.
Campgrounds may be open to New Hampshire residents, members, or out of state visitors who have met the 14-day quarantine requirement.
Funeral homes may resume operation according to the guidance in Emergency Order #52.
Lodgings, including hotels, motels, inns, and short-term rentals, may be opened to the public with restrictions.

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); General population (inclusive)
policy_description: Retail stores must develop a process for limiting the number of customers inside a store at a given time, implement one-way aisles (or other traffic patterns) if possible, and  implement pay-ahead and curbside pickup and/or delivery service options if possible. Retail stores should consider dedicated shopping hours or appointment times for the elderly and medically vulnerable persons. Retail stores must use plastic shields or barriers between customers and clerks at service counters and clean them frequently. Retail stores must assign task management-level employees within the store (i.e. a safety officer) to monitor and enforce compliance with face-covering, distancing, and other COVID-19 safety policies.

Visitors will not be allowed on camp property during periods of group quarantine. Visitors will be limited to essential service providers for the duration of the camp session. Camps must plan for systematically perform daily temperature and symptom screenings on all staff, adults, teenagers, and children on the camp. Camps must plan for isolation of symptomatic people and quarantine of anybody exposed to a person who is undergoing COVID-19 testing or has confirmed COVID-19. Camps should identify a local New Hampshire medical director for the camp who is an M.D., D.O., or APRN. Camps must train camp medical staff on use of appropriate COVID-19 personal protective equipment (PPE), which involves at a minimum wearing a medical gown, gloves, surgical face mask, and eye protection (face shield or goggles) when evaluating a person with COVID19 symptoms. All out-of-state staff and volunteers must arrive at the camp at least 14 days before the official start of camp. During this 14-day pre-camp session, staff and volunteers should be undergoing temperature and symptom monitoring Any campers coming from out-of-state must quarantine in NH for at least 14 days before camp, or attest to home quarantine in their home state in the 14 days before start of camp session and not go out in public places or interact with others outside of their household during their home quarantine or en-route to camp. Campers and and staff are to undergo a pre-arrival health screening concerning symptoms and risk factors related to COVID-19. This screening must be completed in the 7 days before arrival at camp. Campers and staff are to be screened again upon arrival.   Any person (staff, volunteer, or camper) who develops any of the above symptoms must be tested for COVID-19 using an appropriately collected nasopharyngeal swab. Camp medical directors should be the ordering clinician for all COVID-19 specimen collection and testing conducted through the camp.

All dental patients will be pre-screened for symptoms of COVID-19 and with an in-office temperature check prior to treatment. Patients with an elevated temperature or symptoms of COVID-19 should be instructed to contact their primary care provider and rescheduled for their dental procedure.

Places of worship should develop a system and process that builds in social distancing at all times so that participants are separated by at least 6 feet of space when entering, kneeling/sitting/standing and participating in worship, and leaving the service. Where lines of people may form (e.g., entry, exit, receiving sacraments, veneration of religious objects, processionals) the floor should be clearly marked to delineate 6 feet distances between participants. Places of worship must not use shared or communal religious items that require physical contact. Ex: hand-held donation receptacles, shared bibles, shared cups and plates.

Funeral service attendees should wear cloth face coverings at all times when inside the funeral establishment. Close contact with others (e.g. hugging or shaking hands) is discouraged. Condolences should be provided from a distance of at least 6 feet. Funeral homes should develop ways for attendees to be able to show condolences that do not require close contact within 6 feet of a person.  Tissues and no-touch trash cans should be made readily available for drying eyes and blowing noses with hand sanitizer readily available.

Employers must develop a process for screening all employees reporting for work for COVID-19 related symptoms. An employee must be assigned to take and document the temperatures of all employees before they enter the workplace. The screener must also ask the questions regarding symptoms and contacts listed in Exhibit A of the policy. Employees found to have signs and symptoms must be instructed to leave the premises and seek medical advice. Employers must maintain the confidentiality of their employees' health information.

People must maintain a physical distance of at least 6 feet from others at all times even when in the pool. A limited number of spectators can be allowed at swim events but they must be limited to close/immediate family members of the athletes. Swim events will not be open to the public and should not be advertised publicly.  All mouth-based activities that are often encountered during swim events, such as spitting in the pool or filling one’s mouth with water and then releasing the water back into the pool, shall not be allowed.

Fitness center and gym members are required to thoroughly clean and disinfect used equipment (machines, benches, bars, dumbbells, weights, sporting equipment, etc.) after each use. If fitness class equipment or machines cannot be physically moved to accommodate spacing and distance requirements, then fitness class equipment or machines should be taken out of order. "Group recreational activities outside of structured classes are allowed (i.e., pick-up games of racquetball, volleyball, basketball, group sparing sessions, etc.) for groups of 10 or less." Fitness center and gym members who do not comply with requirements must be asked to leave the facility. Repeat offenders must not have access the facility or classes until the facility is allowed to return to normal operations At least 30 minutes between classes to allow for appropriate ventilation of the fitness room and cleaning and disinfection of the floor and commonly touched surfaces.
Cosmetologists, barbers, manicurists, pedicurists, estheticians, and tanning facilities may offer all services as long as clients are capable of wearing cloth face coverings at all times.

Food service workers who are sick must stay home and seek out COVID-19 testing. Suspected or confirmed cases must self-isolate at home for a minimum of 10 days from the onset of symptoms and at least three days from the resolution of fever (without the use of fever reducing medications) and the improvement of other symptoms.
Golf course may remain open with some restrictions.

Authorizes outdoor dining. Outdoor dining areas must be disinfected. If the outdoor expansion is in a shared space, the business or organization must coordinate and seek approval from applicable local authorities.

All childcare employees must wear face coverings at all times. It is NOT recommended that young children wear masks or other face coverings. Childcare employees must supervise children to ensure proper hand-washing and safe use of alcohol based hand sanitizer. Hand sanitizer should be kept out of reach of children. Frequently touched surfaces, including door handles, toys, chairs, tables, must be disinfected frequently. Childcare facilities must have a Safety Data Sheet (SDS) for each chemical used in the facility. Pick-up/drop-off times should be staggered to reduce congregation. Facilities should consistently keep the same groups of children and staff together and avoid intermixing or interaction between groups. They should increase outdoor play time, but stagger groups.

Signage must be prominently posted throughout the establishment to ask customers if they are experiencing COVID-19 symptoms. Menus must be sanitized between uses (disposable menus encouraged). No "self-serve" utensils or buffet style dining.

Lodgings, including hotels, motels, inns, and short-term rentals, may only accept overnight reservations from New Hampshire residents, or out of state visitors who have met the 14 day quarantine requirement. Reservations may be accepted by phone, online, or in person. Elevators, if present in the facility, should be limited to one person or associated reservation group at a time. Lines for elevator use should be clearly marked with demarcations on the floor spaced at least 6 feet apart for where people should stand to wait for an elevator.

Parks must post signage and messaging about COVID-19 and the need for social distancing, frequent hand hygiene/washing, and cloth face covering use when in public places.  Parks must make hand washing stations and alcohol-based hand sanitizer readily available where able. Measures to be taken to limit occupancy at in-land beaches.

Creating non-COVID-19 care zones within the facility, such as dedicated wings for hospitalized patients, should be done if possible, by segregating patients, clarifying safe patient flow coming into the building, and circulation within the building. Hospitals should have transfer agreements in place with other hospitals in their region to treat both COVID and non-COVID patients if those hospitals have that capability, when necessary, and when appropriate.

policy_subtarget: Minors and children; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare)
policy_description: Summer day camps/playground programs may resume operation according to the guidelines listed in Emergency Order #52. Day camp staff and campers must be either New Hampshire residents or must meet the 14 day quarantine requirement.  All day camp staff must wear cloth masks. Older children and parents must also wear masks when distancing from other staff, parents, and children is not possible. Any person who develops symptoms of COVID-19 while at the day camp must be masked if they are over 2 years of age, removed from contact with others, and be immediately sent home.  Camps must develop drop-off and pick-up processes which stagger arrivals/departures of children and parents/guardians to avoid interaction and congregation. Day camps should attempt to divide staff and children into small groups of ideally no more than 10 people total, including children and staff. Groups should be kept consistent (no floating staff) and separated from other groups. Each group should have its own activity equipment. Campers should be kept outdoors as much as possible.
Campsites must be limited to 6-8 occupants depending upon campground and campsite configuration. Campground reservations must be done in advance online or by phone.

Dental staff must follow ADA, CDC, and OSHA guidelines for face coverings and other PPE. If ADA, CDC or OSHA approved PPE is not available to safely treat patients, patients are to be referred to providers who have that equipment.

Amateur and youth sports limited to outdoor, low-physical contact sporting events.  All youth and amateur sport event staff and spectators must wear masks. Athletes must wear masks when not actively participating in athletics. Staff, athletes, and volunteers must be screened on arrival to each competitive sporting event, training session, or practice. All staff, athletes and volunteers must have their temperatures taken and shall be asked regarding signs, symptoms, and travel risk factors. Practices and training sessions may begin and are allowed for groups of up to 50 participants No teams/groups/athletes other than from New Hampshire, Maine, and Vermont are allowed at the competitive sporting events, training sessions, or practices in New Hampshire.  Shared equipment provided by staff or volunteers must be cleaned and disinfected according to CDC guidance after every use between athletes and at the completion of each practice, training session, or sporting event. A limited number of spectators will be allowed at competitive sporting events, and must be limited to close/immediate family of athletes. Competitive sporting events will not be open to the public and should not be advertised publicly.  “Mass Starts” are allowable where all participants have enough space to remain at least 6 feet apart. In cases where space limitations prohibit a mass start, a staggered start format will be necessary to reduce the number of people at start line.

All employees must wear a cloth face covering while at work and in potential close contact with others. Employees must maintain at least 6 feet of distance between one another at all times. Employers must implement workplace cleaning and disinfection practices following CDC guidelines. They must also promote frequent hand-washing and make hand sanitizer readily available. Employers must allow employees to work from home as much as is practical.

Manufacturing companies should stagger shifts, breaks, and meals, in compliance with wage and hour laws and regulations to maintain social distancing. If possible, have employees take breaks outside, weather permitting.
Asymptomatic food service workers who have had contact with a suspected or confirmed case must quarantine themselves at home for 14 days from their last exposure before returning to work.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Minors and children
policy_description: New Hampshire schools retain the flexibility to provide traditional in-person instruction, distance learning, or hybrid instruction that encompasses aspects of both in-person and distance learning.  It is expected, however, that schools will operate using in-person instruction to the extent possible based on the factors set forth in the Guidance. Each school must take any and all necessary steps to meet its obligation to provide a free and appropriate education to each of its students.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Minors and children
policy_description: School districts may conduct "distance education." The district shall create a plan that shall include procedures for participation by all students. Academic work shall be equivalent in effort and rigor to typical classroom work. The local school board shall be responsible for the approval, coordination, and supervision of distance education courses offered by the school district.
Campgrounds may be open to New Hampshire residents, members, or out of state visitors who have met the 14-day quarantine requirement.
Funeral homes may resume operation according to the guidance in Emergency Order #52.

Authorizes indoor dining in Belknap, Coos, Carrol, Cheshire, Sullivan and Grafton Counties. However, seated dining areas are limited in capacity to the number of people where table spacing (6 ft between patrons at adjacent tables) is able to be maintained. The same applies to Rockingham, Hillsborough, Merrimack and Strafford County, however, seated dining is also limited to 50 percent capacity of the permitted occupancy based on New Hampshire’s Building and Fire Code. Staggered reservations to avoid congregation and maximum six guests per table.
Lodgings, including hotels, motels, inns, and short-term rentals, may be opened to the public with restrictions.
Public and commercial pools are allowed to be opened according to the guidelines of Emergency Order #52.

Amateur and youth sports limited to outdoor, low-physical contact sporting events.  All youth and amateur sport event staff and spectators must wear masks. Athletes must wear masks when not actively participating in athletics. Staff, athletes, and volunteers must be screened on arrival to each competitive sporting event, training session, or practice. All staff, athletes and volunteers must have their temperatures taken and shall be asked regarding signs, symptoms, and travel risk factors. Practices and training sessions may begin and are allowed for groups of up to 50 participants No teams/groups/athletes other than from New Hampshire, Maine, and Vermont are allowed at the competitive sporting events, training sessions, or practices in New Hampshire.  Shared equipment provided by staff or volunteers must be cleaned and disinfected according to CDC guidance after every use between athletes and at the completion of each practice, training session, or sporting event. A limited number of spectators will be allowed at competitive sporting events, and must be limited to close/immediate family of athletes. Competitive sporting events will not be open to the public and should not be advertised publicly.  “Mass Starts” are allowable where all participants have enough space to remain at least 6 feet apart. In cases where space limitations prohibit a mass start, a staggered start format will be necessary to reduce the number of people at start line.

All dental patients will be pre-screened for symptoms of COVID-19 and with an in-office temperature check prior to treatment. Patients with an elevated temperature or symptoms of COVID-19 should be instructed to contact their primary care provider and rescheduled for their dental procedure.

Authorizes outdoor dining. Outdoor dining areas must be disinfected. If the outdoor expansion is in a shared space, the business or organization must coordinate and seek approval from applicable local authorities.

Lodgings, including hotels, motels, inns, and short-term rentals, may only accept overnight reservations from New Hampshire residents, or out of state visitors who have met the 14 day quarantine requirement. Reservations may be accepted by phone, online, or in person. Elevators, if present in the facility, should be limited to one person or associated reservation group at a time. Lines for elevator use should be clearly marked with demarcations on the floor spaced at least 6 feet apart for where people should stand to wait for an elevator.

All childcare employees must wear face coverings at all times. It is NOT recommended that young children wear masks or other face coverings. Childcare employees must supervise children to ensure proper hand-washing and safe use of alcohol based hand sanitizer. Hand sanitizer should be kept out of reach of children. Frequently touched surfaces, including door handles, toys, chairs, tables, must be disinfected frequently. Childcare facilities must have a Safety Data Sheet (SDS) for each chemical used in the facility. Pick-up/drop-off times should be staggered to reduce congregation. Facilities should consistently keep the same groups of children and staff together and avoid intermixing or interaction between groups. They should increase outdoor play time, but stagger groups.

policy_subtarget: Minors and children; Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare)
policy_description: Summer day camps/playground programs may resume operation according to the guidelines listed in Emergency Order #52. Day camp staff and campers must be either New Hampshire residents or must meet the 14 day quarantine requirement.  All day camp staff must wear cloth masks. Older children and parents must also wear masks when distancing from other staff, parents, and children is not possible. Any person who develops symptoms of COVID-19 while at the day camp must be masked if they are over 2 years of age, removed from contact with others, and be immediately sent home.  Camps must develop drop-off and pick-up processes which stagger arrivals/departures of children and parents/guardians to avoid interaction and congregation. Day camps should attempt to divide staff and children into small groups of ideally no more than 10 people total, including children and staff. Groups should be kept consistent (no floating staff) and separated from other groups. Each group should have its own activity equipment. Campers should be kept outdoors as much as possible.

Fitness center and gym members are required to thoroughly clean and disinfect used equipment (machines, benches, bars, dumbbells, weights, sporting equipment, etc.) after each use. If fitness class equipment or machines cannot be physically moved to accommodate spacing and distance requirements, then fitness class equipment or machines should be taken out of order. "Group recreational activities outside of structured classes are allowed (i.e., pick-up games of racquetball, volleyball, basketball, group sparing sessions, etc.) for groups of 10 or less." Fitness center and gym members who do not comply with requirements must be asked to leave the facility. Repeat offenders must not have access the facility or classes until the facility is allowed to return to normal operations At least 30 minutes between classes to allow for appropriate ventilation of the fitness room and cleaning and disinfection of the floor and commonly touched surfaces.
Cosmetologists, barbers, manicurists, pedicurists, estheticians, and tanning facilities may offer all services as long as clients are capable of wearing cloth face coverings at all times.

Dental staff must follow ADA, CDC, and OSHA guidelines for face coverings and other PPE. If ADA, CDC or OSHA approved PPE is not available to safely treat patients, patients are to be referred to providers who have that equipment.

Signage must be prominently posted throughout the establishment to ask customers if they are experiencing COVID-19 symptoms. Menus must be sanitized between uses (disposable menus encouraged). No "self-serve" utensils or buffet style dining.

Parks must post signage and messaging about COVID-19 and the need for social distancing, frequent hand hygiene/washing, and cloth face covering use when in public places.  Parks must make hand washing stations and alcohol-based hand sanitizer readily available where able. Measures to be taken to limit occupancy at in-land beaches.

Food service workers who are sick must stay home and seek out COVID-19 testing. Suspected or confirmed cases must self-isolate at home for a minimum of 10 days from the onset of symptoms and at least three days from the resolution of fever (without the use of fever reducing medications) and the improvement of other symptoms.

Visitors will not be allowed on camp property during periods of group quarantine. Visitors will be limited to essential service providers for the duration of the camp session. Camps must plan for systematically perform daily temperature and symptom screenings on all staff, adults, teenagers, and children on the camp. Camps must plan for isolation of symptomatic people and quarantine of anybody exposed to a person who is undergoing COVID-19 testing or has confirmed COVID-19. Camps should identify a local New Hampshire medical director for the camp who is an M.D., D.O., or APRN. Camps must train camp medical staff on use of appropriate COVID-19 personal protective equipment (PPE), which involves at a minimum wearing a medical gown, gloves, surgical face mask, and eye protection (face shield or goggles) when evaluating a person with COVID19 symptoms. All out-of-state staff and volunteers must arrive at the camp at least 14 days before the official start of camp. During this 14-day pre-camp session, staff and volunteers should be undergoing temperature and symptom monitoring Any campers coming from out-of-state must quarantine in NH for at least 14 days before camp, or attest to home quarantine in their home state in the 14 days before start of camp session and not go out in public places or interact with others outside of their household during their home quarantine or en-route to camp. Campers and and staff are to undergo a pre-arrival health screening concerning symptoms and risk factors related to COVID-19. This screening must be completed in the 7 days before arrival at camp. Campers and staff are to be screened again upon arrival.   Any person (staff, volunteer, or camper) who develops any of the above symptoms must be tested for COVID-19 using an appropriately collected nasopharyngeal swab. Camp medical directors should be the ordering clinician for all COVID-19 specimen collection and testing conducted through the camp.

Manufacturing companies should stagger shifts, breaks, and meals, in compliance with wage and hour laws and regulations to maintain social distancing. If possible, have employees take breaks outside, weather permitting.

Employers must develop a process for screening all employees reporting for work for COVID-19 related symptoms. An employee must be assigned to take and document the temperatures of all employees before they enter the workplace. The screener must also ask the questions regarding symptoms and contacts listed in Exhibit A of the policy. Employees found to have signs and symptoms must be instructed to leave the premises and seek medical advice. Employers must maintain the confidentiality of their employees' health information.
Golf course may remain open with some restrictions.

Places of worship should develop a system and process that builds in social distancing at all times so that participants are separated by at least 6 feet of space when entering, kneeling/sitting/standing and participating in worship, and leaving the service. Where lines of people may form (e.g., entry, exit, receiving sacraments, veneration of religious objects, processionals) the floor should be clearly marked to delineate 6 feet distances between participants. Places of worship must not use shared or communal religious items that require physical contact. Ex: hand-held donation receptacles, shared bibles, shared cups and plates.

Creating non-COVID-19 care zones within the facility, such as dedicated wings for hospitalized patients, should be done if possible, by segregating patients, clarifying safe patient flow coming into the building, and circulation within the building. Hospitals should have transfer agreements in place with other hospitals in their region to treat both COVID and non-COVID patients if those hospitals have that capability, when necessary, and when appropriate.

Funeral service attendees should wear cloth face coverings at all times when inside the funeral establishment. Close contact with others (e.g. hugging or shaking hands) is discouraged. Condolences should be provided from a distance of at least 6 feet. Funeral homes should develop ways for attendees to be able to show condolences that do not require close contact within 6 feet of a person.  Tissues and no-touch trash cans should be made readily available for drying eyes and blowing noses with hand sanitizer readily available.
Asymptomatic food service workers who have had contact with a suspected or confirmed case must quarantine themselves at home for 14 days from their last exposure before returning to work.
Campsites must be limited to 6-8 occupants depending upon campground and campsite configuration. Campground reservations must be done in advance online or by phone.

All employees must wear a cloth face covering while at work and in potential close contact with others. Employees must maintain at least 6 feet of distance between one another at all times. Employers must implement workplace cleaning and disinfection practices following CDC guidelines. They must also promote frequent hand-washing and make hand sanitizer readily available. Employers must allow employees to work from home as much as is practical.

People must maintain a physical distance of at least 6 feet from others at all times even when in the pool. A limited number of spectators can be allowed at swim events but they must be limited to close/immediate family members of the athletes. Swim events will not be open to the public and should not be advertised publicly.  All mouth-based activities that are often encountered during swim events, such as spitting in the pool or filling one’s mouth with water and then releasing the water back into the pool, shall not be allowed.

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); General population (inclusive)
policy_description: Retail stores must develop a process for limiting the number of customers inside a store at a given time, implement one-way aisles (or other traffic patterns) if possible, and  implement pay-ahead and curbside pickup and/or delivery service options if possible. Retail stores should consider dedicated shopping hours or appointment times for the elderly and medically vulnerable persons. Retail stores must use plastic shields or barriers between customers and clerks at service counters and clean them frequently. Retail stores must assign task management-level employees within the store (i.e. a safety officer) to monitor and enforce compliance with face-covering, distancing, and other COVID-19 safety policies.
Lodgings, including hotels, motels, inns, and short-term rentals, may be opened to the public with restrictions.
Funeral homes may resume operation according to the guidance in Emergency Order #52.
Public and commercial pools are allowed to be opened according to the guidelines of Emergency Order #52.

Staggered reservations to avoid congregation and maximum six guests per table.

Employers must implement workplace cleaning and disinfection practices following CDC guidelines. They must also promote frequent hand-washing and make hand sanitizer readily available. Employers must allow employees to work from home as much as is practical.

Parks must make hand washing stations and alcohol-based hand sanitizer readily available where able. Measures to be taken to limit occupancy at in-land beaches.
