Reservations may be accepted by phone, online, or in person. Elevators, if present in the facility, should be limited to one person or associated reservation group at a time. Lines for elevator use should be clearly marked with demarcations on the floor spaced at least 6 feet apart for where people should stand to wait for an elevator.

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); General population (inclusive)
policy_description: Retail stores must develop a process for limiting the number of customers inside a store at a given time, implement one-way aisles (or other traffic patterns) if possible, and  implement pay-ahead and curbside pickup and/or delivery service options if possible. Retail stores should consider dedicated shopping hours or appointment times for the elderly and medically vulnerable persons. Retail stores must use plastic shields or barriers between customers and clerks at service counters and clean them frequently. Retail stores must assign task management-level employees within the store (i.e. a safety officer) to monitor and enforce compliance with face-covering, distancing, and other COVID-19 safety policies.

policy_subtarget: Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Casinos/gambling facilities
policy_description: Casinos, places of entertainment (including concert venues, nightclubs, racetracks, movie theaters, and performing arts centers) and gyms and fitness centers and classes will be closed beginning March 16.
All higher education instutition will cease in-person instruction beginning March 18.
All preschool and K-12 schools will be closed beginning March 18.

policy_subtarget: Indoor spaces; Non-governmental organizations; Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Public and private social clubs (including but not limited to facilities owned or operated by the American Legion, Veterans of Foreign Wars, Knights of Columbus, and any other social clubs associated with community service organizations) must close to the public.

Personal care facilities that cannot maintain social distancing in their services (including but not limited to cosmetology shops, barber shops, beauty salons, hair braiding shops, nail salons, spas, electrology facilities, massage parlors, tanning salons, tattoo parlors) must close to the public. Health facilities that provide medically necessary or therapeutic services are exempted from this directive.
All preschool and K-12 schools will remain closed.
Non-essential businesses must close.
All institutions of higher education shall continue to remain closed.

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist)
policy_description: Blood drives are exempt from the terms and conditions of EO 107 regarding gatherings. Nothing in EO No. 107 (2020) limits, prohibits, or restricts the ability of New Jersey residents to participate in blood drives, including leaving their homes or places of residences to do so.

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist)
policy_description: Blood drives must incorporate mitigation efforts including social distancing practices, collecting blood from only individuals who are healthy and feeling well at the time of donation, conducting temperature screens of both staff and donors before entering a blood drive, requiring the use of PPE, providing hand sanitizer to donors, and practicing surface sanitation

Extends certain statutory deadlines for school districts with elections in May, including 1) the governing body of the municipality presenting and certifying a tax levy to the county board of taxation and 2) districts giving notice to nontenured teaching staff members whether they will be employed for the following year.
The primary elections on June 2 have been postponed to July 7.

Restaurants, cafeterias, food courts, bars, etc. that are still permitted to operate must adopt policies that contain the following provisions: limit occupancy to 10% maximum capacity, practice social distancing, require infection control practices, allow employees time for handwashing, arrange for contactless pay, pickup, and/or delivery options wherever feasible, provide sanitization materials, practice surface sanitation, maintain proper signage, require workers to wear gloves

NJ TRANSIT and private carrier companies (including bus and light rail services, bus services, and Access Link paratransit services) must adopt the following policies (varying by category of private carrier companies): occupancy of NJ TRANSIT limited to 50% of the stated maximum vehicle capacity on all trains, buses and light rail lines, require infection control practices, contactless pay options, maintain proper social distancing when feasible, practice surface sanitation, maintain proper signage, and require workers to wear gloves when in contact with customers.

Extends various deadlines associated with rulemaking for state agencies until 90 days following the end of the public health emergency. Allows for any rules or emergency rules that would expire during the current public health emergency to be extended until 90 days following the end of the public health emergency.

Extends Retired Officer Carry Permits that expire during the term of Public Health Emergency until 90 days after the Public Health Emergency ends. The order creates a process for applicants seeking to obtain or renew a Carry Permit to complete training, practice, or testing required by law.

policy_subtarget: Essential business (inclusive); Retail stores (not including food); Churches/places of worship
policy_description: Stores that principally sell items necessary for religious observation or worship shall be considered essential retail businesses, provided that they adopt in-person operation policies that include social distancing practices detailed in paragraph 1 of Executive Order No. 122 (2020).

Licensees, owners, operators, employees, or independent contractors of personal care services facilities ordered to be closed to the public in Executive Order No. 107 (2020), are not permitted to provide personal care services in their own homes, the homes of others, or in any facility or business setting unless the individual personal care service provider is providing the service to their household members, immediate family or other individuals with whom the personal care service provider has a close personal relationship.

policy_subtarget: Essential business (inclusive); Retail stores (not including food)
policy_description: Pet grooming, pet daycare, and pet boarding businesses shall be considered essential retail businesses permitted to open so long as they abide by in-person operation policies including social distancing practices detailed in paragraph 1 of Executive Order No. 122 (2020).

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Public sector/government employees
policy_description: Shooting ranges that are closed to the public may only offer access to individuals seeking to obtain or renew a Carry Permit that must complete training, practice, or testing required by law. Social distancing practices must be maintained.

County and municipal clerks are allowed to accept initiative and referendum petitions electronically. Signatures for these petitions are allowed to be collected electronically. Hand signatures obtained prior to the effective date of this Executive Order shall also be accepted.

State parks and forests, county parks (determined by the locality), and golf courses (with the exception of miniature golf courses or driving ranges) can reopen to the public. Passive recreation including fishing, hunting, boating, canoeing, hiking, walking, running or jogging, biking, birding, and horseback riding at state parks and forests is permitted.
Counties are allowed to determine whether their parks will be open or closed. State parks and golf courses are now open.

Golf courses must implement social distancing policies including implementing electronic or telephone reservation and payment systems, spacing out tee times, limiting persons using golf carts, practicing surface sanitation, closing golf center buildings, pro shops, and other buildings and amenities; etc.

State parks and forests must implement restrictions including limiting parking to 50% of maximum capacity and prohibiting parking in undesignated areas, prohibiting picnics, requiring social distancing, banning organized or contact activities or sports and gatherings of any kind.

policy_subtarget: Essential business (inclusive); Housing sector; Churches/places of worship
policy_description: Construction of new religious facilities or construction involving existing religious facilities shall be considered essential construction projects.

policy_subtarget: Essential business (inclusive); Housing sector; Churches/places of worship
policy_description: Essential construction of new religious facilities must abide by all conditions of Executive Order No. 122 (2020), including social distancing and health guidelines.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Recreational and entertainment activities prohibited under Executive Order No. 107 are also prohibited from taking place within the brick-and-mortar premises of essential retail businesses that are permitted to remain open. Recreational and entertainment activities are also prohibited within the facilities of public, private, and parochial preschool programs, or elementary and secondary schools, including charter and renaissance schools that remain closed to students.
Retail businesses may begin curbside pickup
Nonessential construction may resume
Car gatherings are permitted (ex: drive in movie theaters)

Businesses conducting construction projects must adhere to the following requirements: prohibit non-essential visitors, follow social distance guidelines (including in pickup/ delivery of equipment or materials), limit meetings/ workgroups to fewer than 10 people, limit number of individuals in "high-risk areas," stagger work times and lunch breaks to limit individuals on worksite, provide hand washing stations, carry out infection control practices, practice surface sanitation, post signs with these guidelines
Allowing a vote-by-mail election for the July 7th primary

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Retail stores (not including food); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Allows charter fishing services and for-hire vessel activities, as well as watercraft rental businesses (following curb side pickup restrictions), to open with required social distancing measures on Sunday, May 17 at 6 am.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Retail stores (not including food); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Charter fishing services and for-hire vessels must reduce capacity to no more than 10 people on a vessel at a time, maintain electronic reservations, practice social distancing measures on vessels and boarding areas, prohibit sharing of equipment, practice infection control, practice surface sanitation, require face coverings, prohibit food and beverage services, and brief passengers on such restrictions
Allows certain outdoor recreation businesses to reopen
Increases limit of outdoor gatherings from 10 to 25 people
Professional sports are allowed to resume
Racetracks will be able to open for racing activities and stabling on June 1st, for racing without spectators.

By 5:00 p.m. on May 31, 2020, racetrack permit holders that conduct racing shall adopt policies that include: prohibit non-essential individuals, require social distancing measures, stagger timed entry to limit individuals leaving and entering facilities, require infection control practices, provide sanitization materials, practice surface sanitation, maintain proper signage, send homes those with COVID-19 symptoms, notify individuals of possible exposure, etc.

Allows childcare services to resume provided that they comply with the COVID-19 Child Care Standards and other applicable statutes, regulations, and Executive Orders. Child care services must submit an attestation to the Department of Children and Families no later than 24 hours prior to the anticipated opening date
Organized sports are allowed to resume provided that activities remain outdoors and are non-contact. Sporting activities that involve person-to-person contact or close proximity remain prohibited.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Secondary education
policy_description: High school sports under the jurisdiction of the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association (NJSIAA) may resume only in accordance with reopening protocols issued by NJSIAA, and cannot resume any earlier than June 30.

Youth day camps are allowed to begin provided that they comply with the COVID-19 Child Care and Youth Summer Camp Standards and other applicable statutes, regulations, and Executive Orders. Residential and overnight camps are prohibited from operating. Youth day camps must submit an attestation to the Department of Health no later than 24 hours prior to the anticipated opening date.
Retail businesses are allowed to resume
Outdoor and indoor dining allowed to resume
Salons and barber shops allowed to resume
Picnic Areas and Pavilions may be open to the public including at all State Parks and Forests.

Establishments with liquor licenses will be temporarily allowed to expand their licensed premises into outdoor areas that are either contiguous or non-contiguous to their permanently licensed premises. Establishments may apply through the POSSE ABC Online Licensing system, and if approved will be issued a temporary permit effective on June 15th that will run until November 14, 2020.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Retail stores (not including food)
policy_description: Effective at 6:00 a.m. on Monday, June 15, 2020, the brick-and-mortar premises of non-essential retail businesses can reopen.
Allows outdoor dining at food or beverage establishments in New Jersey starting on Monday, June 15th.

Food and beverage establishments are subject to the following requirements: a limit of 8 customers per table, at least six feet of distance between parties, food or beverage establishments are required to prohibit smoking in any outdoor areas designated for the consumption of food and/or beverages.

Outdoor recreational and entertainment businesses are permitted to reopen immediately besides amusement parks, water parks, and arcades. Businesses permitted to reopen are subject to social distancing and infection control measures.
Outdoor gatherings are limited to 100 people, and attendees are required to be six feet apart
Outdoor swimming pools can open

Students, who may be accompanied by parents or guardians, may enter school premises to retrieve personal belongings from lockers, classrooms, or other areas provided the district and/or school has protocols in place regarding social distancing and mitigation practices
Special events, including fireworks displays, at public and private beaches, boardwalks, lakes, and lakeshores are permitted, subject to the restrictions on outdoor gatherings

policy_subtarget: Restaurants/bars; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Restaurants, indoor recreational and entertainment businesses, and public and private social clubs are permitted to allow individuals indoors to tour their facilities for event-planning purposes

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Bicycle shops, boat dealerships, car and used car dealerships, farming equipment stores, federal firearms licensees, livestock feed stores, mobile phone retail and repair shops, motorcycle dealerships, car washes, and nurseries and garden centers can operate according to the requirements placed on essential retail businesses

Municipal, county, and State public libraries and all libraries at public and private colleges and universities are allowed curbside pickup and can reopen their outdoor spaces to the public beginning at 6:00 a.m. on Monday, June 15. Patrons shall not be permitted to enter the brick-and-mortar premises.

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Housing sector
policy_description: Open houses to view real estate and yard and garage sales are permitted, provided they comply with the restrictions on indoor gatherings, including the requirement that attendees wear face coverings
Personal care facilities are allowed to reopen

Personal care facilities are subject to the following restrictions: limiting services to appointment-only, performing health screening upon entry to facility, requiring use of PPE, requiring clients to wear face coverings at all times (unless inhibiting health), practice social distancing, adopt cleaning practices

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Indoor spaces
policy_description: Shared space tutoring service facilities remain closed to students and clients.

Libraries permitted to open to the public are subject to the following requirements: patrons cannot enter the brick-and-mortar premises, but are permitted curbside pickup/drop-off, in-premise operations are limited to employees responsible for curbside pickup/drop-off, transactions will avoid person-to-person contact, wherever feasible, efforts will be made to schedule patrons arrival times in advance, and designated employees shall bring materials outside of the facility and place the materials directly in a patron’s vehicle whenever feasible. Libraries must also adopt policies including at minimum establishing hours of operation for high risk individuals, requiring infection control practices, practicing surface sanitation, requiring workers to wear gloves, etc.

policy_subtarget: Restaurants/bars; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Dining establishments, public and private social clubs, and indoor recreational and entertainment businesses that can allow individuals to enter their indoor premises for event-planning purposes can allow monetary transactions on their premises, but only for the purpose of securing venue space.

Clarification that permitted non-contact organized sporting activities in outdoor areas also includes non-contact organized sporting activities at public and private beaches, boardwalks, lakes, and lakeshores.
Clarification that libraries, which can engage in “curbside pickup/drop-off” are also permitted to deliver materials to patrons

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Indoor spaces
policy_description: Indoor portions of retail shopping malls including retail kiosks may open to members of the public, effective at 6:00 a.m. on Monday, June 29, 2020. Businesses located within the indoor portions of retail shopping malls such as entertainment and recreational businesses (including gyms, fitness centers, movie theaters, amusement parks, water parks, and arcades) shall remain closed. Valet parking, vending machines, stroller rentals, and any type of communal play area shall remain closed.

policy_subtarget: Personal care facilities; Retail stores (not including food)
policy_description: Personal care service facilities located in the interior of shopping malls are permitted to reopen to the public as long as they comply with adaptation measures of Executive Order No. 154 (2020).

Food and beverage establishments located within the interior of a retail shopping mall are restricted to offering takeout and delivery services, but they may provide in-person service at outdoor areas outside the shopping mall in conformance with the requirements of Executive Order No. 150 (2020).

In-person instruction of students for curricula that requires labs, technical, clinical, or hands-on instruction and cannot be readily taught virtually allowed at institutes of higher education. Trade and training schools are allowed to reopen for in-person instruction so long as they follow specific health and safety polices.

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Indoor spaces
policy_description: Indoor shopping malls must adopt policies that include, at minimum, the following requirements: install physical barriers between customers and employees, require infection control practices, establish policies to minimize congestion, implement social distancing policies, provide employees break time for repeated handwashing, provide sanitization materials, require surface sanitation, place signage of measures at entrances, require employees to wear gloves and face coverings. Retail businesses located in the interior of shopping malls must comply with the requirements contained in Paragraph 1 of Executive Order No. 122 (2020). All areas with communal seating shall be removed or cordoned off. Isolated seats or benches may remain available.
Indoor gatherings are limited to 25 percent of capacity with maximum of 100 people

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Outdoor gatherings are limited to 250 people

New Jersey recommended that all travelers quarantine for 14 days upon arrival if they are coming from a U.S. state with a large number of cases (test positivity rate >10% or >10 positive tests per 100,000 residents, both on a 7-day rolling average). New Jersey did so simultaneously and in coordination with New York and Connecticut, which both required the quarantine for travelers (while New Jersey recommended it).
Clarification that retail businesses 50% capacity limitation will not include the retail establishment's employees.

Indoor recreation and entertainment businesses, libraries, museums, aquariums, and public and private social clubs can open with 25 percent capacity on July 2. Indoor reopening excludes gyms and fitness centers, movie theaters, performing arts centers, other concert venues, and indoor amusement and water parks.
Playgrounds (including playgrounds at pool facilities) can reopen to the public on July 2 at 6 am.

Gyms can open for individual instruction by appointment. Simultaneous instructions at the same facility must take place in separate rooms or be separated by a floor-to-ceiling barrier that complies with all fire code requirements.
Food and beverage establishments are permitted to offer in-person service indoors effective at 6:00 a.m. on Thursday, July 2, 2020.

Personal care services that would require the removal of a face covering (ie. facials) can resume on July 2 as well, subject to otherwise applicable requirements issued by the Division of Consumer Affairs and the Department of Health.

Food and beverage establishments indoors and outdoors are subject to the following requirements: limit patrons indoors to 25% of indoor capacity (excluding employees), ensure tables are six feet apart, require patrons to wear face coverings inside premises (except when seated), and patrons may only order, be served, and consume food or beverage when seated
Temporary stops resumption of indoor dining

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Casinos/gambling facilities; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Prohibits the consumption of food or beverages and smoking in the indoor premises of any retail, recreational, or entertainment business, including casinos, where masks are strictly required.
Outdoor gatherings are limited to 500 people
As of 6:00 a.m. on July 3, 2020, racetrack permit holders are permitted to open their premises to the public, which includes racetracks and stabling facilities

Policies required to be adopted by the racetrack permit holders as listed in paragraph 2 of Administrative Order No. 2020-14 are amended to include the following: restaurants are permitted to offer outdoor dining and shall limit their outdoor capacity to 100% of the restaurant’s combined indoor and outdoor capacity prior to the expansion of outdoor capacity during this Public Health Emergency; indoor dining is prohibited; restaurants within sports wagering lounges may offer outdoor dining and outdoor dining capacity shall be equal to the indoor capacity of the sports wagering lounge; individuals granted admission to the racetrack facility shall count towards the State gathering limits for outdoor gatherings except those dining at restaurants or within a sports wagering lounge; individuals should remain in the grandstands and other outdoor areas

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Restaurants/bars; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Definition of "outdoor areas" is revised to be defined as open air spaces that either 1) have no roof or cover or 2) have a fixed roof or temporary or seasonal awning or cover, with at least two open sides that would comprise over 50 percent of the total wall space if the space were fully enclosed. Food or beverage establishments are permitted to offer in-person service at such outdoor areas.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Practices and competitions for sports defined as “Low Risk” are permitted in both outdoor and indoor settings. No-contact practices for sports defined as “High or Medium Risk” are permitted to resume in outdoor and indoor settings. Contact practices and competitions for sports defined as “Medium Risk” are permitted to resume in outdoor settings only. Contact practices and competitions for sports defined as “High Risk” remain prohibited in both indoor and outdoor settings.
Postponement of annual municipal party committee meetings  to be held on July 27th
Postponement of annual county party committee meetings to be held on July 28th
Any election scheduled for a date between July 7, 2020 and November 3, 2020, shall be postponed until November 3, 2020. No other elections may be held or proceed prior to November 3, 2020.

Lifts 50% capacity limits on NJ TRANSIT and private-carrier buses, trains, light rail vehicles and Access Link vehicles. NJ TRANSIT and private-carriers are now limited to the maximum seated capacity, effective at 8:00 p.m. on Wednesday, July 15. Individuals should practice social distancing to the best of their ability.

Employer Provided Transportation Services must practice infection control, put up proper signage of requirements, provide and require workers to wear face coverings, and prohibit the consumption of food or beverages and smoking on their vehicles
Prohibits the consumption of food or beverages and smoking in all trains, buses, and vehicles that are operated by NJ TRANSIT, private carriers, and Employer Provided Transportation Services.
Issues travel ban for 22 states
Contact practices and games are allowed to resume for certain sports
Contact practices and games are allowed to resume for certain sports

Indoor gatherings are limited to 25% of a room's capacity with maximum limit of 25 persons (change from 100 persons) and minimum limit of 10 persons. Any private residence or residential unit shall be treated as a single room.

policy_subtarget: Indoor spaces; General population (inclusive); Churches/places of worship
policy_description: Extension: Weddings, funerals, memorial services, religious services or celebrations, and political activities continue to be limited 25% of a room's capacity with a maximum limit of 100 persons and minimum limit of 10 persons.

Announcement of the implementation of a new DOH directive for the safe reopening of long-term care facilities. Before reopening, facilities must meet certain public health benchmarks including no active outbreaks, adequate infection control, weekly staff testing, adequate Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) supplies, etc.. When facilities conclude their outbreaks and implement the requirements of the DOH’s directive, they will advance in phases, and in each phase, will be able to restore services for residents and ultimately allow for indoor visitation and resumption of normal activities.
Authorizes the reopening of computer labs at public and private colleges and universities while abiding by the health, safety, and sanitation protocols of the order. Begins 6 am. August 11.

Computer labs at public and private colleges and universities must adopt the following policies: social distancing policies, hours of operation reserved for high risk individuals, infection control practices, availability of sanitation materials, practice of surface sanitation, installation of a physical barrier between staff and individuals using the computer lab, sanitation after use of computer terminal or desk

The list of states under the 14-day quarantine advisory has been updated to include Hawaii, South Dakota, and the Virgin Islands. New Mexico, Ohio, Rhode Island, and Washington were removed. Individuals traveling to or returning to New Jersey from states with high rates of COVID-19 are advised to self-quarantine for 14 days. Individuals should only leave their location of self-quarantine for medical reasons and/or food and other essential goods.

policy_subtarget: Secondary education; Primary education; Higher education
policy_description: New Jersey public and private schools are required to open for in-person instruction. Schools are only allowed remote-only instruction if they are unable to meet health and safety protocols in the state’s school reopening guidance "The Road Back." Even if schools are open for in-person learning, schools are required to have a remote learning option for parents or guardians who request it.

Executive order to create a modified vote-by-mail (VBM) election for the November 3rd General Election. Sample ballots will be suspended, and each county's elections officials are required to send VBM ballots with pre-paid postage to all active registered voters for the General Election. Voters will return their ballots to a secure drop box or at a polling location.

Polling locations must follow public health measures. There must be a  minimum of one polling place in each municipality and a minimum of 50 percent of polling places in each county for in-person voting opportunities, including accommodations for voters with disabilities. All public schools will close for in-person instruction on November 3rd for possible use as polling locations.

The deadline to allow ballots being returned through the United States Postal Service (USPS) is extended. Every vote-by-mail ballot that is postmarked on or before November 3, 2020, and that is received by November 10, 2020, at 8:00 p.m. shall be considered valid and shall be canvassed. Mis-marked ballots and those without a postmark received within forty-eight (48) hours of the closing of polls on November 3, 2020 will be considered valid.
Alaska and Delaware are added to travel advisory list

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Public sector/government employees
policy_description: The order clarifies modifications to this year’s primarily vote-by-mail (VBM) General Election. It requires county clerks to publish a notice reflecting this year's primarily vote-by-mail process; permits county boards of elections to continue counting ballots every day until counting is completed; and requires election audits to be completed by December 4, 2020.
Amusement and water parks are allowed to reopen their indoor premises to the public on Tuesday, September 1 at 6:00 a.m. so long as they adhere to health and safety standards.
Gyms and health clubs are allowed to reopen their indoor premises to the public on Tuesday, September 1 at 6:00 a.m. so long as they adhere to health and safety standards.

Indoor entertainment venues including movie theaters, performing arts centers, and concert venues may open at 25% of maximum capacity with a limit of 150 people inside at 6:00 a.m. on September 4, 2020. Facilities must follow sanitation, health and safety standards.

Resumption of indoor dining at 25% capacity with parties of no more than 8 people starting September 4 at 6 am. Food and beverage establishments must follow social distancing and health and safety standards.
Updated travel advisory to include Alaska and Montana.

Smoking in the indoor areas of any casino or casino simulcasting facility and retail sports wagering lounges that are open to the public is prohibited effective at 6:00 a.m. on Saturday, September 5, 2020.

Restaurants on racetrack premises and within sports wagering lounges are permitted to offer outdoor and indoor dining in accordance with the provisions of Executive Order No. 150 (2020) and Executive Order No. 183 (2020).

Racetrack premises shall be subject to the gatherings limits as follows: restaurants permitted for outdoor dining shall limit their outdoor capacity to 100% of the restaurant’s combined indoor and outdoor capacity prior to the expansion of outdoor capacity; restaurants that permit indoor dining shall limit their capacity to  25% capacity with parties of no more than 8 people; sports wagering lounges; sports wagering lounges must abide by the restrictions on indoor recreation/ entertainment venues of Executive Order No. 157 (2020); restaurants located within sports wagering lounges may offer outdoor and indoor dining subject to restrictions; all individuals admitted to racetrack facilities (except individuals dining at restaurants or within a sports wagering lounge) shall count towards State gathering limits for outdoor gatherings; efforts will be made to ensure individuals do not congregate in the indoor areas of the premises and remain in the grandstand and other outdoor areas

Clarification that health facilities in hotels, motels, condominiums, cooperatives, corporate offices, or other business facilities may open indoors. Health facilities open to the public must adhere to provisions of Paragraph 1 of Executive Order No. 181.
intended_duration: In effect for as long as Executive Order No. 181 (2020) remains in effect or until a subsequent amending Administrative Order is issued

policy_description: Updated travel advisory to include Delaware, Maryland, Ohio and West Virginia. Puerto Rico and U.S. Virgin Islands are removed from the travel advisory list.

The Chief Administrator of the New Jersey Motor Vehicle Commission is required to reserve one day per week or a certain time each day or each week at certain commission agency locations to offer appointments to (1) senior citizens, and (2) customers who, due to a medical condition (diagnosed and with evidenced proof) cannot wear masks or face coverings to register a newly purchased, newly acquired, or transferred motor vehicle.

Extends deadline for new State residents who moved to New Jersey during the COVID-19 public health emergency to register their vehicle and obtain a New Jersey driver's licence. New residents of New Jersey now have 120 days.
Allows residents 65 years of age or older to be eligible to use a stored photograph for each standard driver’s license or standard identification card renewal.
Authorizes the New Jersey Motor Vehicle Commission (MVC) to use stored driver's license or identification card photos for longer than 8 years to a new maximum of 12 years
Updated Quarantine Advisory list to include Puerto Rico. California, Hawaii, Maryland, Minnesota, Nevada, and Ohio are removed from the list.
Updated Quarantine Advisory list to include Arizona, Minnesota, Nevada, Rhode Island, and Wyoming.
Updated Quarantine Advisory list to include Colorado. Arizona and Virginia were removed from the list.
Updated quarantine advisory list to include New Mexico.

Executive Order 187 allows the resumption of contact practices and competitions in indoor settings for organized sports defined as “medium risk” and “high risk” by the New Jersey Department of Health’s “Guidance for Sports Activities" including hockey, basketball, cheerleading, group dance, rugby, boxing, judo, karate, taekwondo, and wrestling.

The resumption of indoor sports practices and competitions are subject to the following health and safety guidelines: indoor practices and competitions are limited to 25% of the capacity of the room, between 10 and 25 people. If number exceeds 25 including necessary individuals, then no spectators can be present. Limit cannot exceed 150 persons in the room.

Facilities and participants must abide by health and safety protocols outlined in the Department of Health’s “Guidance for Sports Activities,” such as screenings for athletes, coaches, and staff; limitations on equipment sharing; and requirements for disinfecting and sanitizing surfaces and equipment.
Updated Quarantine Advisory list to include Ohio, Michigan, and Virginia.

The Governor passed Bill S2519 that awards certain inmates and parolees (any adult inmate or juvenile within 365 days of their scheduled release) public health emergency credits during a public health emergency. Credits will not be awarded to those serving a sentence for murder or aggravated sexual assault or one who is a repetitive, compulsive sex offender.
Updated Quarantine Advisory list to include Arizona and Maryland.
Updated Quarantine Advisory list to include California and Massachusetts

policy_subtarget: Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: At 6 am on November 5, employers must require employees to maintain 6 ft of distance from each other, require wearing masks at worksite, provide sanitation materials to employees and visitors, ensure employees practice hand hygiene, clean and disinfect high-touch areas, conduct daily health checks, exclude sick employees from the workplace, and notify employees of exposure to Covid-19 at worksite.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Higher education
policy_description: Opens private tutoring facilities to students and clients
Permits vending machines and stroller rentals to operate at malls

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Athletes, coaches, referees, trainers, and other individuals necessary to the performance of a professional or collegiate sporting event are not included in the number of individuals present at a gathering. Individuals present inside facilities where indoor athletic competitions are taking place may not exceed 25% of the capacity of the room in which it takes place, and such limit may not exceed 150 persons.

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Grocery store
policy_description: Prohibits self-service food at retail businesses including grocery stores. Retail businesses shall limit self-service drink stations to those that can be routinely and effectively cleaned and disinfected.

policy_subtarget: Transportation sector/shipping/logistics; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Valet parking and communal play areas shall remain closed
Any run-off elections resulting from municipal elections held on the November General Election shall be postponed and rescheduled for Tuesday, December 15, 2020

Every vote-by-mail ballot that is postmarked (or without a postmark or mismarked) on or before December 15, 2020, that is received by December 17, 2020, at 8:00 p.m. shall be considered valid and shall be canvassed

Polling stations must limit occupancy to allow for social distancing, ensure six feet distance between voters and between voters and poll workers through a demarcation of six feet, ensure hand washing and hygiene practices, surface sanitation, allow time for hand washing, and provide sanitation materials.

Updated Quarantine Advisory list to include Oregon and Washington. Connecticut, Pennsylvania, and Delaware meet the criteria for New Jersey’s travel advisory, but due to close proximity, a 14-day quarantine is not necessary in all instances.

Indoor tables must be six feet apart. Where six feet apart is not possible, restaurants can have groups at tables indoors that are closer than six feet together if separated by barriers that comply with guidance from the Department of Health. Restaurants can set up plastic domes outdoors, limited to one group each, as additional outdoor dining space
Updated Quarantine Advisory list to include Maine and New Hampshire

Restaurants, bars, clubs, lounges, and other businesses that serve food or drinks cannot operate indoors between 10:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m.  Outdoor dining, takeout and delivery services can continue after 10:00 p.m.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Minors and children
policy_description: All interstate games and tournaments involving indoor sports, up to and including the high school level, will be prohibited. This does not include collegiate and professional sports.
Casinos cannot serve food or drinks between 10:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. (except for room service delivered to guest rooms and takeout)
Seating at the physical bar in the indoor areas of bars and restaurants will be prohibited during all operating hours

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Retail, recreational, and entertainment businesses allowed to open indoors can only stay open after 10 pm if they don't serve food or drink indoors.

policy_subtarget: Churches/places of worship; General population (inclusive); Indoor spaces
policy_description: The limit for weddings, funerals, memorial services and religious and political activities remain unchanged and will be limited to 25% of the capacity of the room in which the gathering takes place, up to a maximum of 150 individuals.
Legislative and judicial proceedings are not subject to the indoor gatherings limits.
Athletes, coaches, referees and other individuals necessary for a professional or collegiate sports competition are not counted towards the 150 person limit of outdoor gatherings.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: All outdoor gatherings will be limited to 150 individuals (except weddings, funerals, memorial services, and religious and political activities).
Indoor gathering limit will decrease from 25 to 10 people

Indoor sporting competitions and practices will be permitted to exceed the 10 person limit only for individuals necessary for the practice or competition, such as players, coaches, and referees, but may not exceed 150 individuals.  For most indoor sports, this will mean that there can be no spectators.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Outdoor gathering limit will decrease from 500 people to 150 people
Permits raffles to be conducted remotely at large sporting venues. Tickets can be sold and purchased electronically.

Extension of the deadline by which counties must certify the results of the election from November 20 to November 25 for counties that are unable to meet the initial deadline due to Covid-19. For counties that receive such extension, production of reports must occur on or before November 25, 2020.
Extension for all counties of the date by which statutorily-required election audits must occur from December 4 until December 11.

policy_subtarget: Secondary education; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Clarification that athletes, coaches, referees, trainers, and other individuals necessary to the performance of an outdoor high school sporting event are not included in the total number of individuals present at the gathering.
Modifies Executive Order No. 193 paragraph 4 such that notice in lieu of a sample ballot authorized pursuant to this subsection shall be sent "return service requested" as required by current law.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Higher education
policy_description: Postpones all special school elections (elections held outside annual school elections) from January 26, 2021 to the March 2021 special school election
Travelers and residents returning from any U.S. state or territory beyond neighboring states (New York, Connecticut, Pennsylvania, and Delaware) should self-quarantine for 14 days.
Indoor meetings of addiction groups are now limited to 25 percent of the capacity of the room in which they take place, up to a maximum of 150 individuals.

For other adult and youth sports occurring outdoors, there can be more than 25 people present but only if no unnecessary individuals (ie. spectators) are present. Athletes, coaches, referees and other individuals necessary for a professional or collegiate sports competition are not counted towards the 25-person limit.

Indoor sports practices and competitions, including group, competitive and/or organized sporting activities for youth and adults, will be prohibited. This does not include collegiate and professional sports, and private fitness classes, lessons, and trainings at gyms, studios and similar locations.
All outdoor gatherings (except for wedding ceremonies, funerals, memorial services, and religious and political activities) will be limited to 25 individuals (from the previous 150 person limit).

Indoor entertainment centers (including a movie theater, performing arts center, and other concert venues) may host a performance in an adjacent outdoor area with a maximum capacity equivalent to the facility’s indoor capacity permitted under Paragraph 6 of Executive Order No. 196.

Centers shall abide by the health and safety provisions within Paragraph 7 of Executive Order No. 157 and all applicable provisions of Executive Order No. 192 (2020) including ensuring that all individuals can remain six feet apart, practicing infection control practices, etc.

Authorizes individuals who have passed road test to use driving permit to operate motor vehicle for 60 days during COVID-19 public health emergency while they are waiting to get their probationary driver's license. The legislation allows drivers who have passed their road tests to operate vehicles under the same restrictions as a probationary license.
Modified in-person graduation companies can begin on July 6th
All visitors must have their temperature taken before entering the facility. All visitors must not have a fever.
The Department of Health announced it has ordered nursing homes and other assisted living facilities to limit visitation to people whose loved ones are receiving end-of-life care.
All visitors to a nursing facility must wash their hand or use an alcohol sanitizer.

Incarcerated persons who meet the criteria listed in Section 1 of the order shall receive a gubernatorial commutation of the remainder of their sentences. The Department of Corrections shall release these individuals on parole until the expiration of their term of imprisonment. A list of these individuals shall be provided to the Office of the Governor and the Office of the Secretary of State.
Houses of worship way hold services as long as they do not exceed 25% max occupancy and comply with the "All Together New Mexico: COVID-Safe Practices for Individuals and Employers."
All mass gatherings of 5 or more people are prohibited.
Outdoor and indoor dine-in services are permitted. Indoor services limited to 50% occupancy. Bars may not operate other than for take-out and delivery.
Houses of worship may not exceed 25% max occupancy.

Recreational Facilities such as "theaters, museums, amusement parks, concert venues, and indoor recreation and entertainment" shall remain closed. Businesses not defined as an "essential business" or "recreational facility" may open at 25% max occupancy and enforce 6ft social distancing between customers. Indoor shopping malls, barbershops, tattoo parlors and massage services may operate at 25% capacity. Close contact businesses such as hair salons may open.
Mass gatherings of more than 5 people remain prohibited.
All individuals shall wear a face covering in public settings unless eating, drinking, exercising or instructed otherwise by a healthcare provider.

All air travelers to New Mexico who have been through an airport and come from outside New Mexico are directed to self-isolate for 14 days. A list of approved activities for those under self-quarantine is outlined in section 2 and a list of excepted individuals are outlined in section 3. Family/household members are also directed to quarantine for 14 days if they come into contact with a quarantined individual. Individuals who do not comply with voluntary isolation and self-quarantine shall be involuntarily isolated or quarantined.
Breweries may offer outdoor/ patio seating at 50% occupancy. Bars are not included.
Breweries may offer indoor seating at breweries now permitted.
Places of lodging shall not operate at more than 50% of max occupancy. Vacation rental occupancy is determined based on the number of properties operated by the manager.
All casinos remain closed. Horse racing facilities may operate without spectators.

Outdoor and indoor dine-in services are permitted. Indoor services limited to 50% occupancy. Breweries may offer outdoor/ patio seating at 50% occupancy. Bars may not operate other than for take-out and delivery.
Houses of worship may not exceed 25% max occupancy.

Recreational Facilities such as "theaters, museums, amusement parks, concert venues, and indoor recreation and entertainment" shall remain closed. Businesses not defined as an "essential business" or "recreational facility" may open at 25% max occupancy and enforce 6ft social distancing between customers. Indoor shopping malls, barbershops, tattoo parlors, and massage services may operate at 25% capacity. Close contact businesses such as hair salons may open.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Gym/workout facility/fitness center
policy_description: Golf courses and tennis facilities may open. Gyms and exercise facilities may operate at 50% capacity. Public swimming pools may operate at 50% capacity with play and splash areas closed and with lane swimming and lessons permitted. Summer camps and youth programs may open for day use. 9 additional state parks shall open.
Mass gatherings of more than 5 people remain prohibited.

All travelers to New Mexico coming from outside of New Mexico are directed to self-isolate for 14 days. A list of approved activities for those under self-quarantine is outlined in section 2 and a list of excepted individuals are outlined in section 3.  Family/household members are also directed to quarantine for 14 days if they come into contact with a quarantined individual. Individuals who do not comply with voluntary isolation and self-quarantine shall be involuntarily isolated or quarantined.
Houses of worship may not exceed 25% max occupancy.
All casinos remain closed. Horse racing facilities may operate without spectators.

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Personal care facilities; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Gym/workout facility/fitness center
policy_description: Recreational Facilities such as "theaters, museums, amusement parks, concert venues, and indoor recreation and entertainment" shall remain closed. Businesses not defined as an "essential business" or "recreational facility" may open at 25% max occupancy and enforce 6ft social distancing between customers. Gyms and "close contact" businesses such as tattoo shops and salons are now limited to 25% max occupancy. Indoor shopping malls are limited to 25% occupancy.
Restaurants and breweries may no longer provide indoor dining. Restaurants and breweries are permitted outdoor seating at 50% max occupancy. All pickup and delivery services may continue to operate.
Mass gatherings of more than 5 people remain prohibited.

Golf courses and tennis facilities may open. Organized amateur contact sports are prohibited. Public swimming pools may operate at 50% capacity with play and splash areas closed and with lane swimming and lessons permitted. Summer camps and youth programs may open for day use. Only New Mexico residents may use state parks.

Golf courses and tennis facilities may open. Organized amateur contact sports are prohibited. Public swimming pools may operate at 50% capacity with play and splash areas closed and with lane swimming and lessons permitted. Summer camps and youth programs may open for day use. Only New Mexico residents may use state parks.

Wineries and distilleries are now classified in the same category as restaurants. Outdoor patio and seating is permitted. Indoor seating remain prohibited. Restaurants and breweries may no longer provide indoor dining. Restaurants and breweries are permitted outdoor seating at 50% max occupancy. All pickup and delivery services may continue to operate.
Houses of worship may not exceed 25% max occupancy.

policy_subtarget: Retail stores (not including food); Personal care facilities; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Gym/workout facility/fitness center
policy_description: Recreational Facilities such as "theaters, museums, amusement parks, concert venues, and indoor recreation and entertainment" shall remain closed. Businesses not defined as an "essential business" or "recreational facility" may open at 25% max occupancy and enforce 6ft social distancing between customers. Gyms and "close contact" businesses such as tattoo shops and salons are now limited to 25% max occupancy. Indoor shopping malls are limited to 25% occupancy.
Mass gatherings of more than 5 people remain prohibited.

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Primary education; Secondary education
policy_description: Private educational institutions that serve children from pre-K through 12th grade shall adhere to guidance provided by the NM public education Department and shall operate at 25% max occupancy in indoor spaces

All travelers to New Mexico coming from outside of New Mexico are directed to self-isolate for 14 days. A list of approved activities for those under self-quarantine is outlined in section 2 and a list of excepted individuals are outlined in section 3.  Family/household members are also directed to quarantine for 14 days if they come into contact with a quarantined individual. Individuals who do not comply with voluntary isolation and self-quarantine shall be involuntarily isolated or quarantined. Any New Mexico resident leaving the state for vacation must also self quarantine once reaching the state. Mandatory self quarantine does not apply to New Mexico residents who have left the state for less than 24 hours due to parenting responsibilities and  medical care.
Places that serve food and drink such as restaurants, breweries, wineries distillers, cafes, coffee shops may open indoor dining at 25% max occupancy.
Mass gatherings greater that 10 are prohibited.
Houses of worship may operate at 40% max occupancy.
Museums with static displays may open at 25% capacity.  Museums categorized as recreational facilities with interactive displays remain closed.
Tables at restaurants and establishments that serve food/drink must be spaced 6 ft apart with no more than 6 to a table both indoors and outdoors.

The state’s emergency public health order requires that places of lodging may operate at a maximum of 50 percent occupancy. Places of lodging that have been safe-certified may expand maximum occupancy to 75 percent. All places of lodging must operate in accordance with COVID-Safe Practices.

Anyone arriving in New Mexico from a state with a test rate higher than 80 per 100,000 people or a positivity rate greater than or equal to 5%, or those arriving from outside the US musts self-quarantine for at least 14 days or until they leave the state of NM (whichever duration is shorter). Those who show documentation of a negative test taken within 72 hours are exempt (this exception does not apply to travelers from outside the US). This self quarantine order does not apply to anyone in section 5.
Pumpkin Patches may operate

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Gym/workout facility/fitness center
policy_description: Youth sports with no more than 10 in one group are now permitted. Competitive contact play is still prohibited. Ice skating rinks may open for training and practice by reservation. Swimming pools may open with no more than 10 at a time.
New Mexicans may camp overnight at most state parks in groups of 10 or less.
Any food/drink establishment in NM that serves alcohol must close in person service before 10:00 pm.

Anyone arriving in New Mexico from a state with a test rate higher than 80 per 100,000 people or a positivity rate greater than or equal to 5%, or those arriving from outside the US must self-quarantine for at least 14 days or until they leave the state of NM (whichever duration is shorter). Those who present a negative COVID-19 test when coming from these states are no longer exempt from quarantine.  Those entering from a state with less than 80 per 1,000,000 residents and a positivity rate less than 5% are advised to self quarantine. NM residents should be tested for COVID-19 within 5-7 days after their return  to NM.  This self quarantine order does not apply to anyone in section 5.
Mass Gatherings of more than 5 are prohibited.
Maximum hotel occupancy is now 60% for places of lodging that are N.M safe certified and 25% fro all other places of lodging
Retail establishments must close by 10:00 pm.

policy_subtarget: Restaurants/bars; Retail stores (not including food); Hotels/lodging; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: Businesses that incur four rapid responses– which occur when an employer reports, as required, an incidence of COVID-19 in the workplace to the state– over a 2 week period will be required to close for 2 weeks. This applies to food and drink establishments, close contact businesses, retail places and places of lodging
State museums and historical sights are now closed.

Food and drink establishments that complete the NM safe certification training program may continue indoor dining at 25% max occupancy. Spot tests of employees will be part of the certification program as well as collection of indoor dining guest information in a logbook. Establishments that are not certified may continue outdoor dining at 75% max occupancy and tables 6 ft apart but not indoor dining.

Anyone arriving in New Mexico from a state with a test rate higher than 80 per 100,000 people or a positivity rate greater than or equal to 5%, or those arriving from outside the US must self-quarantine for at least 14 days or until they leave the state of NM (whichever duration is shorter). Those who present a negative COVID-19 test when coming from these states are no longer exempt from quarantine.  Those entering from a state with less than 80 per 1,000,000 residents and a positivity rate less than 5% are advised to self quarantine. NM residents should be tested for COVID-19 within 5-7 days after their return  to NM.  This self quarantine order does not apply to anyone in section 5.
Houses of Worship may hold services that do not exceed 40% max occupancy
Outdoor recreational facilities may operate
Bowling Alleys and Ice skating rinks may open for athletic training.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Casinos/gambling facilities
policy_description: Close contact recreational facilities remain closed
Places of lodging that have completed the NM safe certified training may operate at 60% max occupancy and 25% max occupancy for all other places of lodging

policy_subtarget: Personal care facilities; Gym/workout facility/fitness center
policy_description: Close contact businesses may operate at 25% max occupancy

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Primary education; Secondary education
policy_description: Private educational institutions that serve children from pre-K through 12th grade shall adhere to guidance provided by the NM public education Department and shall operate at 25% max occupancy in indoor spaces
Mass gatherings of more than 5 people are prohibited.
Essential Businesses/ retail spaces must close between the hours of 10:00pm and 4:00 am and may not exceed 25% of max occupancy.
All state run museums must close.

Food and drink establishments may provide dine in services at 25% max occupancy. No more than 6 people may be at a single table and there must be 6ft of distance between tables. In order to provide dine in services food and drink establishments must comply with the NM Safe certified requirements. All food and drink establishments may provide outdoor seating at 75% max occupancy. Establishments that serve alcohol must close in person services between 10:00 pm and 4:00 am.
Any business that is not included in definitions within the order may operate at 25% max occupancy
Houses of Worship may not be used for non-religious events. Houses of worship may not exceed 25% max occupancy or 75 individuals
Places of lodging that have completed the NM safe certified training may operate at 25%  max occupancy. Other places of lodging must close.
Essential Businesses/ retail spaces must close between the hours of 10:00pm and 4:00 am and may not exceed 25% of max occupancy or 75 people.

All businesses not identified as essential must reduce in person workforce by 100%. Businesses not identified as essential businesses may operate remotely or only to the minimum extent necessary to provide puck up or delivery services.
Food and drink establishments may not provide indoor or outdoor dine in services
retail space definition has been tightened. Animal grooming services may not operate, and "big box" stores and large retailers such as Hobby Lobby may not operate in-person services.

policy_subtarget: Personal care facilities; Retail stores (not including food); Hotels/lodging; Restaurants/bars
policy_description: Businesses with significant numbers of positive COVID-19 cases among workers will be subjetc to closure unless the business is essential and determined a necessary provider of goods or services in the community, a business tests employees every 2 weeks and provides data to the environment departments. This closure is triggered if 4 or more rapid responses occur within 14 days/
Houses of worship must adhere to all relevant  Covid Safe practices

policy_description: In neighborhoods experiencing outbreaks of COVID-19 and classified as "orange zones" by Department of Health's cluster action initiative, gyms and businesses providing personal care services must close, and restaurants and bars must close for indoor dine-in.

In neighborhoods experiencing outbreaks of COVID-19 and classified as "orange zones" or "yellow zones" by Department of Health's cluster action initiative, restaurants and bars providing dine-in services must limit tables to 4 people.
Voters will be permitted to drop off absentee ballots on election day without needing to wait in line with in-person voters in order to promote social distancing.

In neighborhoods experiencing outbreaks of COVID-19 and classified as "red zones" by Department of Health's cluster action initiative, no non-essential gatherings are permitted, and religious gatherings are capped at the lower of 10 individuals or 25% occupancy.

In neighborhoods experiencing outbreaks of COVID-19 and classified as "red zones" by Department of Health's cluster action initiative, all non-essential businesses must close in-person operations, and restaurants and bars must close for dine-in.

In neighborhoods experiencing outbreaks of COVID-19 and classified as "yellow zones" by Department of Health's cluster action initiative, non-essential gatherings may not exceed 25 people, and religious gatherings are capped at 50% occupancy and are subject to further Department of Health guidance.

In neighborhoods experiencing outbreaks of COVID-19 and classified as "red zones" or "orange zones" by Department of Health's cluster action initiative, schools are still required to temporarily close for at least four days, but then may reopen if they implement certain testing procedures.

The quarantine order for travelers to New York state from areas with high transmission continues, but is modified to permit individuals to cut short their quarantine period if they received negative COVID-19 tests before departure and after arrival, and to replace the quarantine requirement with testing mandate for individuals who spend less than 24 hours outside of New York. New York additionally requires that any incoming travelers subject to quarantine fill out a form providing contact and other information to the state, and acknowledging the quarantine requirements.
intended_duration: Until rescinded by Commissioner of Health

policy_description: Extension: In neighborhoods experiencing outbreaks of COVID-19 and classified as "orange zones" by Department of Health's cluster action initiative, non-essential gatherings may not exceed 10 people, and religious gatherings are capped at the lower of 25 individuals or 33% occupancy.

Extension: In neighborhoods experiencing outbreaks of COVID-19 and classified as "red zones" by Department of Health's cluster action initiative, no non-essential gatherings are permitted, and religious gatherings are capped at the lower of 10 individuals or 25% occupancy.

Extension: In neighborhoods experiencing outbreaks of COVID-19 and classified as "red zones" by Department of Health's cluster action initiative, all non-essential businesses must close in-person operations, and restaurants and bars must close for dine-in.

Restaurants, bars, liquor stores, and gyms must all ceases operations from 10pm to 5am daily. Restaurants may continue to serve takeout food during this time.

Extension: schools statewide may continue to operate, provided they adhere to state guidelines and they are located in a region with a low infection rate. In addition, low- and moderate-risk school sports may continue, subject to limitations.

Extension: the Commissioner of Health may revoke the operating certificate of any nursing home not in compliance with state directives or regulations. The Commissioner may appoint another entity to continue operating the home in this case.

policy_description: Businesses remaining open must, to the extent practicable, follow social distancing and sanitation rules.
intended_duration: 30 days or until state of emergency rescinded, whichever first

policy_description: Governor Roy Cooper ordered that skilled nursing facilities take various steps to hinder the spread of COVID, including not allowing sick employees to work, screening employees and residents for symptoms (including fever), canceling communal gatherings, and using facemasks if available.
intended_duration: Until end of state of emergency

policy_description: Governor Cooper authorized and encouraged non-profits to hold meetings remotely.
Personal care, grooming and tattoo services that reopen must follow social distancing, screening, signage and sanitation guidelines.
Governor Cooper lifts the stay-at-home order, but encourages telework as far as possible.
Restaurants may open for on-site services.
Personal care, grooming and tattoo services may reopen.
Childcare services may open and serve all children, following screening guidelines.
People are encouraged to follow social distancing and sanitation recommendations when in public, and high risk individuals are encouraged to stay home.
Reopened retail businesses must follow social distancing, screening, signage and sanitation guidelines.
Restaurants that open for on-site services must follow social distancing, screening, signage and sanitation guidelines.
Governor Cooper prohibits visitation in long term care except for compassionate care situations, such as end of life care.
Governor Cooper extends Phase 2, as per Executive Order 141, to remain in effect until July 17.
Governor Cooper extends certain waivers and modifications to legal constraints regarding visitation in health care facilities.
Governor Cooper extends Executive Order 141, detailing the plan for Phase 2, until August 7th 2020.
Governor Cooper prohibits the sale and service of alcohol at restaurants and bars between 11:00pm and 7:00am.
Governor Cooper extends Executive Order 141, extending Phase 2 of re-opening until the 11th of September.
Governor Cooper extends Executive Order No. 153, prohibiting the sale and service of alcohol at restaurants and bars between 11:00pm and 7:00am, until 2nd October 2020.
Museums and aquariums may open, adhering to certain distancing, occupancy, sanitation and screening guidelines.
Personal care, grooming and tattoo services may reopen and must follow social distancing, screening, signage and sanitation guidelines.
Restaurants are permitted open for on-site services and must follow social distancing, screening, signage and sanitation guidelines.
Indoor and outdoor pools may reopen, and must adhere to occupancy, social distancing, screening, and sanitation guidelines.
Reopened retail businesses must follow social distancing, occupancy screening, signage and sanitation guidelines.
Most fitness and physical activity facilities may open, following certain occupancy, face covering, and sanitation guidelines.
Mass gatherings of more than 25 people indoors, and more than 50 people outdoors, remain prohibited.

Governor Cooper authorises the opening of fitness centres and physical activity facilities, given certain social distancing, capacity restrictions, and other measures are followed. Face coverings must be worn except in the case of strenuous exercise.

Any businesses or organizations that sell or serve alcoholic beverages for onsite consumption shall cease the sale and service of alcoholic beverages for onsite consumption between 11 :00 pm and 7:00 am.

Governor Cooper authorises the opening of movie theatres, meeting spaces, and other such entertainment facilities given certain social distancing, capacity restrictions, face covering mandates, and other measures are followed.
Governor Cooper authorises the opening of bars, night spots, and arenas, given certain social distancing, capacity restrictions, face covering mandates, and other measures are followed.
Governor Cooper authorises the opening of amusement parks and as long as indoor attractions remain closed, however, indoor restaurants, concessions and retail spaces may remain open.
Mass gatherings of more than 25 people indoors or more than 50 people outdoors remain prohibited.
Events at very large outdoor facilities that meet certain criteria may exceed the mass gathering restrictions as long as they follow social distancing, face covering, and other such restrictions.
Governor Cooper extends Phase 3, described in Executive Order 169, until November 13 2020.
Governor Cooper extends Phase 3 to last until 4 December 2020.
Governor Cooper amends the mass gathering limit, prohibiting indoor gatherings of more than 10 people and outdoor gatherings of more than 50 people.
Governor Cooper extends Phase 3 to last until 11 December 2020.
Access to the North Dakota Capitol is limited to by appointment only
Governor Doug Burgum allowed closed public K-12 schools to remain open through May for the limited purpose of providing childcare to staff and essential workers.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Government/public buildings; Public sector/government employees

intended_duration: Until end of state of emergency

policy_description: Reinstates provisions of state law allowing local health officers and local health boards to issue quarantine / isolation orders. He continued other waivers to more easily quarantine individuals.

policy_description: COVID-19 declared a post-mortem communicable disease, requiring that certain precautions be taken with the bodies of individuals suspected to have died while having the disease.
Retail stores may reopen for dine-in at 8am on 5/1 but that they must follow ND Smart Restart guidelines.
intended_duration: Until end of state of emergency

policy_description: Bars and restaurants may reopen for dine-in at 8am on 5/1 but that they must follow ND Smart Restart guidelines.
intended_duration: Until end of state of emergency

policy_description: Extends the order that state agencies have employees work from home where possible.
intended_duration: Until end of state of emergency

policy_description: Governor Doug Burgum authorised high school graduation ceremonies, provided they follow social distancing measures.
Governor Burgum authorises the Department of Environmental Quality to hold virtual public hearings.
14 day quarantine from time of entry into the state applies only to international travellers, and people who have travelled internationally within the past 14 days.
All people who test positive must remain in isolation in their residences for at least 10 days after symptom onset, and 72 hours after becoming fever free.
Governor Burgum allows recreation and sport arenas, entertainment and music venues to open, provided they follow the protocol for large gatherings.
Authorises school superintendents to use school buildings for appropriate limited use.
Reopened non-essential businesses are strongly encouraged to follow ND Smart Restart standards
Provides guidelines for the re-opening of schools, requiring schools to prepare Health and Safety Plans for each school building.
All travellers entering North Dakota from a different country, or having travelled internationally in the past 14 days is subject to immediate quarantine in their place of residence.

Revokes the order that all travelers entering North Dakota from a different country, or having travelled internationally in the past 14 days are subject to immediate quarantine (State Health Officer Order 2020.02-3)
In addition to household contacts, close contacts must also quarantine if they're named as close contacts of someone who tested positive for COVID-19
intended_duration: Until revocation by the State Health Officer

policy_description: Revokes the order requiring close contacts to quarantine

Allows asymptomatic, COVID-positive health care workers to work in the COVID unit of a licensed health care facility, so long as they remain asymptomatic and additional precautions are taken as recommended by the CDC and ND Department of Health to protect the worker and the community.
intended_duration: Until revocation by the State Health Officer

policy_description: All high school, association, community, and club sports for youth and adults are cancelled until December 14th. All other extra curricular K-12 school events are cancelled until December 14th as well.

Bars, restaurants, and food service establishments must comply with the following mitigation measures: maximum 50% capacity (max 150 persons), food / drinks services to seated patrons only (no stand up service), allow for 6ft distancing, follow the face covering order (#2020-08)

Banquets, ballrooms, weddings, and event venues must comply with the following mitigation measures: maximum 25% capacity, food / drinks services to seated patrons only (no stand up service), close dance areas, allow for 6ft distancing, follow the face covering order (#2020-08)
Bars, restaurants, and food services must close in person dining between 10pm and 4am

Continuation of requirement that banquets, ballrooms, weddings, and event venues must comply with the following mitigation measures: maximum 25% capacity, food / drinks services to seated patrons only (no stand up service), close dance areas, allow for 6ft distancing, follow the face covering order (#2020-08)
Amends EO 2020-43 to also cancel all practices, rehearsals, and meetings for extra curricular actives until November 30
