The Ohio Department of Health has amended its order over limiting visitors to nursing and assisted living homes to reflect that no visitors will be admitted.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Governor DeWine ordered all senior centers and adult day care centers to stop providng care in congregate settings.
Manufacturing, distribution, and construction businesses may reopen, as may general office requirements.
Retail may reopen as long as they meet the safety requirements, like face coverings and social distancing.
Outdoor dining may open in restaurants and bars. Personal care services may reopen following guidelines.
Indoor dining may open, following detailed public health guidelines.

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Public sector/government employees
policy_description: Ohio Bureau of Motor Vehicles may reopen, as may gyms, fitness centers, pools, and non-contact adult and youth sports leagues.
Childcare may reopen.
Ohio moves from a stay at home to a safer at home.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Miniature golf, bowling alleys, and skills trainings for all sports may begin.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Higher education; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Schools, entertainment, and recreation continue to be closed, except for noted exceptions.
Mass gatherings of greater than 10 continue to be prhobited, with few exceptions.
Limit to one day camp or residential camp staff member per nine school-age children with no more than nine children in the room.
Camp employees to stay home if experiencing symptoms of COVID-19.

Staff and campers should record their temperature for 14 days before camp. If a staff member or camper has a fever of 100 degrees or higher or any other COVID-19 symptoms, such as cough or shortness of breath, they should not attend camp.

Day camp and residential providers must check the temperatures of all staff, children, and adults upon arrival. If any individual has a fever of 100 degrees or higher, they may not enter the facility. Providers must immediately send home any child or employee who has a temperature of 100 degrees or higher. This individual may not return until they are fever free for 24 hours, without the use of fever-reducing medication.

Camp operators should organize the camp into the smallest group sizes possible, made up of staff and campers from a single sleeping quarter. Small groups should remain together, including at meal time and during activities.
Youth day camps and residential camps to reopen so long as safety standards are met.

Staff and campers that have had contact with someone confirmed or probable to have COVID19, he or she must complete isolation or quarantine procedures in coordination with the local health department prior to returning to the program.
No more than 10 people per residential camp sleeping area. Head-to-toe sleeping arrangement is recommended.

policy_subtarget: Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare); Minors and children; Non essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Day camp workers and attendees must follow rigorous handwashing procedures as detailed in Appendix B to Ohio Administrative Code 5101:2-12-13. Day camp providers must ensure that children wash their hands prior to departure.

Camp providers may use temporary walls to divide a room into smaller spaces to serve multiple groups, under limited circumstances. 1. The smaller space must contain at least 35 square feet of space per child. 2. The divider must be at least six feet in height. 3. The divider must be made from nonporous material or other material that can be sanitized.
Properly prepared assisted living facilities and intermediate care facilities may begin to allow outdoor visitiation.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Indoor recreation centers, outdoor recreation centers, museums, and entertainment venues can reopen if following guidelines.
Restaurants must establish maximum dining capacity and limit reservations/party sizes to 10 persons.

policy_subtarget: Non essential workers (inclusive); Essential workers (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Employees experiencing acute respiratory symptoms must be sent home immediately. Employers must actively encourage sick employees to stay home until they are free of fever (without fever-reducing medication) for at least 72 hours AND symptoms have improved for at least 72 hours AND at least 7 days have passed since symptoms began.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Restaurants/bars
policy_description: Six feet of social distancing must be enforced at bars and food service facilities when possible. Use of signage and tape encouraged.
Food service employees must perform a daily temperature and symptom assessment before attending work.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Restaurants/bars
policy_description: Termination of policy closing bars, restaurants, banquets and catering facilities and services. All bars, restaurants, banquets, and catering facilities and services are permitted to reopen for full dine-in services, so long as social distancing guidelines continue to be followed. Tables must be limited to 10 people and catering/banquet services are limited to 300 people.
Casinos and amusement parks may reopen.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Six feet of distancing between members of different households must be maintained at livestock competitions/auctions and grandstand events. Grandstand events must be limited to half capacity with no more than 2,500 seated spectators.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: County Fairs are permitted to reopen so long as all safety standards are met. Animal exhibitions on county fairgrounds, whether open or closed, are also permitted so long as guidances are followed.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: County Fair Managers should conduct the fair in such a manner that discourages large gatherings.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space; Restaurants/bars
policy_description: County Fair food and concession stands must abide by rules for restaurants as described in RestartOhio Rules for Restaurants.

Extension of Director's Order that Reopens Youth Day Camps and Residential Camps. Limit to one day camp or residential camp staff member per nine school-age children with no more than nine children in the room.
Extension of Director's Order that Reopens Youth Day Camps and Residential Camps. Camp employees to stay home if experiencing symptoms of COVID-19.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Spectators, players, coaches, officials, and athletic trainers should perform daily symptom assessments and must stay home if experiencing symptoms.

Extension of Director's Order that Reopens Youth Day Camps and Residential Camps. Camp operators should organize the camp into the smallest group sizes possible, made up of staff and campers from a single sleeping quarter. Small groups should remain together, including at meal time and during activities.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Any symptomatic individual should be isolated immediately and medical care should be sought.

If any individual has a fever of 100 degrees or higher, they may not enter the facility. Providers must immediately send home any child or employee who has a temperature of 100 degrees or higher. This individual may not return until they are fever free for 24 hours, without the use of fever-reducing medication.
Extension of Director's Order that Reopens Youth Day Camps and Residential Camps. Youth day camps and residential camps to reopen so long as safety standards are met.

policy_description: Intra-club/team practices/scrimmages may resume for contact sports. Practices/scrimmages with other teams are prohibited.
Extension of Director's Order that Reopens Youth Day Camps and Residential Camps. No more than 10 people per residential camp sleeping area. Head-to-toe sleeping arrangement is recommended.

Extension of Director's Order that Reopens Youth Day Camps and Residential Camps. Staff and campers that have had contact with someone confirmed or probable to have COVID19, he or she must complete isolation or quarantine procedures in coordination with the local health department prior to returning to the program.

Extension of Director's Order that Reopens Youth Day Camps and Residential Camps. Staff and campers should record their temperature for 14 days before camp. If a staff member or camper has a fever of 100 degrees or higher or any other COVID-19 symptoms, such as cough or shortness of breath, they should not attend camp.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Six feet of social distancing must be kept between spectators. Players must also maintain six feet of distance when not on the field/in play.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Physical contact is only permitted within the rules of the game during competitive practice. Players, coaches, and officials are not to contact each other before or after practice (greetings, high-fives, team huddles, congregations).

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Time should be allotted between practice sessions for proper sanitizing of shared spaces.

policy_description: Extension of Director's Order that Reopens Youth Day Camps and Residential Camps. Camp providers may use temporary walls to divide a room into smaller spaces to serve multiple groups, under limited circumstances. 1. The divider must be made from nonporous material or other material that can be sanitized.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Nursing homes/assisted living facility
policy_description: No visitors of residents shall be admitted to any nursing home, except for end of life situations (as defined by this order). These visitors must adhere to strict guidelines. Visitors must be screened. No more than 3 visitors per resident per visit. Visits must be under one hour.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Nursing homes/assisted living facility
policy_description: Nursing homes (as defined by the order) may permit residents to have visitors in outdoor settings in accordance with guidelines and exceptions. Facilities should use the guidelines described in the order to assess their preparedness to resume outdoor visits.

policy_description: Campers shall be subject to twice daily temperature checks administered by staff at breakfast and dinner and shall, complete and sign a daily COVID-19 symptom questionnaire which the residential camp providers shall keep on file for 90 days.

policy_description: Inter-team contact sport players, coaches, athletic trainers, support staff, and officials must: Not exhibit signs or symptoms of COVID-19 within the past 72 hours prior to competition or if coming from outside the state, before arrival in Ohio. Should a player, coach, athletic trainer, support staff or official exhibit signs or symptoms of COVID-19 they will not be permitted to participate in the competition and should not travel to Ohio.

A 10:00 p.m. curfew is established for the fairgrounds during the period of the junior fair. Participants are expected to leave the fairgrounds by that time and if camping on site, must be back in their camper no later than 10:00 p.m.
County fairs beginning on or after July 31, 2020, Agricultural Societies shall limit fairs to allow only individuals participating in youth organizations such as 4-H and FFA.
County fair participants must perform a daily symptom assessment, take temperature, and watch for respiratory symptoms. Individuals with symptoms must stay home.
Limitations on attendance at county fair events including animal exhibitions, livestock auctions, and races.
County fair boards must work with local boards of health to develop proper signage regarding social distancing and handwashing/hand sanitizing.
6 feet of distance must be maintained between all county fair attendees. The is to be no physical contact between county attendees or between attendees and animals.
County fair boards are responsible for drafting 2020 operational guidance specific to each county fair ground, with approval given by the local board of health.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space; Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: EXTENSION: Inter-team contact sport players, coaches, athletic trainers, support staff, and officials must: Not exhibit signs or symptoms of COVID-19 within the past 72 hours prior to competition or if coming from outside the state, before arrival in Ohio. Should a player, coach, athletic trainer, support staff or official exhibit signs or symptoms of COVID-19 they will not be permitted to participate in the competition and should not travel to Ohio.

policy_subtarget: Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space; Non essential business (inclusive); Confirmed cases
policy_description: EXTENSION: Spectators are not permitted in the venue/facility for any competitive contact sports inter-club/team play.

All Sports are permitted to practice and engage in competition in accordance with all provisions of this Order. In the event of a conflict between this Order and the rules of the governing authority, the Sports and Sports Participants shall comply with the provision that is most restrictive on their activities.

Six-feet social distance must be maintained between individuals except when necessary on the field or court of play. Players, coaches, and officials are not to physically contact each other before or after practice or pregame and competitive play (e.g., greetings, team huddles, highfives, congregating, etc.).

To limit exposure of players, no team shall play against more than a single opponent team in any twenty-four hour period. Equipment and personal items must have proper separation and should avoid being shared. If equipment must be shared, proper sanitation must be performed between users. Time must be allotted between practice sessions to allow teams to exit fields/facilities prior to new teams arriving and for proper sanitizing for shared spaces and high-touch surfaces (benches, equipment, etc.).

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: The maximum number of individuals gathered in any outdoor Sports venue is the lesser of 1500 or 15 percent of fixed, seated capacity. For indoor facilities the maximum number of individuals gathered in any indoor entertainment venue shall be the lesser of 300 spectators or 15 percent of fixed seating capacity. Physical separation must be maintained throughout the venue, and seating must be arranged and assigned to allow for six feet of space between groups. Risk notification signage must be posted and one way traffic lanes are to be implemented.

Coaches, athletic trainers, volunteers, officials, and spectators must wear face coverings at all times, and players must wear face coverings when not on the field or court of play, with exceptions including, individuals under 10 years of age, individuals with a medical condition that contraindicates the wearing of a facial covering, individuals communicating or seeking to communicate with someone who is hearing-impaired or has another disability, where the ability to see the mouth is essential for communication, individuals who are seated and actively consuming food or beverage in a restaurant or bar, or when facial coverings are prohibited by law or regulation.

An individual who tests positive for COVID-19, whether symptomatic or asymptomatic, shall not return to Sports activities until a documented medical exam is performed clearing the individual prior to the individual returning to participation in practice or games. The documented medical exam must specifically include an assessment of the cardiac/heart risk of high-intensity exercise due to the potential of myocarditis occurring in COVID-19 patients.

Players, coaches, officials, or other individuals who had close contact (within six feet of an infected individual for at least 15 minutes) or who had direct physical contact with the person (e.g., who were coughed on or sneezed on by the infected person) must self-quarantine for 14 days following exposure.

Sports organizations must designate six-foot distances with signage, tape, or by other means for participants and spectators. Hand sanitizer and sanitizing products must be readily available for sports participants. Sports organizations/facilities must posting online whether they are open and how best to approach the facility consistent with the social distancing requirements.

Locker rooms, weight training rooms, restrooms, and athletic training rooms must be cleaned and sanitized frequently. Individuals must maintain social distancing as much as possible while in these rooms. Face coverings must be worn at all times while in these rooms

Travel sports teams must conduct a pre-travel symptom and temperature check immediately prior to departure. Individuals traveling together by bus, etc., must wear a face covering and social distance where possible while in the vehicle.
Sports players, coaches, athletic trainers, officials, and spectators must conduct daily symptom assessments before each practice or game. Anyone experiencing symptoms must stay home.

Subject to their full compliance with all provisions of this Order, Entertainment Venues, including auditoriums, stadiums, arenas, concert and music halls, theaters, ballrooms, gymnasiums, convention centers, arcades, bingo halls, adult and child skill or chance games, laser tag facilities, and interactive game facilities hosting non-Sports events, are permitted to present and host entertainment events within the State.

Entertainment venues must take proactive measures to ensure compliance with Social Distancing Requirements, including: A. Designating six-foot distances with signage, tape, or by other means six- foot spacing for performers (except when performing), employees and patrons in line to maintain appropriate distance; B. Having hand sanitizer and sanitizing products readily available for performers, employees and patrons; and C. Posting online whether the Entertainment Venue is open and how best to approach the facility consistent with the Social Distancing Requirements.  Each Entertainment Venue manager shall designate, in writing and prior to an event, a compliance officer whose responsibility it is to ensures that the requirements of this Order are followed. That designated person shall also be the contact person for the local health department, sheriff’s department, and any other local law enforcement agency that has jurisdiction over the event.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: For indoor entertainment facilities the maximum number of patrons permitted in an indoor entertainment venue shall be the lesser of 300 patrons or 15 percent of fixed seating capacity.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs
policy_description: The maximum number of patrons permitted in an outdoor Entertainment Venue is the lesser of 1500 patrons or 15 percent of fixed, seated capacity.
Entertainment venues must develop a patron pathway that allows for physical distancing as patrons move from parking, through box office lines, ticket scanning, and security screening to their seats.

All Sports are permitted to practice and engage in competition in accordance with all provisions of this Order. In the event of a conflict between this Order and the rules of the governing authority, the Sports and Sports Participants shall comply with the provision that is most restrictive on their activities.

Sports organizations must designate six-foot distances with signage, tape, or by other means for participants and spectators. Hand sanitizer and sanitizing products must be readily available for sports participants. Sports organizations/facilities must posting online whether they are open and how best to approach the facility consistent with the social distancing requirements.

Locker rooms, weight training rooms, restrooms, and athletic training rooms must be cleaned and sanitized frequently. Individuals must maintain social distancing as much as possible while in these rooms. Face coverings must be worn at all times while in these rooms

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: The maximum number of individuals gathered in any outdoor Sports venue is the lesser of 1500 or 15 percent of fixed, seated capacity. For indoor facilities the maximum number of individuals gathered in any indoor entertainment venue shall be the lesser of 300 spectators or 15 percent of fixed seating capacity. Physical separation must be maintained throughout the venue, and seating must be arranged and assigned to allow for six feet of space between groups. Risk notification signage must be posted and one way traffic lanes are to be implemented.

Players, coaches, officials, or other individuals who had close contact (within six feet of an infected individual for at least 15 minutes) or who had direct physical contact with the person (e.g., who were coughed on or sneezed on by the infected person) must self-quarantine for 14 days following exposure.

Six-feet social distance must be maintained between individuals except when necessary on the field or court of play. Players, coaches, and officials are not to physically contact each other before or after practice or pregame and competitive play (e.g., greetings, team huddles, highfives, congregating, etc.).

Coaches, athletic trainers, volunteers, officials, and spectators must wear face coverings at all times, and players must wear face coverings when not on the field or court of play, with exceptions including, individuals under 10 years of age, individuals with a medical condition that contraindicates the wearing of a facial covering, individuals communicating or seeking to communicate with someone who is hearing-impaired or has another disability, where the ability to see the mouth is essential for communication, individuals who are seated and actively consuming food or beverage in a restaurant or bar, or when facial coverings are prohibited by law or regulation.

To limit exposure of players, no team shall play against more than a single opponent team in any twenty-four hour period. Equipment and personal items must have proper separation and should avoid being shared. If equipment must be shared, proper sanitation must be performed between users. Time must be allotted between practice sessions to allow teams to exit fields/facilities prior to new teams arriving and for proper sanitizing for shared spaces and high-touch surfaces (benches, equipment, etc.).

Travel sports teams must conduct a pre-travel symptom and temperature check immediately prior to departure. Individuals traveling together by bus, etc., must wear a face covering and social distance where possible while in the vehicle.

An individual who tests positive for COVID-19, whether symptomatic or asymptomatic, shall not return to Sports activities until a documented medical exam is performed clearing the individual prior to the individual returning to participation in practice or games. The documented medical exam must specifically include an assessment of the cardiac/heart risk of high-intensity exercise due to the potential of myocarditis occurring in COVID-19 patients.
Sports players, coaches, athletic trainers, officials, and spectators must conduct daily symptom assessments before each practice or game. Anyone experiencing symptoms must stay home.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: All facilities providing older adult day care services and senior centers are permitted to reopen within the State of Ohio.

policy_subtarget: Confirmed cases; Suspected cases; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Non-congregate sheltering be utilized throughout the state to allow confirmed cases of COVID-19 who are unable to safely isolate in their own places of residence. It may also be used for exposed individuals seeking to quarantine from their cohabitants. Non-congregate sheltering may also be used for high-risk individuals who are not safe in their own residences.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Public services
policy_description: Facilities shall assess existing capacity and identify participants best suited to return to the facility. During this initial phase of limited capacity, participants unable to wear masks shall not be permitted to return to facilities. Participants considered to be a risk to others shall not be accepted into the facility until it is safe for everyone.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Senior center facility employees and members of the public must maintain six-foot social distancing. Facilities must require all employees to wear facial coverings. Facilities must take proactive measures to ensure compliance with Social Distancing Requirements, including designating six-foot distances with tape or signage, having hand sanitizer and sanitizing products readily available for employees and customers, posting online whether a facility is open and providing information on remote services, performing thorough cleaning of high-touch surfaces, and posting signage regarding COVID-19 symptoms and hygiene practices.

policy_subtarget: Suspected cases; Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Senior centers must actively encourage sick employees to stay home until they are free of fever (without the use of medication)for at least 24 hours AND symptoms have improved AND at least ten days have passed since symptoms first began.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Public transportation
policy_description: All individuals being transported to or from a senior center shall be required to wear a mask during the process of pick up and drop of and the duration of the ride.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions; Public services
policy_description: Senior center facilities shall immediately isolate and seek medical care for any individual who develops symptoms while at the facility

policy_subtarget: Private sector; Restaurants/bars; Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Restaurants, bars, banquet and catering facilities and services are permitted to reopen so long as workplace safety standards are met should they not ceased operations during prior orders. They must comply with social distancing requirements, and are allowed live entertainment.
intended_duration: Until the Director of the Ohio Department of Health rescinds or modifies the order

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Government/public buildings; Public sector/government employees
policy_description: The Oklahoma Legislature passed and Governor Kevin Stitt signed legislation allowing government bodies to conduct meetings by teleconference.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Medical offices (doctor/dentist/physical therapist); Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services
policy_description: Governor Kevin Stitt ordered that all employees delivering items to medical or certain other facilities submit to screening for COVID upon request. Package delivery companies must screen employees handling packages at each shift.
intended_duration: Until end of state of emergency

policy_description: Individuals submitting absentee ballots now have the option of including a photocopied identification document as an alternative to providing two witness signatures or having their ballot notarized.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Older adults and individuals with underlying conditions are recommended to stay home except for essential trips.
intended_duration: Until end of state of emergency

policy_description: Visitation at nursing homes may resume, subject to guidance from the Oklahoma State Department of Health. In areas with increasing case numbers or facilities with COVID-19 present, more strict guidelines go into place.
intended_duration: Until end of state of emergency

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: The recommendation that older adults and individuals with underlying conditions stay home except for essential trips was modified so as to only apply in counties experiencing high levels of transmission.
intended_duration: Until end of state of emergency

policy_description: Restaurants and bars must close dine-in at 11pm.
Restaurants and bars must space separate parties by six feet (unless there is a barrier between them).

Public and social gatherings are now limited to 50% of building occupancy occupancy, with a private residences and a variety of buildings/businesses exempted from this limit. Indoor extracurricular activities also face a 50% occupancy limit, as well as a cap of four spectators per youth participant.
intended_duration: Until end of state of emergency

policy_description: The Oregon Dept of Corrections suspended all visits at its facilities.
Governor Kate Brown extended the closure of K-12 schools, making certain modifications to allow for the delivery of school-based services.
The Oregon Department of Human Services put in place stricter limits on visitors at long-term care facilities and required more screening of all personnel.
The Oregon Department of Human Services put in required screening or all personnel at long-term care facilities.
Agricultural employers and employers providing of housing for agricultural workers must adopt various measures to ensure distancing among workers and otherwise mitigate the spread of COVID-19.

Homeless shelters and other basic services are exempted from closure orders, and shelters are not expected to maintain distancing between residents, but should encourage distancing and limited travel.
Restrictions and distancing requirements established for summer camps.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Higher education
policy_description: Restrictions and distancing requirements established for all levels of summer schools.
Government offices may reopen to the public in some cases, subject to the guidance of the Department of Administrative Services.
Public campgrounds can continue to be open, subject to OHA rules.
Private campgrounds can continue to be open, subject to OHA rules.
Continuation: childcare providers must maintain stable groups of 10 or fewer children, and must adhere to additional guidelines.

Businesses must continue to adhere to OHA guidance and guidance from other appropriate agencies, including sector-specific guidance. OHA may also issue guidance that applies to individuals. Guidance posted at govstatus.egov.com/OR-OHA-COVID-19 is mandatory.
Continuation: individuals must maintain distance when engaging in outdoor activity.

Governor Kate Brown established guidelines for institutions of higher education resuming in-person instruction/activity. Further guidelines will originate from the Oregon Health Authority. Institutions must submit plans by 9/1/2020 on how they will ensure compliance.

Governor Kate Brown established guidelines for public and private K-12 schools to resume in-person instruction/activities. Further guidelines will originate from various state agencies and bodies. Schools must submit plans by 8/15/2020 or the start of their school year, whichever first, on how they will ensure compliance.
Local government bodies may continue to conduct meetings online, with various amendments (including that absences due to illness with COVID-19 do not count against quorum).

In addition to previously established requirements for reopening, schools are only allowed to reopen in person if test positivity and incidence is and remains sufficiently low at the county level and test positivity is and remains sufficiently low statewide.

With some modifications, agricultural employers and employers providing of housing for agricultural workers must continue to adopt various measures to ensure distancing among workers and otherwise mitigate the spread of COVID-19.
Establishments statewide must close for dine-in, though they may continue to operate for take-out.
Businesses must have employees telework/work from home to the extent possible.

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Indoor recreation/sports facility ; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Casinos/gambling facilities
policy_description: Gyms, indoor recreation businesses, event-based businesses, and athletic and recreational businesses must close.
Gatherings within homes are limited to 6 attendees; religious gatherings and funerals are limited to 25 individuals when indoors or 50 individuals when outdoors.
Businesses must comply with industry-specific and general adaptation and mitigation measures (e.g. occupancy limits).
Executive Order 20-27 is rescinded, ending this particular policy relating to reopening government services.
Executive Order 20-27 is rescinded, ending this distancing mandate.

Businesses must take various adaptation and mitigation measures (such as enforcing occupancy limits) as listed in sector-specific guidance issued by the Oregon Health Authority (OHA). This guidance varies depending on the OHA-designated risk level of the county in which the business operates.
Executive Order 20-27 is rescinded, ending this particular policy regarding campgrounds.
Executive Order 20-27 is rescinded, ending this particular policy regarding campgrounds.
Institutions of higher education must continue to follow guidance from the Oregon Health Authority and the governor's office when conducting in-person operations.
K-12 schools must continue to adhere to requirements from the governor's office and various state agencies and bodies in order to resume in-person instruction/activities.
Childcare providers must continue to adhere to various adaptation and mitigation measures specified by the Oregon Health Authority (OHA), including limitations on group sizes.
All dine-in establishments must close by 11pm statewide (or 12am, in the case of establishments located in Lower Risk counties).
Governor Tom Wolf extended the closure of all K-12 schools indefinitely
Secretary of Health Rachel Levine ordered that businesses clean high-touch surfaces and take other mitigation steps.
Secretary of Health Rachel Levine ordered that businesses maintain at least 6 feet of distance between occupants.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Government/public buildings; Public sector/government employees
policy_description: The PA General Assembly passed and Governor Tom Wolf signed legislation to permit government bodies to meet electronically and allowing remote notarization.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Businesses must continued to follow previous distancing/sanitation rules from the Governor and the Secretary of Health, as well as all guidance from the CDC and PA Dept. of Health.

policy_subtarget: Childcare facilities (preschool or other daycare); Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: The Department of Health released guidance (which, under Governor Wolf's 5/7 order, businesses are required to follow) establishing distancing, sanitation, and occupancy requirements for summer camps, pools, and outdoor recreation.
Restrictions on visitors at nursing homes continue. (Additional details as to the level of restriction are not specified.)

Hospitals must take various steps to mitigate the spread of COVID-19, including notifying staff when a staff member tests positive, distributing PPE, and ensuring testing of staff members who are exposed.

Statewide (now that all counties have enter the Green Phase), there is a 75% occupancy limit for all non-essential businesses not contained in the following list: indoor recreation, health and wellness facilities and personal care services (such as gyms, spas, hair salons, nail salons and massage therapy providers), and all entertainment (such as casinos, theaters) and such businesses. (Officials in Philadelphia County in particular are permitted to impose more stringent limits.)

Statewide (now that all counties have enter the Green Phase), no mass gatherings of 250 or more. Places of worship are exempt from the limit. (Officials in Philadelphia County in particular are permitted to impose more stringent limits.)
Statewide (now that all counties have enter the Green Phase), restaurants and bars must follow distancing and sanitation guidance when operating for indoor and outdoor dine-in.

policy_subtarget: Non essential business (inclusive); Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Casinos/gambling facilities; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Government/public buildings; Personal care facilities
policy_description: Statewide (now that all counties have enter the Green Phase), there is a 50% occupancy limit for the following businesses: indoor recreation, health and wellness facilities and personal care services (such as gyms, spas, hair salons, nail salons and massage therapy providers), and all entertainment (such as casinos, theaters) and such businesses. Additionally, personal care services must conduct services by appointment only. (Officials in Philadelphia County in particular are permitted to impose more stringent limits.)

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Government/public buildings; Public sector/government employees
policy_description: Government agencies may conduct administrative proceedings by remote means.
intended_duration: Until end of state of emergency

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Casinos/gambling facilities; Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Government/public buildings; Personal care facilities
policy_description: Gyms must prioritize services outdoors when possible. All other business limitations and reopenings continue unchanged, with a 50% occupancy limit.

Restaurants and bars face new, additional restrictions for indoor dining, with occupancy limited at 25% and a prohibition on bar-style seating. They must follow distancing and sanitation guidance when operating for indoor and outdoor dine-in.
Nightclubs statewide must close.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: All businesses must now have employees work from home where possible. (This policy had previously been phased out as counties entered the Green Phase, but now it is reinstated).

Restaurants may increase indoor occupancy to 50% effective September 21, if owners self-certify that they are meeting current social distancing obligations. Restaurants who complete this process will be mailed materials to advertise their compliance with social distancing rules to boost consumer confidence. Restaurants must also now observe a new curfew on the sale of alcohol. All restaurants and bars must continue to follow existing distancing and sanitation guidance when operating for indoor and outdoor dine-in.

Travelers into Pennsylvania must complete a 14-day quarantine upon arrival, or alternatively must obtain a negative COVID-19 test result in the 72 hours before entering Pennsylvania. Various categories of people are exempted, including those traveling for work.

Extension: Bars and restaurants are subject to various adaptation and mitigation measures, including occupancy limits and a prohibition on late-night alcohol sales. Bars are closed unless operating similar to restaurants (i.e. all alcohol sales are accompanied by a meal, and bar seating is not used). Restaurants may still increase indoor occupancy to 50% if owners self-certify that they are meeting current social distancing obligations.
A temporary 5pm curfew on the sale of alcohol at food service businesses (e.g. restaurants) is put in place for the day preceding Thanksgiving.

Venues hosting mass gatherings of any size (excluding places of worship) must adhere to specific occupancy limits, which are lower for indoor events and for events with more attendees. This replaces the previous hard limit on gatherings of over 250 individuals.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Businesses must continue to have employees work from home where possible.
Restrictions on visitors at nursing homes are ended.
Nightclubs statewide remain closed.
Businesses must continue to ensure distancing of at least six feet on their premises, and must post signage to that effect.

policy_subtarget: Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Personal care facilities
policy_description: In addition to statewide occupancy limits and mitigation measures for businesses, businesses offering entertainment, businesses offering personal care services, and gyms face additional, lower occupancy limits and restrictions.
Businesses must administer temperature checks and must send home any employees with elevated temperatures or other COVID-19 symptoms.

Businesses (excluding health care providers) must continue to take various enumerated adaptation and mitigation measures, such as cleaning high-touch surfaces, ensuring distancing among employees, having exposed or infected employees stay home, and limiting occupancy to a level that permits six feet of distance between households.

Public schools located in counties seeing substantial levels of COVID-19 transmission over the previous two weeks must either (A) comply with various adaptation and mitigation measures or (B) must move to entirely online instruction. (This policy is also described in record 72138.)

Public schools located in counties seeing substantial levels of COVID-19 transmission over the previous two weeks must either (A) comply with various adaptation and mitigation measures or (B) must move to entirely online instruction. (This policy is also described in record 72139.)

Extension with modifications: travelers into Pennsylvania must complete a 14-day quarantine upon arrival, or alternatively must obtain a negative COVID-19 test result in the 72 hours before entering Pennsylvania. Various categories of people are exempted, including those traveling for work and, newly, individuals under 12 years old.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Higher education; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: All school sports and in-person extracurriculars are cancelled, as are all sports leagues and tournaments; however, professional and collegiate sports may continue without spectators, so long as they comply with health guidance.
Indoor gyms and entertainment businesses must close.

The occupancy limit is lowered to 50% for all indoor businesses. Businesses (excluding health care providers) must continue to take the various other adaptation and mitigation measures established in previous orders, such as cleaning high-touch surfaces, ensuring distancing among employees, having exposed or infected employees stay home, and limiting occupancy to a level that permits six feet of distance between households.
Indoor dining is temporarily prohibited. (Outdoor dining may continue, subject to the adaptation and mitigation measures already established.)
Indoor events are capped at 10 attendees, while outdoor events are capped at 50. Places of worship are exempted.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Non essential workers (inclusive); Public sector/government employees
policy_description: Closure of all governmental operations, except for essential services.

A lockdown is declared. The use of motor vehicles is restricted except on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays for vehicles with license plate numbers ending in even numbers and Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays for those ending in odd numbers. On these days, vehicles may circulate only to gather essential supplies or to complete any of the allowed tasks.
Medical offices may open to see patients in person, but must continue to practice social distancing and see patients by appointment only. Elective surgeries may also begin again.
Starting June 16, restaurants are authorized to open to 50% capacity indoors.
Childcare centers may re-open during non-lockdown hours for staff only.
Extension of the lockdown (from 10pm-5am) until July 22, 2020.
Extension of the quarantine policy for all suspected and confirmed cases. Anyone who has reasonable suspicion that they have been exposed to COVID-19 must quarantine in isolation for 14 days
Extension of the lockdown (from 10pm-5am) until July 31, 2020.
Extension of the quarantine policy to July 31, 2020. Anyone who has reasonable suspicion that they have been exposed to COVID-19 must quarantine in isolation for 14 days
Extension of the lockdown (from 10pm-5am) until August 21, 2020. People may not leave their homes on Sundays at any time, unless they have specific permission to do so.
Extension of the lockdown (from 10pm-5am) until October 16, 2020. People may not leave their homes on Sundays at any time, unless they have specific permission to do so.
Governor Gina Raimondo fully prohibited visitors at nursing homes.
Governor Gina Raimondo ordered that anyone testing positive or diagnosed based on symptoms must self-isolate. Civil penalties may be assessed against anyone breaking this quarantine order.
RIPTA states no more than 15 passengers will be allowed on any fixed-route bus, also passengers are asked to wear face masks.

policy_subtarget: Public sector/government employees; General population (inclusive); Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: RIDOH shall establish distancing and sanitation guidelines for all businesses.
Personal service businesses (such as barber shops, nail salons, tattoo parlors, and tanning salons) may open but follow regulations set by RIDOH.
Non-critical businesses may continue in-store pick up and limited browsing. Can allow 1 customer per 150 square feet.
All state parks and beaches can now open. Limited capacity and parking.

Gyms and fitness centers may begin reopening. In outdoor settings, capacity must be maintained at one person per 150 square feet. Group classes can not exceed 15 people and must maintain social distancing guidelines.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Government/public buildings; Public sector/government employees
policy_description: Supersedes an order that government meetings may only be conducted by telephonic or electronic means. Now they may occur in the open and allow for public access.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Government/public buildings; Public sector/government employees
policy_description: Extension: Government meetings may occur in the open and allow for public access.
Indoor settings can increase up to one person per 100 square feet or up to 66% capacity. This includes places like offices and restaurants.
Social Gathering limit expanded to no larger than 25 people indoors or 50 people outdoors.
Public events can be up to 125 people indoors or up to 250 people outdoors. Any organizers planning to host a group of more than 100 people will need to submit plans to Commerce RI.
Governor Gina Raimondo ordered that anyone testing positive or diagnosed based on symptoms must self-isolate. Civil penalties may be assessed against anyone breaking this quarantine order.
Extension: Various restrictions on summer camps, including limiting them to groups of 15 people. They may not begin operations until 6/29/2020.
Recreation and entertainment businesses and historical/cultural establishments may operate at 66% capacity or 1 person per 100 square feet.
Concert halls, theaters, and performance venues may operate at 66% capacity or 1 person per 100 square feet. At a cap of 125 people.
Prohibit gathering of more than 15 people in public or private indoor spaces. Gatherings inside restaurants may have up to 50 people, with proper licensing.

Religious organizations may conduct in person activities at 66% capacity or 1 person per 100 square feet. At a cap of 125 people. Outdoor gatherings are restricted to 250 people max. (social distancing measures apply)

extension: Personal service businesses (such as barber shops, nail salons, tattoo parlors, and tanning salons) may open but follow regulations set by RIDOH and only allow 1 person per 100 square feet.
Retail businesses may allow 1 customer per 100 feet (previously 150 feet).
Prohibit gathering of more than 15 people in public or private outdoor spaces. Outdoor gatherings at a restaurant or with catering may have up to 100 people, with proper licensing.

policy_subtarget: Non essential workers (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: Working at home strongly encouraged. 66% of workers may work on site. (social distancing measures apply).
extension: restaurants may continue limited seating and outdoor dining.

policy_subtarget: Non essential workers (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive)
policy_description: All office based businesses must follow state requirements on cleaning, screening employees, masks, and contact tracing.

policy_subtarget: Older adults/individuals with underlying medical conditions
policy_description: Vulnerable populations (including those 65 years and older) advised to stay home.
Governor Henry McMaster ordered correctional and detention facilities to halt visitation at state and local correctional facilities, as needed.
Governor Henry McMaster ordered that only essential government employees work in-person.
Governor Henry McMaster ordered police to prohibit or disperse any gathering of 3 or more that an officer deems a potential threat to public health.

policy_subtarget: Hospitals/urgent care/emergency medical services; Essential workers (inclusive)
policy_description: Orders the implementation of non-congregate temporary quarantine solutions for first responders or health care workers and indigent populations.
Governor Henry McMaster ordered that individuals maintain 6 feet of space when in public.
All elections scheduled to occur between 3/15 and 5/12, which had previously been delayed, are rescheduled to 7/14/2020.

policy_subtarget: Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Personal care facilities
policy_description: Bowling alleys are permitted to reopen.
Nursing homes may resume limited visitation for immediate family members of residents.
South Carolina restricts alcohol sales in bars and restaurants after 11pm.
Continuation: Governor Henry McMaster ordered police to prohibit or disperse any gathering of 3 or more that an officer deems a potential threat to public health.
Governor Henry McMaster repealed an order that individuals maintain 6 feet of space when in public.

policy_subtarget: Entertainment/concert venues/nightclubs; Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Personal care facilities
policy_description: All business closures end.
Restaurants must screen employees for symptoms (including by checking their temperatures), and must post signs stating that symptomatic patrons may not enter.
Individuals participating in a mass gathering (defined as an event drawing a large number of people) must wear face coverings.
Restaurant staff, patrons, and other occupants must wear face coverings except while eating/drinking.
Continuation: Governor Henry McMaster ordered that only essential government employees work in-person.

Restaurants must take reasonable steps to comply with state and local reopening requirements, must limit occupancy to 50%, and must take meet listed distancing, sanitation, and mitigation measures if they are to operate.
Sales of alcohol continues to be prohibited after 11pm at restaurants and similar establishments.
Individuals shall wear face coverings in government facilities.

policy_description: Mass gatherings (defined broadly) are limited to 50% occupancy of the space or 250 people, must adhere to social distancing guidelines, and may not involve the sale or consumption of alcohol between 11pm and 10am.

Rescinds 50% occupancy limit on restaurants. Social distancing and other mitigation measures are strongly encouraged, but no longer required. Sales of alcohol continues to be prohibited after 11pm at restaurants and similar establishments.

policy_description: Nursing homes must limit visitors (no additional details given).

Governor Greg Abbott today issued a proclamation suspending provisions of the Texas Election Code to allow political subdivisions to postpone their 2020 local elections.  This means local governments now have the ability to postpone their May 2, 2020 elections until November 3, 2020.

Executive Order GA-11 and the March 29, 2020 proclamation are hereby rescinded and terminated to the extent applicable to travelers from the City of New Orleans or the State of Louisiana. Any mandatory self-quarantine already in effect as a result of these executive orders, to the extent applicable to travelers from the City of New Orleans or the State of Louisiana, is terminated immediately as of the effective date of this executive order.  Every person who enters the State of Texas as the final destination through an airport, from a point of origin or point of last departure in the following—State of California; State of Connecticut; State of New York; State of New Jersey; State of Washington; City of Atlanta, Georgia; City of Chicago, illinois; City of Detroit, Michigan; or City of Miami, Florida—shall be subject to mandatory self-quarantine for a period of 14 days from the time of entry into Texas or the duration of the person’s presence in Texas, whichever is shorter. The governor may by proclamation add to or subtract from the list of states and cities covered by this executive order. This order to selfquarantine shall not apply to people traveling in connection with military service, emergency response, health response, or critical-infrastructure functions, as may be determined by the Texas Division of Emergency Management. Each person covered under this order to self-quarantine shall be responsible for all associated costs, including transportation, lodging, food, and medical care.  A covered person shall use a form prescribed by the Texas Department of Public Safety (DPS) to designate a quarantine location in Texas, such as a residence or a hotel, and provide a full name, date of birth, home address, telephone number, and driver license or passport information.

policy_subtarget: Criminal justice system/prisons/jails/incarcerated persons; General population (inclusive)
policy_description: Governor Greg Abbott today modified his executive orders related to COVID-19 to eliminate confinement as a punishment for violating these orders. These modifications are being applied retroactively.   Per Gov. Abbott: "This order is retroactive to April 2nd, supersedes local orders and if correctly applied should free Shelley Luther. It may also ensure that other Texans like Ana Isabel Castro-Garcia and Brenda Stephanie Mata who were arrested in Laredo, should not be subject to confinement. As some county judges advocate for releasing hardened criminals from jail to prevent the spread of COVID-19, it is absurd to have these business owners take their place.”

Governor of Texas, under the authority vested in me by the Constitution and laws of the State of Texas, do hereby suspend Sections 41.007(d) and 41.008 of the Texas Election Code to the extent necessary to allow the Midland County Hospital District to order its special election to occur on July 14, 2020, as an emergency election on the question of whether to adopt a program to sustain the district pursuant to Section 41.0011(b) of the Texas Election Code. I further suspend Section 85.001(a) of the Texas Election Code to the extent necessary to allow early voting by personal appearance for the special election to begin not earlier than Monday, July 6, 2020, and to run concurrently with the early voting period for the runoff primary election.  The authority ordering the election under Section 3.004 of the Texas Election Code is the authority authorized to make the decision to postpone its election in accordance with this proclamation. Early voting by personal appearance shall begin on Monday, July 6, 2020, in accordance with Section 85.001(d) of the Texas Election Code so that it runs concurrently with the early voting period for the runoff primary election.

Governor Greg Abbott today announced that the Texas Department of Public Safety (DPS) will begin a phased opening of driver license offices starting May 26th with limited service offerings. As part of this opening plan, DPS will launch a statewide driver license (DL) appointment system that allows customers to book appointments up to six months in advance. The limited services being offered will be by appointment only.

Governor Greg Abbott today issued an Executive Order suspending in-person visitations in all county and municipal jails in the state of Texas. This restriction does not apply to visitation by an attorney meeting with a client or a religious leader or member of the clergy.

policy_subtarget: Essential business (inclusive); Non essential business (inclusive); Government/public buildings
policy_description: With few exceptions, businesses may open at 50% capacity.  There is no occupancy limit for the following: a. any services listed by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security’s Cyhersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) in its Guidance on the Essential Critical Infrastructure Workforce, Version 3.1 or any subsequent version;  b. religious services conducted in churches, congregations, and houses of worship; c. local government operations, including county and municipal governmental operations relating to licensing (including marriage licenses), permitting, recordation, and document-filing services, as determined by the local government; d. child-care services; e. youth camps, including but not limited to those defined as such under Chapter 141 of the Texas Health and Safety Code, and including all summer camps and other daytime and overnight camps for youths; and f. recreational sports programs for youths and adults;  Except as provided below by paragraph number 5, this 50 percent occupancy limit does not apply to outdoor areas, events, or establishments, except that the following outdoor areas or outdoor venues shall operate at no more than 50 percent of the normal operating limits as determined by the owner: a. professional, collegiate, or similar sporting events; b. swimming pools; c. water parks; d. museums and libraries; e. zoos, aquariums, natural caverns, and similar facilities; and f. rodeos and equestrian events;  This 50 percent occupancy limit does not apply to the following establishments that operate with at least six feet of social distancing between work stations: a. cosmetology salons, hair salons, barber shops, nail salons/shops, and other establishments where licensed cosmetologists or barbers practice their trade; h. massage establishments and other facilities where licensed massage therapists or other persons licensed or otherwise authorized to practice under Chapter 455 of the Texas Occupations Code practice their trade; and c. other personal-care and beauty services such as tanning salons, tattoo studios, piercing studios, hair removal services, and hair loss treatment and growth services  Amusement parks and carnivals shall operate at no more than 50 percent of the normal operating limits as determined by the owner, except that in counties with more than 1 ,000 cumulative cases of COVID- 19, amusement parks may not begin operating until 12:01 a.m. on June 19, 2020.  For indoor bars and similar indoor establishments that are not restaurants as defined above and that hold a permit from the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Commission, only those customers who are seated may be served.
This bill would require county elections officials to mail a ballot to every registered voter for the November 3, 2020, statewide general election.
Outdoor gatherings of 100 or more people must be approved by local governments, with certain exceptions.

All bars and similar establishments that receive more than 51% of their gross receipts from the sale of alcoholic beverages are required to close at 12:00 PM today. These businesses may remain open for delivery and take-out, including for alcoholic beverages, as authorized by the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Commission.   Restaurants may remain open for dine-in service, but at a capacity not to exceed 50% of total listed indoor occupancy, beginning Monday, June 29, 2020.  Rafting and tubing businesses must close.

The Governor issued a proclamation giving mayors and county judges the ability to impose restrictions on some outdoor gatherings of over 10 people, and making it mandatory that, with certain exceptions, people cannot be in groups larger than ten and must maintain six feet of social distancing from others.

Theaters, opera houses, concert halls, and music halls may open at a limited capacity subject to social distancing, sanitation, and other restrictions.

Daycares and child care centers may operate with sanitation, screening for symptoms prior to entry, social distancing during drop off and pickup, and other restrictions; the facility must close if there is a confirmed case of COVID-19.

Extends orders of protection and temporary injunctions that would otherwise expire between March 18, 2020 and May 31, 2020.

Extends the order suspending rules regarding paper copies of pleadings in the Supreme Court and the order adopting procedures for remote administration of oaths and witnesses, verification of guilty pleas, and for paper filings.

Jury trials may only be conducted if a jury trial operating plan has been adopted by the relevant judges, submitted to the county health officer without objection, and submitted to the Wyoming Supreme Court, subject to other restrictions.

In-person proceedings in all Circuit and District Courts and the Supreme Court are suspended, with specified exceptions including proceedings necessary to protect constitutional rights of criminal defendants and proceedings related to emergency child custody orders.

Extends order that allows nail salons, hair salons, barber shops, cosmetology, electrology, and esthetic services, non-medical massage therapy services, and tattoo, body art, and piercing shops to operate with requirements including social distancing and face coverings.

Extends order that mass gatherings of more than 50 people in a confined space are prohibited. In some cases gatherings of more than 50 but less than 250 people may be allowed subject to restrictions including social distancing and face coverings.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Higher education
policy_description: Continuation; K-12 schools, colleges, universities, and trade schools may resume on-campus instruction provided that groups are limited to 50 people, social distancing is practiced, and sanitation requirements are adhered to.

Restaurants, cafes, bars, and other places of public accommodation offering food, beverages, or alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption may provide indoor and outdoor services, subject to restrictions including social distancing.
Continuation; gymnasiums may open at limited capacity (maximum of one person per 120 square feet) with social distancing, sanitation, and other requirements.
Extends order that gymnasiums may operate.
Extends order that child care centers or home daycares may operate.

Extends order that restaurants, food courts, and other places of public accommodation offering food, beverages, or alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption may provide indoor and outdoor services.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Higher education
policy_description: Extends order that K-12 schools, colleges, universities, and trade schools may provide on-site instruction to students.

Prohibits gatherings of more than 50 people in a single room or confined space. Exempts gatherings at specific places from this order, including hotels and motels for lodging purposes, grocery stores, healthcare facilities, and religious organizations, among others. Events not specified by name or type within this order may allow indoor gatherings of more than 50 but no more than 250 people, and outdoor gatherings of more than 50 people but no more than 50% venue capacity (or 250, whichever is greater), with a maximum of 1,000 people.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Higher education
policy_description: On-site instruction in K-12 schools, colleges, universities, and trade schools is subject to groups being limited to 50 individuals per room with social distancing being maintained as much as possible and up to 250 individuals in rooms where social distancing can be maintained at all times, face masks being worn when social distancing cannot be maintained, and hand hygiene requirements, among other restrictions.

Extends order that nail salons, hair salons, barber shops, cosmetology, electrology, and esthetic services, non-medical massage therapy services, tattoo, and tattoo, body art, and piercing shops may operate.

The operation of nail salons, hair salons, barber shops, cosmetology, electrology, and esthetic services, non-medical massage therapy services, tattoo, and tattoo, body art, and piercing shops is subject to social distancing, screening of employees for symptoms or exposure to COVID-19, patrons wearing face coverings as much as possible, staff wearing face coverings when they cannot maintain social distancing, and sanitation protocols, among other restrictions.
Extends order that movie theaters, performance theaters, opera houses, concert halls, and music halls may operate.

Authorized gatherings of more than 50 people are subject to the number of people in any confined area of the event to be limited to allow for social distancing between households, the prohibition of close contact between members of different households, the wearing of face coverings when social distancing cannot be maintained, and protective equipment for staff, among other restrictions.

The operation of movie theaters, performance theaters, opera houses, concert halls, and music halls is subject to social distancing, hand hygiene, face coverings for staff when they cannot maintain social distancing, encouraging patrons to wear face coverings, and screening of employees for COVID-19 symptoms, among other restrictions.

The operation of gymnasiums is subject to restrictions including staff coming within 6 feet of others must wear face coverings, employees must be screened for COVID-19 symptoms, indoor close-contact group activities are prohibited, workout equipment must be at least 6 feet apart and cleaned by staff in between each use, the number of patrons in the facility may not exceed 1 person per 120 square feet, and disinfection and hygiene requirements, among others.

Restaurants and other places of public accommodation offering food, beverages, or alcoholic beverages must limit table groups to 6 (unless all from the same household), and position tables such that there is six feet between each table when patrons are seated, maintain physical distancing. Staff coming within 6 feet of others must wear face coverings, staff must perform hand hygiene between interactions with each table. Disinfecting protocols must be followed, among other requirements.

The operation of child care centers or home daycare is subject to hand washing upon arrival for children and providers, screening of staff and children for COVID-19 symptoms upon arrival, prohibition of symptomatic individuals from entering the facility, social distancing during drop off and pickup, and sanitation, among other restrictions.
Extends order that gymnasiums may operate under restrictions enforced by the facility owner.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Higher education
policy_description: Extends order that K-12 schools, colleges, universities, and trade schools may provide on-site instruction to students.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Indoor spaces; Outdoor recreation or space
policy_description: Extension prohibiting indoor and outdoor gatherings in a single room or confined space over 50 people. Outdoor gatherings not specified in this order are allowed to reach no more than 50% of venue capacity (or 250 persons, whichever is greater), with a maximum of 1,000 people as long as social distancing and increased sanitization measures are in place. Indoor gatherings in a confined space not specified in this order may exceed 50 persons but may not go over 250 persons if social distancing and sanitization measures are incorporated.
Extends order that child care centers or home daycares may operate under restricted conditions.

Extends order that nail salons, hair salons, barber shops, cosmetology, electrology, and esthetic services, non-medical massage therapy services, tattoo, and tattoo, body art, and piercing shops may operate.

Extends order that restaurants, food courts, and other places of public accommodation offering food, beverages, or alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption may provide indoor and outdoor services so long as they follow restrictions as enforced by the business owner.

Gatherings at the following are exempted from this order: hotels, livestock auctions, worker transportation, government business, military and National Guard, law enforcement, jails and correctional facilities, federal/ state/ local facilities, relief facilities, residential buildings (not including individual households), grocery stores, pharmacies, gas stations, truck stops, auto-repair facilities, retail establishments where more than 50 people are present but not within 6 feet of each other, healthcare facilities, funeral homes, religious organizations, parades, healthcare facilities, long term care facilities, alcohol/ drug treatment centers
Extends order that movie theaters, performance theaters, opera houses, concert halls, and music halls may operate with limited capacity following restrictions enforced by facility owner.

EXTENSION: Restaurants and other places of public accommodation offering food, beverages, or alcoholic beverages must limit table groups to 6 (unless all from the same household), and position tables such that there is six feet between each table when patrons are seated, maintain physical distancing. Staff coming within 6 feet of others must wear face coverings, staff must perform hand hygiene between interactions with each table. Disinfecting protocols must be followed, among other requirements. Employees shall be screened for symptoms of COVID-19 prior to each shift.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Participants in organized sporting events are prohibited from congregating in groups over 50 people.

EXTENSION: The operation of movie theaters, performance theaters, opera houses, concert halls, and music halls is subject to social distancing with groups limited to 6, hand hygiene, face coverings for staff when they cannot maintain social distancing, encouraging patrons to wear face coverings, and screening of employees for COVID-19 symptoms, among other restrictions.

Extension of order stating the operation of nail salons, hair salons, barber shops, cosmetology, electrology, and esthetic services, non-medical massage therapy services, tattoo, and tattoo, body art, and piercing shops is subject to social distancing, screening of employees for symptoms or exposure to COVID-19, patrons wearing face coverings as much as possible, staff wearing face coverings when they cannot maintain social distancing, proper PPE for staff, recording of staff working hours for contact tracing, and sanitation protocols, among other restrictions.

EXTENSION: The operation of child care centers or home daycare is subject to hand washing upon arrival for children and providers, screening of staff and children for COVID-19 symptoms upon arrival, prohibition of symptomatic individuals from entering the facility, social distancing during drop off and pickup, and surface sanitation, among other restrictions.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Higher education
policy_description: Extends order that K-12 schools, colleges, universities, and trade schools may provide on-site instruction to students.

policy_subtarget: Gym/workout facility/fitness center; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Extension: Permits indoor close-contact group activities including indoor close contact sports to occur in all settings

Gatherings at the following are exempted from this order: hotels, livestock auctions, worker transportation, government business, military and National Guard, law enforcement, jails and correctional facilities, federal/ state/ local facilities, relief facilities, residential buildings (not including individual households), grocery stores, pharmacies, gas stations, truck stops, auto-repair facilities, retail establishments where more than 50 people are present but not within 6 feet of each other, healthcare facilities, funeral homes, religious organizations, parades, healthcare facilities, long term care facilities, alcohol/ drug treatment centers

Extends order that nail salons, hair salons, barber shops, cosmetology, electrology, and esthetic services, non-medical massage therapy services, tattoo, and tattoo, body art, and piercing shops may operate.
Extends order that child care centers or home daycares may operate under restricted conditions.

policy_subtarget: Primary education; Secondary education; Higher education
policy_description: EXTENSION: On-site instruction in K-12 schools, colleges, universities, and trade schools is subject to groups being limited to 50 individuals per room with social distancing being maintained as much as possible and up to 250 individuals in rooms where social distancing can be maintained at all times, face masks being worn when social distancing cannot be maintained, hand hygiene requirements, and social distancing during transportation, among other restrictions.

Extension of order stating the operation of nail salons, hair salons, barber shops, cosmetology, electrology, and esthetic services, non-medical massage therapy services, tattoo, and tattoo, body art, and piercing shops is subject to social distancing, screening of employees for symptoms or exposure to COVID-19, patrons wearing face coverings as much as possible, staff wearing face coverings when they cannot maintain social distancing, proper PPE for staff, recording of staff working hours for contact tracing, and sanitation protocols, among other restrictions.

EXTENSION: Restaurants and other places of public accommodation offering food, beverages, or alcoholic beverages must position tables such that there is six feet between each table when patrons (up to 8 except for groups with persons are from the same household) are seated, maintain physical distancing. Staff coming within 6 feet of others must wear face coverings, staff must perform hand hygiene between interactions with each table. Disinfecting protocols must be followed, among other requirements. Employees shall be screened for symptoms of COVID-19 prior to each shift.

EXTENSION: The operation of gymnasiums is subject to restrictions including staff coming within 6 feet of others must wear face coverings, employees must be screened for COVID-19 symptoms, indoor close-contact group activities are prohibited, group workout classes permitted with under 50 people remaining 6 ft apart at all times, workout equipment must be at least 6 feet apart and cleaned by staff in between each use, the number of patrons in the facility may not exceed 1 person per 120 square feet, and disinfection and hygiene requirements, among others.

EXTENSION: The operation of movie theaters, performance theaters, opera houses, concert halls, and music halls is subject to social distancing with groups limited to 8 (unless from the same household), hand hygiene, face coverings for staff when they cannot maintain social distancing, encouraging patrons to wear face coverings, and screening of employees for COVID-19 symptoms, among other restrictions.

policy_subtarget: Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor recreation/sports facility
policy_description: Participants in organized sporting events are prohibited from congregating in groups over 50 people.

policy_subtarget: General population (inclusive); Outdoor recreation or space; Indoor spaces
policy_description: Extension prohibiting indoor and outdoor gatherings in a single room or confined space over 50 people. Indoor gatherings not specified in this order are allowed to reach over 50 people but no more than 250 people as long as social distancing and increased sanitization measures are in place. Outdoor gatherings in a confined space not specified in this order may allow more than 50 people but no more than 50% of venue capacity (or 250, whichever is greater) with a maximum of 10000 people. The number of persons per table allowed at indoor and outdoor gatherings is 8 persons (with exceptions for groups from the same household).

EXTENSION: The operation of child care centers or home daycare is subject to hand washing upon arrival for children and providers, screening of staff and children for COVID-19 symptoms upon arrival, prohibition of symptomatic individuals from entering the facility, social distancing during drop off and pickup, and surface sanitation, among other restrictions.
